KG, Q-Park Operations Netherlands B.V., Q-Park Real Estate Netherlands B.V., Q-Park Duitsland B.V., Q-Park Limited, Universal Parking Limited, Q-Park UK Limited and Q-Park (Taunton) Limited; - “Indenture” refers to the indenture dated January 18, 2024 between, _inter alios, the Issuer, the Guarantors, the Trustee and the Security Agent, as amended and/or supplemented form time to time, pursuant to which the 2029 Notes were issued and pursuant to which the New Notes will be issued; - “Initial Collateral” refers to the security on a first-ranking basis, subject to the operation of the Agreed Security Principles, certain perfection requirements and any Permitted Collateral Liens (as defined in “Description of the Notes—Certain Definitions”), over (a) certain bank accounts of the Issuer and the Parent, (b) intercompany receivables owing to the Parent from the Issuer and (c) shares of capital stock (or partnership interests, as applicable) of the Issuer, Q Park B.V., Q-Park Real Estate Holding B.V., Q-Park Operations Holding B.V., Q-Park Operations Netherlands B.V., QPark Real Estate Netherlands B.V., Q-Park Duitsland B.V., Q-Park Limited, Universal Parking Limited, Q-Park UK Limited and Q-Park (Taunton) Limited held by the Initial Security Providers, to be confirmed on the Issue Date; xxv ----- - “Initial Purchasers” refers to, collectively, BofA Securities Europe SA, KKR Capital Markets (Ireland) Ltd, NatWest Markets N.V., Coöperatieve Rabobank U.A. and ING Bank N.V. - “Initial Security Providers” refers to, collectively, the Issuer, the Parent, Q Park B.V., Q-Park Real Estate Holding B.V., Q-Park Operations Holding B.V., Universal Parking Limited and Q-Park UK Limited, which shall each confirm the Initial Collateral on the Issue Date; - “Intercreditor Agreement” refers to the intercreditor agreement dated February 13, 2020, by and among, inter alios, the Issuer, the Guarantors, the Trustee and the Security Agent, as amended and/or restated from time to time; - “Issue Date” refers to the date on which the New Notes will be issued, which will be       , 2024; - “Issuer” refers to Q-Park Holding I B.V., a private company with limited liability (besloten _vennootschap met beperkte aansprakelijkheid) incorporated under the laws of The Netherlands;_ - “KKR” refers to Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Co. L.P. and its affiliates and co-investors, and any fund, partnership and/or other entities represented, managed, advised, owned or controlled directly or indirectly by it or any of them; - “KKR Infrastructure” refers to KKR Global Infrastructure Investors II fund held by KKR; - “Lenders” refers to the Lenders under the Amended Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement; - “Marseille Concession Agreement” refers to the concession agreement dated December 2, 1991 with Q-Park France SAS to operate parking facilities in Marseille, France, the original 30-year term of which (plus an extension of two and a half years) ended on June 2, 2024 since our bid for renewal of the concession in a public tender process was not successful; - “New Notes” refers to the €550,000,000 in aggregate principal amount of     % Senior Secured Notes due 2030 offered hereby; - “Noteholders” refers to the holders of the New Notes; - “Offering” refers to the offering hereby of the New Notes; - “Operating Facilities” refers to any indebtedness incurred as Operating Facilities as described under “Description of the Notes—Certain Covenants—Limitation on Indebtedness”; - “Parent” refers to Q-Park Holding B.V. (formerly known as Byzantium Acquisition MidCo 2 B.V.), a private company with limited liability (besloten vennootschap met beperkte aansprakelijkheid) incorporated under the laws of The Netherlands; - “PensionDanmark” refers to PensionDanmark Pensionsforsikringsaktieselskab and its affiliates, and any fund, partnership and/or other entities represented, managed, advised, owned or controlled directly or indirectly by it or any of them; - “Pro Forma Transactions” refers to collectively to the Amsterdam City Tender, the Denmark Acquisition, the Tazbell Acquisition, the Britannia Acquisition and the Marseille Concession Agreement; - “Refinancing **Transactions” refers to: (i) the issuance by the Issuer of €550 million aggregate principal amount of New Notes offered hereby; (ii) the redemption of the entire outstanding principal amount of the 2025 Notes, together with accrued and unpaid interest thereon; (iii) the redemption of the entire outstanding principal amount of the 2026 Notes, together with accrued and unpaid interest thereon; (iv) the payment of costs, fees and expenses in connection with the foregoing transactions, including the fees and expenses to be incurred in connection with the Offering and (v) the use of the proceeds for general corporate purposes; - “Restricted Group” refers to the Parent and its Restricted Subsidiaries as such term is defined in “Description of the Notes”; xxvi ----- - “Revolving Credit Facility” refers to the super senior revolving credit facilities of up to €270.0 million made available pursuant to the Amended Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement; - “Revolving Credit Facility Agreement” refers to the super senior revolving facility agreement dated February 13, 2020 (as amended by an amendment letter dated 18 November 2021), by and among, inter alios, the Issuer and the arrangers and lenders thereunder; - “SEC” refers to the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission; - “Safra” refers to the J. Safra Group and its affiliates, and any fund, partnership and/or other entities represented, managed, advised, owned or controlled directly or indirectly by it or any of them; - “Schroders” refers to Schroders plc, registered in England and Wales (company number: 3909886) and its affiliates, and any fund, partnership and/or other entities represented, managed, advised, owned or controlled directly or indirectly by it or any of them; - “Security Agent” refers to Wilmington Trust (London) Limited, in its capacity as security agent under the Indenture, the Intercreditor Agreement and the Amended Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement; - “Security Documents” refers to the agreements creating security interests over the Collateral as described under “Description of the Notes—Security”; - “SeNoFi” refers to our former Swedish, Norwegian and Finnish subsidiaries, which operated parking spaces in Sweden, Norway and Finland at the time of the announcement of the SeNoFi Disposal; - “SeNoFi Disposal” refers to our divesture of SeNoFi and our exit from these markets, which we concluded on April 30, 2019; - “Tazbell Acquisition” refers to the acquisition by Q-Park Ireland Ltd. of 100% of the issued share capital of Tazbell Services Group DAC, parent company of the Irish parking operator, Park Rite, completed on August 31, 2023; - “Trustee” refers to BNY Mellon Corporate Trustee Services Limited, in its capacity as trustee under the Indenture; - “United Kingdom” or “UK” refers to the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland; - “U.S. dollar” or “$” refers to the lawful currency of the United States; - “U.S. Exchange Act” refers to the U.S. Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended; and - “U.S. Securities Act” refers to the U.S. Securities Act of 1933, as amended. xxvii -----

In this Offering Memorandum, unless the context otherwise requires: - “ANPR” refers to automatic number plate recognition technology, which is used to identify customers at the entry and exits of car parks; - “brown field” refers to the acquisition of an existing parking facility; - “concession” or “concession agreement” refers to a public lease, for which the lease amount is paid upfront (concession fee) and where the lessee takes the operational risks and rewards of a facility. Our concession agreements principally only exist in France, and these are regulated under French law; - “control fee” refers to a contract, for which we provide a service to enforce the parking policy within a specific site on behalf of a landlord. This is done by writing control fees (i.e., fines) for detected parking violations; - “EV” or “EVs” refers to vehicles that can be powered by an electric motor that draws electricity from a battery and is capable of being charged from an external source; - “EV charging” refers to the supply of electrical power for recharging EVs; - “green field” refers to a concession or contract that provides for the construction of a new parking facility; - “ground lease” refers to a limited real right to a property, such that we own the property in or on another person’s land or we have the exclusive use of another person’s property and land. Ground lease is a collective of several country specific constructions, including erfpacht/ opstalrecht in The Netherlands and Belgium, erbbaurecht in Germany and droit emphytéotique or droit de superficie in France; - “ICT” refers to our information and communication technology systems; - “legally owned” refers to the legal ownership of both the ground and the property; however, in the United Kingdom this is synonymous with a freehold ownership; - “long-term business” refers, collectively, to our legally owned, ground lease, protected lease, concession and long-term lease business; - “long-term lease” refers to lease contracts that are not already qualified as a protected lease, a concession nor a ground lease and have an initial duration of at least 15 years at inception. We pay an annual rent and bear the commercial risk during the lease contract; - “management contract” refers to a contract for which we provide operational services of the parking facility and receive a (fixed or variable) management fee, often on a cost-plus basis. We do not bear the commercial risk for the parking activities and the parking revenues are for the benefit of the landlord; - “mobility as a service (MaaS)” refers to providing travelers mobility services that are based on their travel needs. This is enabled by combing transportation services from public and private transportation providers through a unified identifier; - “Park +” refers to providing customers parking solutions, often through online pre-booking, linked to their next destination or activity. Best known examples include “Park + Fly,” which provides customers the option to pre-book (including online pre-booking) parking spaces at parking facilities that are located at or close to airports, giving customers the ability to park their cars and catch a flight conveniently and efficiently, “Park + Ride,” which provides customers the option to pre-book (including online pre-booking) parking spaces at parking facilities that are located at or close to public transportation sites, especially train stations and “Park + Charge,” which provides customers the option to charge their EVs using the EV charging points when parked in our parking facilities; xxviii ----- - “PaSS” refers to Parking as a Smart Service, which is our digital service offering for registered customers who desire a seamless parking experience without the need for cash, credit card or tickets. We enable this digital product via ANPR technology; - “PMS” or “parking management system” refers to the system used to control entry and exit by customers into and out of our parking facilities. This includes the physical barriers at entry and exit, payment machines, including the tariff and billing logistics; - “PMS Connected facilities” refers to the parking facilities where the parking management system (PMS) of such facility is connected to our transactional database which enables us to collect transactional data of the parking transactions at such facility (such as entry time, exit time and duration); - “protected lease” refers to tenant protection, found in certain jurisdictions, regarding commercial lease contracts. In terms of countries where we operate, this protection is applicable in Ireland. These leases are separately qualified since the duration is, due to the protection, in theory indefinite; - “QCR” refers to the Q-Park Control Room, which is run by trained staff that remotely control and manage a substantial majority of our parking facilities; - “short-term business” refers, collectively, to short-term leases, control fees and management contracts; - “short-term lease” refers to lease contracts that are not already qualified as a protected lease, a concession or a ground lease, and have an initial duration of less than 15 years. We pay an annual rent and bear the commercial risk during the lease contract; - “smart city” refers to a concept where connected infrastructure and an intelligent ecosystem allow cities of the future to engage municipalities, residents, businesses and visitors in a more efficient way. MaaS and smart parking are sub-components of this concept, to be enabled via seamless connectivity with the smart city ecosystem; and - “Weighted Average Remaining Duration” refers to the average duration weighted by Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs) based on the remaining term of each individual contract (legally owned, ground leases, concessions, protected leases and long-term leases where contract information was available) using 100 years for legally owned, infinite ground leases and protected leases. xxix -----

Subsection Title: Overview
Subsubsection Text: We are a leading parking infrastructure owner and operator in the Western European market, with a large and diversified portfolio of owned, leased and managed parking facilities across seven Western European countries. We mainly operate off-street parking spaces owned by us as well as parking spaces under concessions and longterm leases from public and private landlords, with a focus on off-street purpose-built parking facilities at strategic locations. We operate 4,315 parking facilities comprising 896,187 parking spaces as of March 31, 2024 in The Netherlands, France, the United Kingdom, Germany, Belgium, Denmark and Ireland. As of March 31, 2024, our long-term business portfolio included 64 legally owned facilities, 66 ground lease facilities and five protected lease facilities, 187 concession facilities and 402 long-term lease facilities, which together comprised over 320,000 parking spaces. As of March 31, 2024, our short-term business comprised 3,591 facilities and over 576,000 parking spaces. Based on a third party consultant report, we are a top three player as of December 31, 2023, based on off-street parking revenue, in all of the countries in which we operate. Below are charts showing the percentage of Underlying Gross Margin generated by country of operation and our contract mix by Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs) for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024.

Subsection Title: Underlying Gross Margin[1] by Geography Underlying Gross Margin[1] by Contract Type
Subsubsection Text: 1 Underlying Gross Margin excludes non-allocated and central operating costs. 2 Includes short-term leases, control fees and management contracts. 1 ----- For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our Underlying Total Revenue was €852.5 million, our Underlying Gross Margin was €287.7 million and our Underlying EBITDA was €235.5 million. Our operations in The Netherlands, France and the United Kingdom, respectively, represented 34.5%, 20.6% and 15.4% of our Underlying Total Revenue, 39.2%, 28.1% and 6.7% of our Underlying Gross Margin and 43.0%, 30.5% and 6.6% of our Underlying EBITDA for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. We started our operations in the European market in The Netherlands in 1998, and expanded to Belgium, Germany and the United Kingdom in the early 2000s. We have consistently secured long-term contracts and built a portfolio of prime parking locations in The Netherlands, France, the United Kingdom, Denmark, Ireland, Belgium and Germany, including multi-functional parking facilities near inner-city areas, public transport interchanges, airports and hospitals. Multi-functional parking facilities serve multiple urban needs (such as city centers, shopping centers, hospitals and railway stations). Due to a variety of physical, regulatory and other constraints such as cost and availability of space, we believe that there is limited opportunity to develop alternative parking options in many of these prime areas, allowing us to benefit from a degree of captive demand with limited competition in some areas. We generate revenues under the following main business lines: - _Parking revenues. Our off-street parking business primarily comprises parking facilities owned and operated by us or operated by us under contract (both short-term parking and long-term parking). We have a healthy mix of short- and long-term parking customers. Short-term parking includes shorter term parking customers, such as per-hour or per-day tickets. Short-term parking generated 75.5% of our Underlying Parking Revenues for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. Long-term parking includes customers holding season tickets, including monthly, quarterly and annual season tickets. Long-term parking generated 24.5%% of our Underlying Parking Revenues for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. Short-term parking customers provide immediate payment in cash or by debit or credit cards at the gates and physical barriers present in our parking facilities, while long-term parking customers provide revenue stability and advance payments. Underlying Parking Revenues represented 87.5% of our Underlying Total Revenue for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. We generally retain all fees generated from operating the relevant parking facility. In respect of parking facilities owned by us, we are responsible for all expenses relating to the parking facility, including operation, maintenance and management. Under our concession and lease contracts, we are responsible for all expenses relating to operating and maintaining the parking facility during the term of the concession or the lease. - _Non-parking revenues. o _Control fees. Control fees are predominantly generated in Denmark and represent income arising from enforcement of paid parking (for example, parking fines) in parking facilities (usually above ground) owned by the Group and/or by landlords. Landlords generally contract with parking facility operators like us to eliminate or reduce the misuse of parking spaces (for example, misuse of handicap spaces, parking on rescue roads, misuse of reserved parking spaces and long-term parking in spaces intended for short-term parking). Underlying Control Fees represented 3.0% of our Underlying Total Revenue for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. o _Management fees. Our management fees business represents the fixed and variable fees we receive for operating parking facilities under contracts with third parties including public authorities as well as private landlords and other private entities. Our Underlying Management Fees represented 5.6% of our Underlying Total Revenue for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. o _Rental income. In addition to owning, operating and managing parking facilities, we lease certain of our owned parking facilities to the municipality of Amsterdam. Rental income also includes the income from the lease of parts of our facilities to third parties that use the space for parking, storage or to provide spaces used for business operations, such as refrigeration or storage facilities for restaurants. Our Underlying Rental Income represented 1.8% of our Underlying Total Revenue for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. o _EV charging fees. We launched the EV Charging Program in May 2022 to substantially increase the number of EV charging points in our owned and long-leased parking facilities by the end of 2024. We earn fees from our customers who use the EV charging points provided at our parking facilities. 2 ----- Our Underlying EV Charging Fees represented 0.8% of our Underlying Total Revenue for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. o _Other revenues. Other revenues include all other revenues not included in the categories above, such as subsidies, ancillary revenues, revenue from other alternative uses of our parking facilities and other services such as vending machines placed in our parking facilities. Our Underlying Other Revenues represented 1.3% of our Underlying Total Revenue for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024.

Subsection Title: Strengths
Subsubsection Title: Large and Growing Market with Strong Fundamentals
Subsubsection Text: The off-street parking industry in Western Europe is highly fragmented with a limited number of large players. Accordingly, leading parking infrastructure players like us are better positioned than smaller operators to take advantage of positive industry dynamics and benefit from the resilience and maturity of the market. Our operations are supported by a growing customer base, well-established presence and favorable pricing dynamics. As an established market player, we have consistently grown our total revenue for the past 25 years (other than in 2020, when our revenues were impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic). The European countries in which we operate have also seen continued growth in light vehicle fleet which, according to GlobalData, is expected to grow at a CAGR of 0.5% over the next decade. Personal cars (excluding ride hailing and taxis) are also expected to remain the most popular form of transport, accounting for 45% of trips worldwide, ahead of public transport, ride hailing and other mobility modes, according to The Future of Mobility, McKinsey Quarterly Report, published in April 2023. In addition, we believe that upfront costs and regulatory requirements (including obtaining planning permissions to build new high density parking facilities, complying with regulatory frameworks governing parking concessions and navigating contracts with municipalities) and the economies of scale that result from operating multiple facilities across multiple geographies present significant challenges for new entrants in the car parking industry in Western Europe. In addition, our long-standing relationship with municipalities enables an ongoing dialogue with public sector players, allowing us to be a key counterpart in discussions to improve local and regional mobility solutions. This provides us with opportunities to expand our existing business with such municipalities, and we are well positioned to handle their requirements. Although our volumes (measured by sold hours in respect of our PMS Connected facilities) across the broader transport sector were negatively impacted by the mobility restrictions imposed in response to the COVID-19 pandemic between 2020 and 2022, car traffic (and closely linked to it, toll road traffic) has experienced the fastest pace of recovery among the broader transport sector. As of December 31, 2023, our LFL short term parking volumes (measured by sold hours in respect of our PMS Connected facilities) have recovered to approximately 102% of 2019 levels, while air cargo remains below 2019 levels. A similar recovery in volume has also been experienced across other parking operators in Western Europe, demonstrating the structural resilience of the broader parking sector and a proven ability to recover from industry disruption at a faster pace compared to other traffic-exposed asset classes. Further, we believe that the parking sector is expected to benefit from key trends in the industry, including, for example, (i) the regulatory shift away from on-street parking with reduced on-street parking provisions in low emission zones and/or in densely populated cities, (ii) increasing priority given to pedestrians, cyclists and various forms of shared mobility (including car sharing and public transport) as cities and municipalities increase their sustainability focus, (iii) change in consumer dynamics to focus more on experiences and (iv) carbon neutrality and “green city” goals of various jurisdictions. The increased focus on electrifying the car fleet to meet “green city” objectives is expected to drive the penetration of EVs in Europe from approximately 1% in 2020 to approximately 18% by 2030. We believe that we are well positioned to take advantage of these trends given our (i) continued focus on off-street parking, (ii) strategically located parking assets to capture continued demand, (iii) our highly developed technology platform that provides a digital parking ecosystem and seamless customer 3 ----- experience journey and (iv) the deployment of our EV Charging Program, which we launched in May 2022 to substantially increase the number of EV charging points (“CP”) in our owned and long-leased parking facilities to 5,500 by the end of 2024. As of December 31, 2023, our parking facilities offer 4,114 EV CPs, of which 2,996 are part of our “asset-heavy model,” whereby such EV CPs are owned by us but operated by third parties. We aim to profitably expand our EV charging business through an increasing number of EV CPs in our owned and longleased parking facilities in line with the continued increase in penetration of EVs in Europe.

Subsection Title: Strengths
Subsubsection Title: Leading Off-Street Parking Infrastructure Owner and Operator in Western Europe with Local Scale and Diversified Portfolio of Value Creating Assets in Strategic Locations
Subsubsection Text: We are one of the leading off-street car park infrastructure owners and operators in the Western European parking market, with 4,315 parking facilities comprising 896,187 parking spaces as of March 31, 2024. Based on a third party consultant report, we have a top three market position as of December 31, 2023 in all of the Western European countries in which we operate based on off-street parking revenue. Our large footprint across our seven countries of operation allows us to build on a local scale in each of these markets. Our size and scale allows us to operate our car park portfolio efficiently, for example through sharing resources among our car parks (in particular, in clusters where we operate multiple parking facilities in close proximity), including maintenance and supervisory staff, as well as management resources in respect of accounting, marketing, human resources, insurance and tax matters. The number of our locations and the connectivity of our parking facilities through our digital capabilities and proprietary technology gives us a commercial advantage and enables us to anticipate customer needs across multiple locations. For example, our access to real-time transactional data on occupancy and availability of our parking facilities enables us to better anticipate and predict customer demand. In addition, due to our size and scale, we are better equipped to make significant investments in IT and to leverage such investments across our operations compared to smaller competitors. Between January 1, 2021 and March 31, 2024, we invested approximately €32 million in Underlying ICT & Other Capex, which includes investments in enhancements of infrastructure and cyber security. Such operational efficiencies and cost savings generated through IT initiatives and investments allow us to offer attractive terms to municipalities and landlords and operate a differentiated pricing model. Finally, the size and diversity of our portfolio means that we have significant experience with different operating models, allowing us to adapt effectively and efficiently to different contract types and regulatory structures. Our market leading positions, size and growth have allowed us to achieve significant economies of scale, and the scope of our operations and the quality of our assets have supported the quick recovery of our Underlying Total Revenue following the COVID-19 pandemic. We have been able to achieve operational efficiencies and cost savings through the implementation of a streamlined and lean management and governance structure across our operations. Our economies of scale enable us to be a consolidation platform for European parking operations and allow us to undertake and quickly integrate valuable new concessions and acquisitions of smaller players, as well as individual assets and lease contracts. In addition, through our experienced management team, and due to our long-standing reputation in the industry, we have been able to develop and maintain important relationships with various municipalities and private landlords with whom we do business, thereby reducing our dependence on any single local governmental authority or region. In the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, no single contract represented more than 3% of our total Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs) and no single city represented more than 11% of our Underlying Total Revenue or our Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs). We have strategically positioned our portfolio to focus on off-street parking in line with the regulatory shift in favor of off-street parking. Our off-street parking business and on-street parking business represented approximately 90% and 10%, respectively, of our Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs) for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. Off-street parking contracts are typically longer duration contracts (generally more than 15 years) in comparison to on-street parking contracts (generally less than five years). This generates long-term cash flows with a balanced mix of short- and long-term parking customers. Short-term parking customers provide immediate payment, while long-term parking customers provide revenue stability and advance payments. Further, off-street parking is supported by the presence of physical barriers, which limits fee evasion, facilitates prompt payment and enables revenue stability. Our business benefits from a portfolio of parking facilities and parking spaces which is highly diversified in terms of number of contracts, type of contract, number of municipality clients, number of private landlords and types of parking services we deliver. We operate across seven countries in Western Europe which have attractive and mature parking market dynamics at the inflection point for growth through digitization and electrification. As of March 31, 2024, we had a total of 380,701 parking spaces in The Netherlands, 131,957 parking spaces in France, 4 ----- 46,124 parking spaces in the United Kingdom, 82,672 parking spaces in Germany, 181,916 parking spaces in Denmark, 55,824 parking spaces in Belgium and 16,993 parking spaces in Ireland. Below is a chart that presents the breakdown of our Underlying Total Revenue by country for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024.

Subsection Title: Strengths
Subsubsection Text: We believe that we have several competitive advantages in the car park sector in Western Europe, including our local market leadership positions, high quality real estate portfolio, long-term cash flow visibility, resilient and diversified business profile, strong asset locations and a scalable platform with tangible growth opportunities across our core parking business, digitalization, EV charging and mobility solutions. As a result of these strengths, together with the key infrastructure features that underpin our business model and the continuing regulatory shift in favor of off-street parking, our business benefits from a high level of stable and recurring cash flows.

Subsection Title: Underlying Revenue per country
Subsubsection Title: Robust and Stable Financial Profile with Long Term Historical Track Record and Predictable Cash Flows Underpinned by Real Asset Ownership and Long-Term Contracts
Subsubsection Text: For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, 89.6% of our Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs) was generated by our long-term business. We benefit from long-term visibility of cash flows, and the correlation of parking demand to the total size of the car fleet (rather than GDP) enhances the stability of our revenues over long periods and helps ensure resilience through periods of economic downturn. We have demonstrated consistent revenue growth over the past 25 years (other than during the period impacted by COVID-19), with a strong recovery following the impact of COVID-19. Although our business was negatively impacted during 2020 and 2021 as a result of mobility restrictions put in place in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, our Underlying Total Revenue has recovered to above 2019 levels, and for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, has grown at a CAGR of 4.2% since 2017. The decrease in our Underlying Total Revenue in 2020 and marginal increase in 2021 was primarily driven by increased volatility in Underlying Short-Term Parking Revenue, which dropped immediately in response to COVID-19 restrictions, while Underlying LongTerm Parking Revenue remained relatively stable over the period. Our performance has consistently improved independent from economic cycles, with an average Underlying Likefor-Like Parking Revenue Growth Rate of 4.5% over the period from January 1, 2014 through March 31, 2024, compared to a real gross domestic product (“GDP”) average growth rate of 1.8% and consumer price index (“CPI”) annual inflation of 2.1% during the same period.

Subsection Title: Underlying Revenue per country
Subsubsection Text: Within these countries, our portfolio is spread across approximately 352 cities with no significant exposure to one city. Our top city (Amsterdam, with 31 parking facilities as of March 31, 2024) represented approximately 11% of our Underlying Total Revenue with our top 20 cities representing approximately 54% of our Underlying Total Revenue for the three months ended March 31, 2024. Across these cities, we operate a tailored approach with the type of contract tailored to the country of operations. Our business primarily comprises (i) legally owned properties, (ii) long-term leases, (iii) concessions, (iv) ground leases, (v) protected leases and (vi) short-term leases. As such, we have a portfolio consisting of both parking facilities owned and operated by us as well as those operated by us under contracts (both long-term and short-term), as well as ancillary services such as our control fee business. As of March 31, 2024, our long-term business portfolio included 64 legally owned facilities, 66 ground lease facilities and five protected lease facilities, 187 concession facilities and 402 long-term lease facilities, which together comprised over 320,000 parking spaces and accounted for approximately 89.6% of our Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs) for the three months ended March 31, 2024. As of March 31, 2024, our short-term business comprised 3,591 facilities and over 576,000 parking spaces and accounted for approximately 10.4% of our Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs) for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. Our parking business is also diversified in terms of location (inner city centers, hospitals, shopping areas and transport links). We believe our limited reliance on any single parking facility is a significant factor in diversifying our source of revenues and therefore reduces our cash flow volatility. Our parking facilities are typically not dedicated to a single institution or purpose and are mostly multi-functional, meaning they are used by drivers that may be using the car park to visit different locations, whether it is for work, shopping, cultural activities, or other purposes. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, 70% of our Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs) was generated by multi-functional facilities. We believe that we enjoy a prime position in the relevant local area with respect to a significant proportion of our parking facilities. Our prime locations, the multi-functionality of our car parks and the challenges in building new car parks help mitigate competition risk in our business. Further, our multi-functional car parking facilities also have alternative uses and can potentially be a source of ancillary revenues (for example, as storage facilities or refrigeration for restaurants, car rental, car sharing, bike parking, or as a last mile delivery hub). The remaining 30% of our Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs) for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024 was generated by mono-functional facilities, which are selected on a strategic basis with the aim of ensuring stability of demand. We generally target regional and/or national partnerships (for example, operating Park + Ride solutions for the Dutch railways (NS)) with municipalities and local authorities and/or transport hubs. Our parking business is also diversified in terms of our end users. We process over 100 million transactions annually across both short-term and long-term parking. This gives us access and exposure to and insight into the behavior of a highly diversified customer base. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our short-term 5 ----- parking business represented 66.1% of our Underlying Total Revenue from more than 81.5 million transactions. Our typical short-term parking customer pays for transactions on a per-hour or per-day basis and typically stays at our facilities for an average of two to four hours per transaction. These customers are largely occasion-driven with predominantly low recurrence. On the other hand, for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our longterm parking business represented 21.4% of our Underlying Total Revenue from more than 20.5 million individual single-stay transactions. Our typical long-term parking customer pays for the transaction in advance, usually with the purchase of a monthly, quarterly, half-yearly or annual season ticket, and typically stays at our facilities for an average of eight to ten hours per transaction. These customers constitute our known loyal customer base and currently consist of more than 100,000 season ticket holders. The remaining 12.5% of our Underlying Total Revenue in the twelve months ended March 31, 2024 consists of management fees, control fees, rental income, EV charging fees and other income. We believe our diversified business portfolio differentiates us from other infrastructure companies, who typically rely on a smaller number of large contracts or concessions, or strong concentrations in a single geography, resulting in a greater concentration of risk.

Subsection Title: Underlying Like-for-Like Parking Revenue Growth Rate, compared to real GDP and CPI growth
Subsubsection Text: Note: GDP and CPI for geographies Belgium, Denmark, France, Germany, Ireland, The Netherlands and United Kingdom. 1 Based on Euromonitor data. Country metrics are weighted by share of Underlying Total Revenue for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. 2 Based on percentage change from period to period in the Underlying Parking Revenues generated from parking facilities categorized as LFL operations. We define Underlying Like-for-Like Parking Revenue Growth Rate as the as the percentage change from period to period in the Underlying Parking Revenues generated from parking facilities that we categorize as LFL operations. A parking facility is included in LFL operations: (a) until 2019, if it has an initial duration of five years or more and has operated for at least two full financial years, measured as of the beginning of the current financial year, and (ii) from and including 2020, if it has an initial duration of five years or more and has operated during the full reporting period from 2019 until the current reporting period, in each case, excluding any facilities which are due to expire in the current reporting period, facilities that are newly opened in the current reporting period and certain facilities that are not fully operational (for example, due to refurbishment). Given the foregoing, the number any identity of parking facilities making up our LFL operations up to and including the year ended December 31, 2019 is different from the number and identity of parking facilities making up our LFL operations from the year ended December 31, 2020 onward, so the periods are not fully comparable. Following COVID-19, volumes have recovered rapidly, and our total volume has been above 2019 levels since April 2023, despite price increases. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our Underlying EBITDA was approximately 8% higher than pre-COVID-19 Underlying EBITDA for the year ended December 31, 2019. The 6 ----- seasonality of our Underlying Total Revenue as of March 31, 2024 is also now consistent with pre-COVID-19 seasonality. See “Business—Parking Revenues.” Our cash flow generation benefits from an advantageous working capital cycle through the collection of upfront payments (through season tickets) from our long-term parking customers and revenue collection directly upon exit of the car park for our short-term parking customers. As a result of our low Underlying Existing Business Capex and Underlying ICT & Other Capex requirements, we have achieved Underlying FCF Cash Conversion Ratio of 74.6% and Underlying EBITDA Margin of 27.6% for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. We believe that our infrastructure portfolio is well invested. Our portfolio comprises a mix of legally owned assets, protected leases, ground leases, long-term leases, concessions, other short-term leases and other contracts (including management contracts, rental contracts and contracts in relation to our EV charging business). Below is a chart that presents the breakdown of our Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs) by contract type for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024.

Subsection Title: Underlying Gross Margin[1] by Contract Type
Subsubsection Title: Scalable Platform Well Positioned for Sustainable Growth
Subsubsection Text: The scale in our countries of operation provides us a platform to grow the business (both organically and inorganically) in a sustainable and intentional manner while positioning ourselves to take advantage of the positive trends in digitization and EV charging infrastructure. We benefit from an industry where demand is relatively inelastic to price, although specific contractual arrangements may limit pricing flexibility. We believe that consumer choice regarding parking is not primarily driven by price but by factors such as location and distance to destination, parking availability, security, payment type and more recently, the availability of EV charging points. In addition to this, by virtue of the type of contracts we have entered, approximately 67% of our portfolio benefits from inflation protection either through full discretion on prices or through contractually agreed inflation-linked protection and we have partial flexibility in respect of the remaining 33% of our portfolio as of March 31, 2024. This combined with our scale and leadership position affords us “pricing power,” which provides us freedom to introduce price increases in line with or ahead of inflation, as illustrated by the charts below.

Subsection Title: Underlying Gross Margin[1] by Contract Type
Subsubsection Text: 1 Underlying Gross Margin excludes non-allocated and central operating costs. 2 Includes short-term leases, control fees and management contracts. We have long-term cash flow profile visibility with 89.6% of our Underlying Gross Margin (excluding nonallocated and central operating costs) for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024 comprising primarily facilities that are owned or operated under our long-term business, of which 83% are entitled to operate until at least 2033 (assuming no renewals, new business or price indexation), as illustrated by the following chart. 1 Underlying Gross Margin excludes non-allocated and central operating costs. 2 Based on Underlying Gross Margin for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, excluding non-allocated and central operating costs. As of March 31, 2024, the Weighted Average Remaining Duration of our long-term contracts was approximately 47 years. Furthermore, our portfolio is backed by significant real asset ownership. As of March 31, 2024, the 7 ----- market value of our real estate portfolio, predominantly located in large and attractive cities, was €1.8 billion. The portfolio comprises 123 properties consisting of legally owned and ground leases. Such market value has been prepared without comprehensive due diligence or the benefit of an inspection of all of the properties. We believe that our strategic focus on owned facilities and long-term contracts has resulted in a stable business model, which enables us to attract customers and is supported by the high volume of cars and growing urbanization where our parking facilities are located. These prime locations provide flexibility and stability to our business, combined with stability of demand, leading to revenue stability as evidenced by the historical evolution of our revenues over time. In certain circumstances (primarily in relation to concessions in France), the long-term contracts and concessions include a protection mechanism allowing renegotiation of payments to local municipalities in case a certain level of performance is not achieved, thereby providing protection in case of lower demand. Further, in respect of our ground leases, there is typically a protection mechanism where the municipality is required to pay compensation to us in the event the municipality intends to terminate the ground lease or expropriate the property, thereby providing us adequate security and stability. Our business model shares all the key features of infrastructure assets, including long-term cash flow visibility, physical and high value assets, central role in the local economy, proximity to public sector players, embedded hedge against inflation, limited correlation to economic cycles, resilient revenue generation, and a favorable and stable regulatory environment with certain protections for us in the event of regulatory or administrative changes. Unlike some other infrastructure companies, our parking facilities, once operational, require relatively low levels of Underlying Existing Business Capex. Our limited Underlying Existing Business Capex, which averaged 5.0% of Underlying Total Revenue across the years ended December 31, 2021, 2022, 2023 and the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, are driven by our scale and preventive maintenance measures. Underlying Existing Business Capex relates to the upkeep of our existing facilities as well as repairs to our facilities to ensure they remain fully operational and compliant in line with our internal quality standards. As a result, we believe we are well positioned to benefit from returns on these investments without the need to incur significant Underlying Existing Business Capex with respect to these facilities. Our relatively low Underlying Existing Business Capex requirement allows us to focus on investment in other key areas of growth and portfolio investments, including portfolio expansion and new business, information and communications technology (“ICT”), digital solutions, CO2 reduction and new growth areas such as EV charging infrastructure.

Subsection Title: Pricing increases in line with / ahead of inflation
Short-term Parking Portfolio by Pricing Dynamics (based on Underlying Gross Margin)
Subsubsection Text: 1 Refers to facilities where we have the sole decision-making authority to change prices. 2 Refers to facilities with limited restrictions on our ability to change prices (such as mandated caps to price increases or requirements to obtain landlord or municipality consent to price increases). 3 Refers to facilities where price increases are stipulated by a specific index (usually on an annual basis). Despite these price increases, our volumes (measured by sold hours in respect of our PMS Connected facilities) have continued to recover in 2023 and 2024 with our LFL short term parking volumes (measured by sold hours in respect of our PMS Connected facilities) surpassing pre-COVID-19 levels in the second quarter of 2023 and the positive trend continuing into the third quarter of 2023. Our season ticket volumes were fairly stable throughout the COVID-19 pandemic, with the lowest point in the period, from January 2020 to September 2022, being approximately 6% below January 2020, which was immediately prior to the impact of COVID-19. Following the easing of lockdowns, our season ticket volumes have recovered to pre-COVID-19 levels. This reflects the price inelastic nature of our volume demand, as illustrated by the charts below.

Subsection Title: Short-term Parking LfL volumes above 2019 levels since Q2 2023 Long-term Parking volumes fairly stable through COVID-19 in comparison to the year ended December 31, 2019
Subsubsection Title: Strong and Focused Management Team with Track Record of Strategy Execution and Actionable Sustainability Commitments
Subsubsection Text: Our senior management team has significant experience and understanding of the car park sector. Our senior management team has consistently outperformed budget targets and has a strong track record of strategy execution, which can also be attributed to the senior management team’s ability to anticipate and embrace new trends and technology in the car park sector. This has enabled us to be a pioneer in the deployment of efficient transformational programs, revenue management and digitalization programs, user friendly applications, such as PaSS, and sustainability initiatives, such as our EV Charging Program. Our senior management team has also shown its capability in successful portfolio management with the constant delivery of new contracts and active acquisition activity, with 68 signed deals (seven acquisitions and 61 asset deals) since 2021. In addition, our local management teams are well-connected to industry bodies and groups as well as local municipalities and maintain strong and long-standing local relationships with the relevant regulatory authorities in the jurisdictions in which we operate, and our regional management teams also have extensive sector experience. Our regional teams comprise senior people having local presence, some of whom also hold prestigious positions with local municipalities and regulatory authorities. We believe that our parking facilities are an essential part of the urban mobility infrastructure and thus part of our contribution to the transition to zero-emission mobility. We have been contributing to sustainable mobility for many years, and have been reporting annually on sustainability, based on the GRI Standards, since 2011. While our early sustainability efforts were focused on raising awareness and integrating sustainable development in our day-to-day business, since 2017 we have shifted our focus to developing and implementing shared solutions, including through identifying how we can contribute to achieving the UN Sustainable Development Goals and our role in helping society progress toward Europe’s aim to be climate neutral by 2050. Our sustainability commitments are focused on key areas that have been identified as most relevant to our stakeholders, including sustainable mobility, digitization, electrification, energy consumption and liveability. Promoting sustainable mobility is central to our efforts, and we believe that our focus on off-street parking supports this goal in a number of ways. 225 of our parking facilities were located near public transport hubs as of December 31, 2023, an increase of 2.3% since December 31, 2022, enabling our customers to take advantage of alternative lower-emission forms of transport. As of December 31, 2023, 506 of our parking facilities offered online pre-booking, which reduces the amount of traffic caused by motorists circling city streets searching for a place to park. The increase in the availability of pre-booking solutions has been driven by our focus on digitization, primarily through PaSS, which has also enabled us to process customer information more efficiently and improved our informed decision-making capabilities.. In line with the increasing penetration of EVs in Europe, we have also significantly increased the number of EV charging points in our parking facilities, from 2,114 as of December 31, 2021 to 4,114 charging points as of December 31, 2023. In addition to supporting the shift to more sustainable mobility in the communities in which we operate, we have also improved our own performance on ESG metrics, particularly with respect to energy consumption and our overall carbon footprint. As of December 31, 2023 the total energy consumed in our parking facilities has decreased by 12.7% since the year ended December 31, 2021. Our efforts to reduce our energy consumption and to source more green energy has led to a decrease in our average carbon footprint per parking space in owned and long-leased parking facilities from 179.1 kg of CO2 in the year ended December 31, 2010 to 45.4 kg of CO2 as of December 31, 2023, a decrease of 74.6%. We believe that these efforts have contributed significantly to our goal of enhancing urban liveability and helping society move toward zeroemission mobility

Subsection Title: Short-term Parking LfL volumes above 2019 levels since Q2 2023 Long-term Parking volumes fairly stable through COVID-19 in comparison to the year ended December 31, 2019
Subsubsection Text: 9 ----- Our economies of scale also enable us to be a consolidation platform and we have successfully continued to expand our portfolio inorganically, including during the COVID-19 pandemic, through a prudent and returndriven decision-making process across acquisitions, contract wins and contract renewals. From January 1, 2021 to March 31, 2024, we signed a total of 61 asset deals for parking facilities for new business including for the operation of facilities) consisting of 38 new operating contracts for parking facilities and 23 negotiated contract renewals for parking facilities, as well as seven bolt-on acquisitions of parking facilities, contributing approximately €40.3 million in “run-rate” EBITDA for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, which represents the EBITDA generated from all new contracts signed during the relevant period, assuming that each new contract is being performed at its full maturity potential assessed by us at the time of signing of such contract on the basis that (i) all parking spaces under each contract will be made available during the relevant period, (ii) all revenue generating functions of our business have been realized and (iii) the customary ramp-up period has passed. The 61 new asset deals and seven bolt-on acquisitions have an average contract duration of approximately 18 years and have an average period to recover the costs from the “run-rate” EBITDA of such assets of approximately five years. Since January 1, 2023, we completed four key transactions (“Recent Transactions”): - the Britannia Acquisition, pursuant to which Q-Park UK Limited acquired 100% of the issued share capital of Britannia Parking Group Limited, a parking operator in the United Kingdom, which was completed on June 4, 2024 and was funded using cash on balance sheet; - the Amsterdam City Tender, relating to the public tender by the City of Amsterdam that was awarded to Q-Park Operations Netherlands B.V. on August 14, 2023 pursuant to which Q-Park Operations Netherlands B.V. provides on-street parking services for approximately 160,000 parking spaces and will provide on-street parking services for up to 262,000 parking spaces in Amsterdam, The Netherlands, and related services such as transactions, enforcement, permits and parking meters, for a period of eight years commencing January 1, 2024; - the Denmark Acquisition, pursuant to which Q-Park Operations Denmark A/S acquired City Parkeringsservice A/S, a Danish parking operator and control fee business in Denmark, completed on October 4, 2023; and - the Tazbell Acquisition, pursuant to which Q-Park Ireland Ltd. acquired 100% of the issued share capital of Tazbell Services Group DAC, parent company of the Irish parking operator, Park Rite, completed on August 31, 2023. We estimate that these Recent Transactions collectively would contribute approximately €10.3 million to our Pro _Forma Underlying EBITDA for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024._ Alongside our portfolio expansion, we have invested in the growth of our digital parking ecosystem, PaSS (Parking as a Smart Service), which allows us to offer increased convenience and certainty and a seamless customer experience. As of December 31, 2023, 75% of our parking facilities were PaSS-enabled (excluding management contracts and stalling garages) and 9% of LFL operations were processed through PaSS. PaSS provides us with the opportunity to differentiate online and offline parking tariffs, supporting product diversification and optimization of capacity. Across our digital platform, we focus on pre-booking revenues in event-driven areas with high and stable demand (such as airports, hotels, cruise terminals and event centers) and revenues from repeat short-term parking customers who increasingly value a seamless customer experience. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our digital revenues (calculated as revenues from (i) customers prebooking through our services as well as third party services, (ii) the Q-Park App and (iii) customers pre-booking parking at our airport facilities in the UK and Germany) were €83 million. Our digital revenues increased by 55% for the year ended December 31, 2023 compared to the year ended December 31, 2022 and by 40% for the three months ended March 31, 2024 compared to the three months ended March 31, 2023. We have also invested in expanding our business lines to take advantage of recent trends in the parking sector in order to generate incremental revenues. A key focus in this area has been the development of our EV Charging Program, which we launched in May 2022 to profitably expand our EV charging business through an increasing number of EV charging points in our owned and long-leased parking facilities in line with the growing demand for a publicly available charging infrastructure in our markets in Western Europe. As of December 31, 2023, we had 4,114 EV charging points across our parking facilities, which we estimate have enabled 63.7 million CO2free kilometers of driving for our customers since June 30, 2022. Adding EV charging points to our existing infrastructure enables us to take advantage of the continued trend toward electrification of the car fleet while 10 ----- requiring a low level of incremental investment and deploying capital at our own pace. As of March 31, 2024, we have invested approximately €12.9 million of capital expenditure in our EV Charging Program since 2022 and have realized a “run-rate” Underlying Gross Margin of approximately €4.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2023. We define “run-rate” Underlying Gross Margin as the annualized run-rate impact of EV charging volumes for the second half of the year ended December 31, 2023 (calculated on the basis of EV charging points installed capacity as of December 31, 2023) on the Underlying Gross Margin from our EV charging business for the year ended December 31, 2023.

Subsection Title: Strategy
Subsubsection Title: Maintain a Focus on our Diversified Portfolio and Profitable Assets in Strategic Locations
Subsubsection Text: We have a diversified portfolio of owned, leased and managed parking facilities, including concessions and contracts, in prime locations. Our infrastructure is well-invested, with a focus on the most attractive segments of the car parking market. We focus on smaller cities to benefit from their growth, and we will continue to seek to enhance profitability through portfolio optimization. We intend to focus our efforts on renewing our portfolio of existing contracts by maintaining our well invested assets to better manage future capital expenditure requirements and expanding our operations by capturing new opportunities that meet our stringent investment criteria. Due to our market leading position, scale and expertise, we believe that we are well positioned to continue to grow our diversified portfolio by renewing our existing contracts and capturing new contracts in value-enhancing locations from both existing customers seeking to award new contracts and from other organizations looking to outsource the operation of their parking facilities. Our selection of facility locations is driven by our long-term strategy to operate and expand in high margin cities. Our highly diversified geographical coverage spans across approximately 352 cities that have attractive market dynamics, with a strategic and tailored approach to different markets in an effort to drive higher returns. We may also acquire high-quality smaller car parks in small- and medium-sized cities to further diversify our portfolio and benefit from the potential for growth in these cities. We believe that our balanced focus on smaller cities reduces our exposure to changing urban trends and regulatory changes in larger cities. Due to our scale, long-standing industry experience and established relationships with municipalities and private landlords, we are typically able to achieve significant synergies that also allow us to offer competitive terms and win new business. We will continue to grow our parking facilities in clusters representing multiple locations in strategic cities, which enhances our pricing strategy through a more resilient local competitive dynamic, operational cost reduction given our ability to have a single task force servicing multiple locations and strong relationships with municipalities. Our ability to build and maintain relationships with municipalities makes us well positioned to negotiate and win long-term contracts and to avoid long-term regulatory risk. We have clusters in key cities including The Hague, Amsterdam, Maastricht, Rotterdam, Toulouse, Chambery, Leeds, Manchester, London, Dublin, Berlin, Dusseldorf, Antwerp, Hasselt and Brussels. In addition, we are often able to expand our locations to further facilities once we have entered a local market by virtue of our existing relationship with local authorities and the ability to benefit from synergies with existing parking facilities. We believe our position as one of the leading owners and operators of parking facilities in Western Europe, combined with our long-standing relationships with a diverse number of local authorities and favorable industry dynamics, will assist us in continuing to implement this strategy.

Subsection Title: Strategy
Subsubsection Title: Continue to Invest in a Differentiated Contract Offering with a Disciplined Investment Approach
Subsubsection Text: We believe that we are one of only a few infrastructure-based parking facilities operators in Europe that can offer the full spectrum of contracts, including ground leases, concessions, protected leases and long-term and shortterm leases. This offers us a high degree of adaptability to the most appropriate type of contract depending on the characteristics of each model and the demand in local markets. As of March 31, 2024, we had a diversified portfolio of 4,315 parking facilities in prime locations supporting stable and high demand, and 89.6% of our Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs) comprised long-term business, with the remaining 10.4% of our Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs) comprising short-term leases and other contracts and costs (including management contracts, rental contracts, contracts in relation to our EV charging business and leases with a duration of less than one year). Our other contracts typically have a fixed fee structure, which provides secured income visibility. This enables us to optimize and balance risk and return on our investment portfolio. Further, because our contract portfolio largely comprises long-term facilities (owned facilities, leased facilities (including long-term leases, ground leases and protected leases) and concessions), our Weighted Average Remaining Duration was approximately 47 years as of March 31, 2024, which provides a long-lasting cash flow profile. We also adopt a disciplined approach with respect to new investments and the expansion of our existing business. Our experienced Investment Committee (“IC”) reviews, appraises and assesses new investments. It reviews and advises on investment proposals from the country management teams with respect to potential new business (including the expansion of our existing business) and applies thorough and consistent criteria and analyses to provide a recommendation to the Executive Board to approve or reject the proposal. We will continue to take a 12 ----- disciplined approach to new investments, with different levels of advice, support and strategic guidance, which we believe will continue to generate robust revenues.

Subsection Title: Strategy
Subsubsection Title: Continue to Pursue Strategic Digital and Pricing Initiatives
Subsubsection Text: We believe we are industry frontrunners in pursuing strategic initiatives driven by digitalization trends. Key features of our technology platform include digital invoicing, Park + Events capabilities, pre-booking for city parking, on-street parking, near-time parking information, Park + Fly capabilities, equipping facilities with PaSS gateways and Park + Charge capabilities enabled by the rollout of our EV Charging Program. This is expected to serve as a basis for long-term operations standardization and digitalization. Such digital capabilities seek to increase control and ownership over data, enable the use of standard interfaces to communicate with our partners and facilitate the integration of potential acquisitions or new sites. Our digital capabilities also allow us to capture customers earlier in their journeys, by facilitating pre-booking of parking spaces via the Q-Park App, and provide opportunities for connections with third parties, such as other mobility providers and end users. Our local scale and digital leadership enable us to manage pricing. We believe that our diversified portfolio and differentiated contract offering provides price flexibility and enables us to select the contracts that best suit our investment portfolio. We are able to use such pricing flexibility as a lever to maintain stability of cash flows and sustain profitability. As demand for parking is relatively inelastic to price, we have been able to successfully pass through more than 100% of the impacts of inflation to our customers since October 2021, with no negative impacts on volume (measured by sold hours in respect of our PMS Connected facilities). Our data-driven pricing methodologies include measures such as differentiated pricing models (adaptation of prices based on demand and locations, such as peak hours, and online price differentiation with pre-booking), flexible pricing depending on frequency and duration, location-based pricing (such as premium pricing in city centers, medium-range pricing in Park + Walk locations and budget pricing in Park + Public Transport locations) and day tariffs optimization (through parking for over six or eight hours in strategic locations). Our advanced analytics leveraged through PaSS has enabled us to process customer information more efficiently and supported more informed decisionmaking, and we intend to continue to expand our analytical capabilities and increase our scale to drive digital leadership and pricing initiatives in the market.

Subsection Title: Strategy
Subsubsection Title: Enabler of Sustainable Livability through Active Participation in Mobility Solutions and Partnerships
Subsubsection Text: We aim to continue to focus on promoting sustainable livability, with a focus on customer satisfaction and convenience, by initiating partnerships across the mobility eco-system. We have introduced several mobility solutions to enhance customer experience. For example, our PaSS initiative is built around a public cloud-based technology platform that allows us to interact with and provide services to our customers and business partners virtually. Integrated payment systems such as PaSS enable us to partner with companies like EasyPark, RingGo and 4411. See “Business—ICT and Operations.” We work closely with local authorities including in The Netherlands (Maastricht, Rotterdam and Eindhoven) and Belgium (Antwerp) to develop facilities that enable travelers to park their cars or bicycles close to transport hubs so our facilities act as vital links in the mobility chain, connecting travelers with their final destination and acting as public transport transit points. As of December 31, 2023, we had 225 owned and long-leased parking facilities registered at or near major transport hubs, an increase of 2.3% compared to December 31, 2022. We have also introduced Park + Ride and Park + Walk facilities in The Netherlands, which are modern, integral parts of the mobility chain in many towns and cities across The Netherlands and are located in the vicinity of public transport so they are easy to access and find. Furthermore, as of December 31, 2023, we have installed 4,114 EV charging points in our parking facilities, of which 2,996 are revenue-generating. We will continue to seek and explore initiatives to enable urbanization, particularly those which we believe will give us the first mover advantage in the market and sustain our position as drivers of industry change and leadership.

Subsection Title: Strategy
Subsubsection Title: Capture Sustainable Value with Actionable ESG Commitments
Subsubsection Text: Sustainability is a key part of our strategic framework, and we believe that we are well positioned to capture value from the energy transition, particularly with respect to the evolution of the EV market. According to the IEA Global EV Data Explorer published in April 2024, the share of EVs in Europe as a proportion of the overall car fleet is expected to increase from 1.1% in 2020 to 11.1% in 2030, equivalent to approximately 61.2 million EVs. We believe that our established customer base and broad, well-invested existing infrastructure portfolio makes us well-placed to capitalize on the increasing penetration of EVs, as adding EV charging points to our existing infrastructure requires a low level of incremental investment. Approximately 85% to 90% of the EV charging market is destination charging, with a particular focus on residential, workplace and retail charging, and our existing parking facilities already cover approximately 55% to 65% of the catchment area for this destination 13 ----- charging, primarily through proximity to workplaces and retail locations. We have already installed 4,114 EV charging points in our parking facilities as of December 31, 2023, and we plan to have 5,500 EV charging points by the end of 2024. Outside of the scope of EVs, we aim to continue to focus across our business on enhancing urban liveability and connecting communities by providing sustainable mobility solutions and seamless parking services. Within a broader framework of key sustainability topics, we have focused on the top five material topics of liveability and the mobility transition, energy, digitization and innovation, renovation and maintenance and climate change mitigation, and we are in the process of developing specific key performance indicators (“KPIs”) and targets around these topics, informed by the EU Green Deal and EU Sustainability Reporting Standards (“ESRS”). We intend to incorporate ESRS references into our CSR report, with the goal of being fully in compliance with the EU Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (the “CSRD”) by 2025, which requires a double materiality threshold for reporting standards. Therefore, in 2023, we have conducted a double materiality analysis and analyzed both our impact on economic, environmental and social matters (i.e., impact materiality) and the financial impact of these matters on our business (i.e., financial materiality). In 2023, we have developed quantitative and realistic KPIs and targets for the top five material topics. Accordingly, the following are the targets that we aim to achieve by 2040 and are linked to our top five material topics: - achieving net zero emission through a market-based approach; - procurement of 100% renewable energy; - operating 20,000 EV charging points; - enabling two billion zero-emission kilometers through our EV Charging Program; - equipping 7.5% of our parking spaces with operated EV charging points; and - ensuring 45% of parking facilities offer alternative modes of transportation. Our aim is to complete our double materiality assessment in 2024. We will continue to leverage our sustainability efforts to date, including with respect to our EV Charging Program and reducing the carbon footprint of our parking facilities, with the goal of being the most preferred sustainable mobility hub partner by 2030.

Subsection Title: Strategy
Subsubsection Text: Our strategies focus on value creation, with the aim of enhancing urban liveability and connecting communities by providing sustainable mobility solutions and seamless parking services and a vision to become the most preferred sustainable mobility hub partner by 2030 in the countries in which we operate. We have a disciplined and conservative approach to investment. We intend to drive sustainable growth and sustained business performance through Underlying Like-for-Like Parking Revenue Growth Rate and portfolio growth, supported 11 ----- by value enhancement and revenue management programs, with a strong focus on sustainable development. Our strategies rely on strong processes and tools (such as data analytics, business development processes and feedback loops), our ICT and our brand. Our key strategies are the following:

Subsection Title: Recent Developments
Subsubsection Text: We are currently engaged in a process of soliciting offers for the purchase of a minority stake in the Group. We are in the process of evaluating a number of non-binding offers. While we have not sought offers to sell a controlling stake of the Parent, the non-binding offers we have received vary in their terms, including in relation to the stake sought to be purchased by potential bidders. Any offers will be subject to further negotiation and diligence. Should we decide to proceed with a binding offer at any time, this may ultimately result in a change in the composition and shareholding of the Consortium described in this Offering Memorandum. There is no assurance that that the Consortium members will retain their current interests in the Group.

Subsection Title: Recent Developments
Subsubsection Text: On June 4, 2024, we completed the Britannia Acquisition by which we acquired 100% of the issued share capital of Britannia Parking Group Limited, one of the leading parking operators in the United Kingdom. As part of the Britannia Acquisition, we acquired 629 car parks across the United Kingdom ranging from multi-storey parking facilities to conventional pay and display parking and added 62,000 parking spaces to our portfolio. The preliminary consideration paid for the Britannia Acquisition was €33.5 million (equivalent) which was funded from cash on balance sheet. With the Britannia Acquisition, we added 189 new sites that offer ANPR service, which will serve our seamless parking services and urban liveability vision and help strengthen our position in the United Kingdom.

Subsection Title: Recent Developments
Subsubsection Text: The original term of 30 years (plus an extension of two and a half years) of the Marseille Concession Agreement ended on June 2, 2024 in accordance with the terms of the agreement. Our bid for renewal of the concession in a public tender process was not successful. As of March 31, 2024, we operated 17 parking facilities in Marseille, 14 ----- France, five of which were operated pursuant to the Marseille Concession Agreement. We anticipate that the termination of the Marseille Concession Agreement will have a negative impact of approximately €3.9 million on our Pro Forma Underlying EBITDA for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. See “Underlying Financial _Data Derived from Management Accounts” for further information._

Subsection Title: The Issuer
Subsubsection Text: The Issuer was incorporated as a private company with limited liability (besloten vennootschap met beperkte _aansprakelijkheid) under the laws of The Netherlands on May 12, 2017 and is registered with the Dutch trade_ register under registration number 68751044. Its registered office is located at Spicalaan 39, 2132 JG, Hoofddorp, The Netherlands.

Subsection Title: Principal Shareholders
Subsubsection Text: KKR is a leading global investment firm with a long history of investing in Europe. Founded in 1976, KKR had $578 billion in assets under management as of March 31, 2024. With offices around the world, KKR manages assets through a variety of investment funds and accounts covering multiple asset classes. KKR seeks to create value by bringing operational expertise to its portfolio companies and through active oversight and monitoring of its investments. KKR complements its investment expertise and strengthens interactions with investors through its client relationships and capital markets platforms. KKR’s investment in the Group is held through KKR Infrastructure, which has a long-term approach to investing. KKR Infrastructure holds over 80 infrastructure investments globally within four strategies investing across North America, Europe and Asia-Pacific in a number of sub-sectors and geographies and has over 115 team members, including around 90 investment professionals, in addition to over 25 value creation executives dedicated to Infrastructure. KKR Infrastructure adopts a differentiated and disciplined risk-based strategy to its investments with focus on downside protection and low risk of capital impairment, and a conservative approach to leverage and structuring. As of March 31, 2024, KKR Infrastructure had a total of $61 billion in assets under management.

Subsection Title: Principal Shareholders
Subsubsection Text: Schroders Capital Management (France) (“SCMF”) is an affiliate of Schroders, which has £760.4 billion of assets under management as of December 31, 2023. SCMF has specialized in infrastructure financing since September 2015 as an investment solution for institutional investors willing to invest in the infrastructure sector through equity or debt. As of March 31, 2024, SCMF raised close to €5.0 billion of capital in both debt and equity. Its equity strategy is focused on strategic investments in core European infrastructure assets, generating predictable and resilient distribution to shareholders. Based in Paris, SCMF is led by Yves Desjardins and employed 25 professionals as of March 31, 2024. It is fully owned by the Schroders group through Schroders International Holding Limited, and authorized and regulated in France by the Autorité des Marchés Financiers (AMF) as an alternative investments management company (AIFM).

Subsection Title: Principal Shareholders
Subsubsection Text: Historically, EDF Invest has managed assets that contribute to the long-term financing of future decommissioning of EDF’s nuclear power plants in France.
