In addition, the holders of one series of Notes may be in a position to agree to certain terms in a consent solicitation that would be beneficial to such series of Notes but adverse to the economic interest of the other series of Notes; however, to the extent the relevant amendment or waiver is approved by the holders of a majority in aggregate principal amount of the Notes then outstanding (subject to the limited exceptions described above), all holders of the Notes (including holders of the New Notes) will be bound by such amendment. Furthermore, subject to certain restrictions, further series of additional notes may be issued under the Indenture which have different terms in respect of currency, interest rate and certain other matters. Such additional notes will generally vote as a single class with other series of notes issued under the Indenture but may have interests that differ from the holders of any other series of notes issued under the Indenture, including the New Notes.

Subsection Title: Risk related to Ownership The interests of the Issuer’s indirect principal shareholders may conflict with your interests.
Subsubsection Text: The interests of the Issuer’s indirect principal shareholders, in certain circumstances, may conflict with your interests as holders of the New Notes. The Issuer is indirectly controlled by KKR. See “Principal Shareholders.” The general meeting of shareholders controlled by KKR is able to appoint the Executive Board of Q Park B.V. (the direct subsidiary of the Issuer) and thus indirectly determine corporate strategy, management and policies. In addition, KKR has control over decisions to enter into any corporate transaction and has the ability to prevent any transaction that, in each case, requires the approval of shareholders regardless of whether holders of the New Notes believe that any such transactions are in their own best interests. For example, the shareholder of the Issuer could instruct the board of the Issuer to incur additional indebtedness, sell certain material assets or make dividends, which instruction must be followed by the board unless such instruction is contrary to the interests of the Issuer, in each case, so long as the Indenture, the 2020 Indenture, the Amended Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement and the Intercreditor Agreement so permit. The incurrence of additional indebtedness would increase the Issuer’s debt service obligations and the sale of certain assets could reduce its ability to generate revenue or, if the assets distributed or sold are Collateral, could reduce the amount of the asset sale proceeds available to repay the New Notes, each of which could adversely affect holders of the New Notes. Additionally, KKR is in the business of making investments in companies and may from time to time acquire and hold interests in businesses that compete directly or indirectly with the Issuer. KKR may also pursue acquisition opportunities that may be complementary to the Issuer’s business and, as a result, those acquisition opportunities may not be available to the Issuer. So long as KKR continues to control the Issuer, KKR will continue to be able to influence or effectively control the Issuer’s decisions. The interests of KKR may not coincide with your interests. Moreover, our shares are held by the Consortium members and any shareholder may decide to sell any or all of its interests at any time. Such sale would be subject to the provisions of the Indenture, the 2020 Indenture and the Amended Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement. There is no assurance that the Consortium members will retain their current interests. We are currently engaged in a process of soliciting offers for the purchase of a minority stake in the Group. Although a Change of Control would not be triggered by the sale of a minority interest, it may result in the introduction of a new shareholder, and such new shareholder may have interests that conflict with your interests as holders of the New Notes. In this regard, we are in the process of evaluating a number of nonbinding offers. While we have not sought offers to sell a controlling stake of the Parent, the non-binding offers we have received vary in their terms, including in relation to the stake sought to be purchased by potential bidders. Any offers will be subject to further negotiation and diligence. Should we decide to proceed with a binding offer at any time, this may ultimately result in a change in the composition and shareholding of the Consortium described in this Offering Memorandum. Any sale of more than a minority stake will result in a change of our 71 ----- controlling shareholders and may trigger a Change of Control under the Indenture, the 2020 Indenture and the Amended Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement. However, the Change of Control provision contained in the Indenture may not necessarily afford you protection in the event of such change in shareholding since there are certain exceptions to the definition of “Change of Control” which allow changes in the ownership of the Issuer if certain conditions are satisfied, including if a specified consolidated total net leverage ratio is not exceeded in connection with such Change of Control on one occasion. See “Risk Factors—Risks related to the New Notes, the _Guarantees and our Structure—We may not be able to obtain the funds required to repurchase New Notes upon a Change of Control.”_ 72 -----

_An investment in the New Notes involves a high degree of risk. You should carefully consider the following risks, together with other information provided to you in this Offering Memorandum, in deciding whether to invest in the New Notes. The occurrence of any of the events discussed below, whether alone or together with additional risks and uncertainties not currently known to us, could materially adversely affect our business, results of operations or financial condition. If these events occur, the trading prices of the New Notes could decline, and we may not be able to pay all or part of the interest or principal on the New Notes, and you may lose all or part of your investment. Additional risks not currently known to us or that we now deem immaterial could also adversely affect our business, results of operations, or financial condition or our ability to fulfil our obligations under the New Notes and affect your investment. The order in which the risks are presented is not an indication of the likelihood of the risks actually materializing, or the significance or degree of the risks or the scope of any potential harm to the Group’s business, financial condition, or results of operations. The risks mentioned herein may materialize individually or cumulatively. This Offering Memorandum contains “forward-looking” statements that involve risks and uncertainties. Our actual results may differ significantly from the results discussed in the forward-looking statements. Factors that might cause such differences include those discussed below and elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. See “Forward-Looking Statements.”_

Subsection Title: Sources** **€ in millions** **Uses** **€ in millions
Subsubsection Text: New Notes offered hereby[(1)] ............................ 550.0 Redemption of the 2025 Notes[(2)] ...................... 90.0 Redemption of the 2026 Notes[(3)] ...................... 400.0 Estimated interest, fees, costs and expenses[(4)] .. 9.0 Cash on balance sheet[(5)] .................................... 51.0

(1) Represents gross proceeds from the issuance of €550.0 million aggregate principal amount of New Notes offered hereby. (2) Represents the outstanding principal amount of 2025 Notes. As part of the Refinancing Transactions, the 2025 Notes will be redeemed in full on the Issue Date with the proceeds of the Offering. (3) Represents the outstanding principal amount of 2026 Notes. As part of the Refinancing Transactions, the 2026 Notes will be redeemed in full on the Issue Date with the proceeds of the Offering. (4) Represents (i) the estimated accrued and unpaid interest to, but excluding, the redemption date of the 2025 Notes, (ii) the estimated accrued and unpaid interest to, but excluding, the redemption date of the 2026 Notes, in each case, based on an assumed redemption date of July 3, 2024 and (iii) our estimate of certain fees, costs and expenses associated with the Refinancing Transactions to be paid using the sources set forth in the table above, including discounts, fees and other commissions, advisory and other professional fees and other costs in connection with the Refinancing Transactions. (5) Represents cash on balance sheet which may be used by the Company for ordinary course purposes, including but not limited to, acquisitions, repayment of indebtedness, working capital needs and other general corporate purposes. 73 -----

The gross proceeds of the New Notes offered hereby will be €550.0 million and will be used to: (i) redeem the entire outstanding principal amount of the 2025 Notes issued under the 2020 Indenture, together with accrued and unpaid interest thereon; (ii) redeem the entire outstanding principal amount of the 2026 Notes issued under the 2020 Indenture, together with accrued and unpaid interest thereon; (iii) pay fees, costs and expenses incurred in connection with the foregoing; and (iv) for general corporate purposes. The estimated sources and uses of the funds in connection with the Refinancing Transactions are shown in the table below. Actual amounts are subject to adjustments and may vary from estimated amounts depending on several factors, including the actual redemption date of the 2025 Notes and 2026 Notes and actual fees, costs and expenses.

(1) As of March 31, 2024, this amount represents €104.7 million of cash on balance sheet (which includes €7.5 million of restricted cash for use in connection with contractual maintenance obligations as well as cash collected for third parties under certain management agreements). The Adjusted Cash in bank amount gives effect to (i) the Refinancing Transactions and (ii) the payment of cash consideration in an amount of €33.5 million (equivalent) in connection with the Britannia Acquisition (which was completed on June 4, 2024 and was funded using cash on balance sheet). Neither the actual nor the adjusted amounts reflect any cash generated or used since March 31, 2024 and as such the cash figures presented are not indicative of current cash in bank as of the date of this Offering Memorandum or the Issue Date. We expect to make ordinary course payments, including taxes and lease payments to the Issue Date. Depending on the timing of these payments and available cash in bank at such time, we may draw additional amounts under the working capital and operating facilities provided under our Bilateral Facilities to even out our working capital cycle. To the extent drawn, such additional liquidity amounts are not expected to exceed €25 million and would be repaid using cash in bank following the Issue Date. See “Use of Proceeds.” (2) On February 13, 2020, the Parent, the Issuer and certain of its subsidiaries entered into a revolving credit facility agreement for a super senior revolving credit facility of €250.0 million. On January 11, 2024, the Parent entered into the 2024 Amendment Agreement to, among other amendments, (i) increase the commitments of the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement by €20.0 million to an aggregate amount of €270.0 million, (ii) redesignate a portion of the Existing Facility (as defined in the 2024 Amendment Agreement) as Facility 1, with such facility expected to mature on August 13, 2026 and (iii) establish and incorporate a new multicurrency revolving facility pursuant to the terms set out in the 2024 Amendment Agreement referred to as Facility 2, with such facility expected to mature on February 13, 2028. On the Issue Date, the Revolving Credit Facility is expected to be undrawn and fully available. See “Description of _Other Indebtedness—Amended Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement.”_ (3) Represents the aggregate outstanding principal amount of the 2025 Notes as of March 31, 2024 and the adjusted amount reflects the redemption in full of the 2025 Notes in connection with the Refinancing Transactions. See “Use of Proceeds.” The amount indicated excludes accrued and unpaid interest. (4) Represents the aggregate outstanding principal amount of the 2026 Notes as of March 31, 2024 and the adjusted amount reflects the redemption in full of the 2026 Notes in connection with the Refinancing Transactions. See “Use of Proceeds.” The amount indicated excludes accrued and unpaid interest. (5) Represents the aggregate outstanding principal amount of the 2027 Notes as of March 31, 2024. The amount indicated excludes accrued and unpaid interest. The Amended Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement includes a “springing maturity” provision pursuant to which the maturity date of February 13, 2028 will accelerate to the date that is six months prior to the maturity date of the earliest maturing outstanding senior secured notes issued by the Issuer. The 2027 Notes mature on March 1, 2027 and the maturity date of the Revolving Credit Facility may accelerate to September 1, 2026 if the 2027 Notes are not repaid prior to September 1, 2026. There can be no assurance that the redemption of the 2027 Notes will occur prior to triggering the “springing maturity” provision in the Amended Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement. See “Risk Factors—Risks related to the New Notes, our Structure and our Indebtedness—The _New Notes will mature after a substantial portion of our other indebtedness, including the Revolving Credit Facility and the Existing Notes.”_ (6) Represents the aggregate outstanding principal amount of the 2029 Notes as of March 31, 2024. The amount indicated excludes accrued and unpaid interest. 74 ----- (7) Represents €550.0 million aggregate principal amount of New Notes offered hereby. (8) Represents secured and unsecured bilateral facilities, local lines, project facilities and governmental loans with certain of our local lenders in Germany, France and Denmark. Following this Offering and the use of proceeds therefrom, we expect these bilateral facilities to remain in place. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, none of the facilities are secured by the Collateral. We expect to make ordinary course payments, including taxes and lease payments to the Issue Date. Depending on the timing of these payments and available cash in bank at such time, we may draw additional amounts under the working capital and operating facilities provided under our Bilateral Facilities to even out our working capital cycle. To the extent drawn, such additional liquidity amounts are not expected to exceed €25 million and would be repaid using cash in bank following the Issue Date. See “Description of Other Indebtedness—Bilateral _Facilities.”_ (9) Total financial debt excludes the non-current lease obligations of €1,182.4 million and the current lease obligations of €74.8 million of our financial leases as of March 31, 2024, which are property leases that are classified as financial leases for the purposes of Dutch GAAP, but as to which there is no option or obligation to purchase the asset at the conclusion of the lease. The actual Total financial debt as of March 31, 2024 presented above can also be calculated by adding: (i) the non-current corporate bonds of €1,535.2 million; (ii) the non-current debt credit institutions of €60.6 million; and (iii) the current debt credit institutions of €1.5 million, as derived from our unaudited consolidated balance sheet as of March 31, 2024. (10) Represents the outstanding principal amount of an interest-bearing loan issued by the shareholder of the Parent. As of March 31, 2024, the outstanding principal amount of such interest-bearing shareholder loan was €52.7 million. Interest on the shareholder loan is payable at 7.0% per annum, with an amount of €15.2 million in accrued and unpaid interest as of March 31, 2024. The final repayment date of the shareholder loan is February 11, 2035. The shareholder loan is subordinated to external debt pursuant to the Intercreditor Agreement, including the Existing Notes and the New Notes. See “Related Party Transactions—Shareholder Loan.” (11) The table above excludes the impact of amounts relating to (i) the write-off of existing unamortized debt issuance costs in connection with the 2025 Notes and the 2026 Notes, the total aggregate outstanding principal amount of which will be redeemed in full and (ii) the incurrence of unamortized debt issuance costs in connection with the New Notes. 75 -----

MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS Historical and Underlying Data
Subsubsection Text: The following is a discussion and analysis of our historical financial condition and results of operations with respect to the years ended December 31, 2021, 2022 and 2023 as derived from the audited consolidated annual accounts and the company annual accounts of the Parent as of and for the years ended December 31, 2021, 2022 and 2023, respectively, and the three months ended March 31, 2023 and 2024 as derived from the unaudited condensed consolidated interim financial statements of the Parent as of and for the three months ended March 31, 2023 and 2024, respectively. In order to aid in the understanding of our financial information on a comparable basis, we also present a discussion and analysis of selected financial data for the years ended December 31, 2021, 2022 and 2023, and the three months ended March 31, 2023 and 2024, based on financial data derived from management accounts for such periods. Such “Underlying” financial data is based on our audited and unaudited actual results for the periods presented, as adjusted to better reflect our underlying performance as further described under “—Discussion and _Analysis of Underlying Data.” This information is referred to as “Underlying Data.” This information has not_ been audited, and while Underlying Data is prepared on a basis that is consistent in all material respects as the basis on which our consolidated financial information is prepared, this Underlying Data are not comparable to the audited results due to adjustments and should not be regarded as a substitute for the audited financial data of the Group or financial data prepared in accordance with Dutch GAAP. You should read this discussion in conjunction with the sections entitled “Presentation of Financial and Other _information,” “Summary—Summary Historical Consolidated Financial and Other Information,” “Selected Historical Consolidated Financial information” and “Capitalization” as well as the consolidated financial_ statements and the accompanying notes included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. This discussion includes forward-looking statements, which, although based upon assumptions that we consider to be reasonable, are subject to risks and uncertainties which could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by the forward-looking statements. For a discussion of the risks and uncertainties which we face, see “Forward-Looking Statements” and “Risk Factors.”

Subsection Title: Overview
Subsubsection Text: We are a leading parking infrastructure owner and operator in the Western European market, with a large and diversified portfolio of owned, leased and managed parking facilities across seven Western European countries. We mainly operate off-street parking spaces owned by us as well as parking spaces under concessions and longterm leases from public and private landlords, with a focus on off-street purpose-built parking facilities at strategic locations. We operate 4,315 parking facilities comprising 896,187 parking spaces as of March 31, 2024 in The Netherlands, France, the United Kingdom, Germany, Belgium, Denmark and Ireland. As of March 31, 2024, our long-term business portfolio included 64 legally owned facilities, 66 ground lease facilities and five protected lease facilities, 187 concession facilities and 402 long-term lease facilities, which together comprised over 320,000 parking spaces. As of March 31, 2024, our short-term business comprised 3,591 facilities and over 576,000 parking spaces. Based on a third party consultant report, we are a top three player as of December 31, 2023, based on off-street parking revenue, in all of the countries in which we operate. Below are charts showing the percentage of Underlying Gross Margin generated by country of operation and our contract mix by Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs) for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024.

Subsection Title: Underlying Gross Margin[1] by Geography
Underlying Gross Margin[1] by Contract Type
Subsubsection Title: Scalable Platform Well Positioned for Sustainable Growth
Subsubsection Text: The scale in our countries of operation provides us a platform to grow the business (both organically and inorganically) in a sustainable and intentional manner while positioning ourselves to take advantage of the positive trends in digitization and EV charging infrastructure. We benefit from an industry where demand is relatively inelastic to price, although specific contractual arrangements may limit pricing flexibility. We believe that consumer choice regarding parking is not primarily driven by price but by factors such as location and distance to destination, parking availability, security, payment type and more recently, the availability of EV charging points. In addition to this, by virtue of the type of contracts we have entered, approximately 67% of our portfolio benefits from inflation protection either through full discretion on prices or through contractually agreed inflation-linked protection and we have partial flexibility in respect of the remaining 33% of our portfolio as of March 31, 2024. This combined with our scale and leadership position affords us “pricing power,” which provides us freedom to introduce price increases in line with or ahead of inflation, as illustrated by the charts below.

Subsection Title: Underlying Gross Margin[1] by Contract Type
Subsubsection Text: 1 Underlying Gross Margin excludes non-allocated and central operating costs. 2 Includes short-term leases, control fees and management contracts. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our Underlying Total Revenue was €852.5 million, our Underlying Gross Margin was €287.7 million and our Underlying EBITDA was €235.5 million. Our operations in The Netherlands, France and the United Kingdom, respectively, represented 34.5%, 20.6% and 15.4% of our Underlying Total Revenue, 39.2%, 28.1% and 6.7% of our Underlying Gross Margin and 43.0%, 30.5% and 6.6% of our Underlying EBITDA for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. We started our operations in the European market in The Netherlands in 1998, and expanded to Belgium, Germany and the United Kingdom in the early 2000s. We have consistently secured long-term contracts and built a portfolio of prime parking locations in The Netherlands, France, the United Kingdom, Denmark, Ireland, Belgium and Germany, including multi-functional parking facilities near inner-city areas, public transport interchanges, airports and hospitals. Multi-functional parking facilities serve multiple urban needs (such as city centers, shopping centers, hospitals and railway stations). Due to a variety of physical, regulatory and other constraints such as cost and availability of space, we believe that there is limited opportunity to develop alternative parking options in many of these prime areas, allowing us to benefit from a degree of captive demand with limited competition in some areas. We generate revenues under the following main business lines: - _Parking revenues. Our off-street parking business primarily comprises parking facilities owned and operated by us or operated by us under contract (both short-term parking and long-term parking). We have a healthy mix of short- and long-term parking customers. Short-term parking includes shorter term parking customers, such as per-hour or per-day tickets. Short-term parking generated 75.5% of our Underlying Parking Revenues for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. Long-term parking includes customers holding season tickets, including monthly, quarterly and annual season tickets. Long-term parking generated 24.5% of our Underlying Parking Revenues for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. Short-term parking customers provide immediate payment in cash or by debit or credit cards at the gates and physical barriers present in our parking facilities, while long-term parking customers provide revenue stability and advance payments. Underlying Parking Revenues represented 87.5% of our Underlying Total Revenue for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. We generally retain all fees generated from operating the relevant parking facility. In respect of parking facilities owned by us, we are responsible for all expenses relating to the parking facility, including operation, maintenance and management. Under our concession and lease contracts, we are responsible for all expenses relating to operating and maintaining the parking facility during the term of the concession or the lease. - _Non-parking revenues. o _Control fees. Control fees are predominantly generated in Denmark and represent income arising from enforcement of paid parking (for example, parking fines) in parking facilities (usually above ground) owned by the Group and/or by landlords. Landlords generally contract with parking facility 79 ----- operators like us to eliminate or reduce the misuse of parking spaces (for example, misuse of handicap spaces, parking on rescue roads, misuse of reserved parking spaces and long-term parking in spaces intended for short-term parking). Underlying Control Fees represented 3.0% of our Underlying Total Revenue for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. o _Management fees. Our management fees business represents the fixed and variable fees we receive for operating parking facilities under contracts with third parties including public authorities as well as private landlords and other private entities. Our Underlying Management Fees represented 5.6% of our Underlying Total Revenue for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. o _Rental income. In addition to owning, operating and managing parking facilities, we lease certain of our owned parking facilities to the municipality of Amsterdam. Rental income also includes the income from the lease of parts of our facilities to third parties that use the space for parking, storage or to provide spaces used for business operations, such as refrigeration or storage facilities for restaurants. Our Underlying Rental Income represented 1.8% of our Underlying Total Revenue for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. o _EV charging fees. We launched the EV Charging Program in May 2022 to substantially increase the number of EV charging points in our owned and long-leased parking facilities by the end of 2024. We earn fees from our customers who use the EV charging points provided at our parking facilities. Our Underlying EV Charging Fees represented 0.8% of our Underlying Total Revenue for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. o _Other revenues. Other revenues include all other revenues not included in the categories above, such as subsidies, ancillary revenues, revenue from other alternative uses of our parking facilities and other services such as vending machines placed in our parking facilities. Our Underlying Other Revenues represented 1.3% of our Underlying Total Revenue for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. 1 Underlying Gross Margin excludes non-allocated and central operating costs. 2 Includes short-term leases, control fees and management contracts. We have long-term cash flow profile visibility with 89.6% of our Underlying Gross Margin (excluding nonallocated and central operating costs) for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024 comprising primarily facilities that are owned or operated under our long-term business, of which 83% are entitled to operate until at least 2033 (assuming no renewals, new business or price indexation), as illustrated by the following chart. 1 Underlying Gross Margin excludes non-allocated and central operating costs. 2 Based on Underlying Gross Margin for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, excluding non-allocated and central operating costs. As of March 31, 2024, the Weighted Average Remaining Duration of our long-term contracts was approximately 47 years. Furthermore, our portfolio is backed by significant real asset ownership. As of March 31, 2024, the market value of our real estate portfolio, predominantly located in large and attractive cities, was €1.8 billion. The 127 ----- portfolio comprises 123 properties consisting of legally owned and ground leases. Such market value has been prepared without comprehensive due diligence or the benefit of an inspection of all of the properties. We believe that our strategic focus on owned facilities and long-term contracts has resulted in a stable business model, which enables us to attract customers and is supported by the high volume of cars and growing urbanization where our parking facilities are located. These prime locations provide flexibility and stability to our business, combined with stability of demand, leading to revenue stability as evidenced by the historical evolution of our revenues over time. In certain circumstances (primarily in relation to concessions in France), the long-term contracts and concessions include a protection mechanism allowing renegotiation of payments to local municipalities in case a certain level of performance is not achieved, thereby providing protection in case of lower demand. Further, in respect of our ground leases, there is typically a protection mechanism where the municipality is required to pay compensation to us in the event the municipality intends to terminate the ground lease or expropriate the property, thereby providing us adequate security and stability. Our business model shares all the key features of infrastructure assets, including long-term cash flow visibility, physical and high value assets, central role in the local economy, proximity to public sector players, embedded hedge against inflation, limited correlation to economic cycles, resilient revenue generation, and a favorable and stable regulatory environment with certain protections for us in the event of regulatory or administrative changes. Unlike some other infrastructure companies, our parking facilities, once operational, require relatively low levels of Underlying Existing Business Capex. Our limited Underlying Existing Business Capex, which averaged 5.0% of Underlying Total Revenue across the years ended December 31, 2021, 2022, 2023 and the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, are driven by our scale and preventive maintenance measures. Underlying Existing Business Capex relates to the upkeep of our existing facilities as well as repairs to our facilities to ensure they remain fully operational and compliant in line with our internal quality standards. As a result, we believe we are well positioned to benefit from returns on these investments without the need to incur significant Underlying Existing Business Capex with respect to these facilities. Our relatively low Underlying Existing Business Capex requirement allows us to focus on investment in other key areas of growth and portfolio investments, including portfolio expansion and new business, information and communications technology (“ICT”), digital solutions, CO2 reduction and new growth areas such as EV charging infrastructure.

Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our business and results of operations may be adversely impacted by macroeconomic and geopolitical developments. Public demand for our services is influenced by general economic conditions, including inflation, global health epidemics/pandemics and customer preferences. The global economy experienced one of its sharpest downturns in history as a result of the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic in early 2020 and the related lockdowns and restrictions on activity. As a result of COVID-19 and the measures taken to prevent a further spread, our business was impacted globally, particularly in 2020 and 2021, by the temporary closure and restrictions on opening hours and capacity of public establishments as a consequence of the guidelines given by the respective governments of the countries where we operate. To a certain extent, the impact of COVID-19 on our business continued during the first half of 2022, particularly as a result of lockdowns in The Netherlands during the first quarter of 2022 and other restrictive measures in Germany. Although our operating performance declined as a result of lockdown measures and other restrictions in response to COVID-19, we have showed significant post COVID-19 recovery. Car park usage trends have been positive since 2022 as illustrated by the sharp recovery of revenues during these periods. After a slow start in early 2022 due to continued COVID-19 related mobility restrictions, recovery in the parking business started when restrictions were lifted. The lifting of COVID-19 related restrictions in the different markets in which we operate has led to a strong increase in our volumes (sold hours in respect of our PMS Connected facilities) and revenues and, consequently, our Underlying EBITDA in the three months ended March 31, 2024 has been above our Underlying EBITDA in the corresponding period during the year ended December 31, 2019. Further, economic contraction, heightened inflation, economic and political uncertainty and the perception by our customers of weak or weakening economic conditions may cause a decline in demand for the services that we offer. Economic downturns and economic and political volatility in the various markets in which we operate may adversely affect our results of operations and financial condition. Further, heightened inflation and increase in commodity and services prices may have a negative impact on purchasing power and consumer spending, which could have an adverse effect on our business and cash flows. Our business may also be negatively impacted by fluctuations in other macroeconomic factors which influence consumer spending, such as unemployment rates, tax rates and general consumer confidence. 80 ----- In addition, the attacks in Israel by Hamas on October 7, 2023 and the conflict that followed in the Gaza Strip has created an unstable geopolitical environment in the Middle East. Further, the military invasion of Ukraine by the Russian Federation on February 24, 2022 and the sanctions imposed by the United States, the EU, the UK and other jurisdictions has negatively impacted the global economy and financial markets. Furthermore, higher energy costs and commodity prices, cyber disruptions or attacks, heightened general operating risks and disruption of logistic chains in Europe, have resulted in economic instability, market volatility and heightened inflation, all of which could adversely impact our business, results of operations, financial condition and prospects. The Group has no direct exposure to Israel, the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, Ukraine or Russia as none of our assets are located in any of these markets. However, we cannot predict the impact of the rising conflict between Israel and Hamas, which controls the Gaza Strip, the impact of Russian actions in Ukraine or any other heightened military conflict or geopolitical instability that may follow, including heightened operating risks and production disruptions in the Middle East and Europe. See also “Risk Factors—Risks relating to our Business and Industry— _Continuing economic or political instability and geopolitical conditions, including the conflict in Israel and the Gaza Strip and Russia’s actions in Ukraine, higher energy costs and commodity prices and disruption in logistics chains, may negatively affect our business, results of operations or financial condition.”_

Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Asset Base and Facility Contract Type
Subsubsection Text: Within the industry and across different geographies, the type of contract underlying a parking facility impacts the level of revenue, cash flow stability, typical Underlying EBITDA Margin, and capital requirements of the facility. Our long-term business accounted for 89.6% of our Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs) for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. As a result, our portfolio is more heavily weighted towards high-margin facilities, with a corresponding benefit to our Underlying EBITDA and profitability. In addition, because of these long-term arrangements, we are less exposed to circumstances in which contracts or leases come up for renewal on a regular basis, and where they may not be renewed, or renewed only at re-negotiated prices following a tender process. As a result, we benefit from stable and highly visible revenues and operating margins over lengthy periods. Profitability per country is driven by contract mix as the Underlying Gross Margin for each type of contract varies. For example, our legally owned properties typically require high upfront capital expenditure investment as compared to other contract types, but involve lower costs during the life of the parking facility (since we are not required to make any lease payments on our legally owned properties), thereby resulting in higher Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs), expressed as a percentage of our Underlying Total Revenue from legally owned properties. In contrast, lease contracts usually require relatively low upfront investments as compared to other contract types, but due to lease payments and costs incurred during the term of the lease, generally result in lower Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs), expressed as a percentage of our Underlying Total Revenue from lease contracts. 81 ----- Below are charts showing the percentage of Underlying Gross Margin generated by country of operation and our contract mix by Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs) for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024.

Subsection Title: Underlying Gross Margin[1] by Geography Underlying Gross Margin[1] by Contract Type
Subsubsection Text: Our revenues and our profitability, are driven by the demand for parking at our locations. Given our well invested portfolio of facilities in attractive and convenient locations, we are well positioned to benefit from demand based on such factors. As they apply to our own financial history, we have noted the following features. During the period under review, our financial performance demonstrates the resilience of our underlying revenue and the diversified sources of demand for our portfolio parking facilities: - _Employment, physical shopping and leisure, functional parking: Demand for our parking facilities is generated from a wide range of activities in proximity of a car park. Demand is, for instance, driven by the need for commuters to park near their place of employment, or near the place where they embark on mass transit. It is also driven by the need to use essential services such as hospitals and to park in locations where only a single operator of parking facilities is permitted, such as airports. Finally, it is driven by demand for a variety of leisure activities, such as physical shopping, and entertainment or cultural events. Each of these demand drivers in turn is driven by general economic and market conditions, as well as the overall trend in many of our geographic markets, such as increased urbanization, which may increase the demand for parking. Other factors including location, lighting and security, followed by price, drive customer demand. As a result, our portfolio of 4,315 parking 82 ----- facilities across seven countries is highly diversified to cater to our customers’ various demands for convenient parking. - _Macroeconomic resilience: Our Underlying Total Revenue over time, including through periods of economic downturn and pandemics, has been driven by the correlation of parking demand to the total number of cars driven, rather than macroeconomic factors such as inflation or GDP. However, our business was impacted globally as a result of the outbreak of COVID-19 and the measures taken by governments across the markets where we operate. Our Underlying Short-Term Parking Revenues decreased significantly as demand for parking facilities declined due to temporary closures of public establishments and other mobility restrictions. Despite the macroeconomic effects of COVID-19, we have experienced a rapid post-COVID-19 recovery in our business after restrictions were lifted. The relatively swift recovery illustrates the long-term resilience of the parking business despite macroeconomic factors and demand for such services. See “Business—Strengths—Highly Predictable _Business and Resilient Business Model, with Strong Cash Conversion.”_ - _Focus on to off-street parking: Local authorities, such as in Amsterdam and Copenhagen, and other stakeholders are increasingly embracing pedestrian-focused urban planning and anti-traffic measures, including redirecting inner-city car flows to streamlined off-street parking. As a result, there has been a transition from on-street to off-street parking. By moving car parking from on-street to off-street, cities free up public space for pedestrians and cyclists, reducing overall inner-city congestion and contributing to a better urban quality of life. For example, the municipality of Amsterdam announced in March 2019 that it is planning a reduction of up to 10,000 on-street parking spaces by the end of 2025 (approximately 4% of total on-street spaces in the city center) with a reduction of approximately 1.1% of the number of permits every half-year in certain busy areas and is looking for opportunities to significantly reduce the car population in some areas. See “Business—Parking Revenues.” - _Electrification of car fleet: As EVs are gaining significant traction as a result of changing customer preferences, there is a growing demand for inner-city EV charging facilities, especially near public transport hubs. This demand for EV charging facilities is further accelerated by carbon neutrality goals in various jurisdictions, regulation and ESG considerations. We are committed to supporting this energy transition. See “—EV Charging Program.” - _Digitalization and disintermediation: There is growing demand to digital services in the parking business, as part of the general digitalization megatrend. Such services allow us to proactively interact with customers and include offering a pre-booking service for customers to pre-book a parking space, seamless, no-touch parking experience, automatic payment methods chosen by the customer and the flexibility to use any virtual payment method. See “Business—ICT and Operations.”

Subsection Title: Underlying Gross Margin[1] by Geography Underlying Gross Margin[1] by Contract Type
Subsubsection Title: Underlying Like-for-Like Parking Revenue Growth Rate, Changes to Portfolio of Facilities and Strategic Transactions
Subsubsection Text: Our Underlying Total Revenue and Underlying EBITDA are impacted by both the Underlying Like-for-Like (“LFL”) Parking Revenue Growth Rate and the changes to our portfolio of parking facilities. Our Underlying Like-for-Like Parking Revenue Growth Rate for the years ended December 31, 2021, 2022 and 2023 and the three months ended March 31, 2024 was 8.3%, 34.6%, 12.3% and 5.7%, respectively. Our Underlying Like-for-Like Parking Revenue Growth Rate has been primarily driven by mainly due to a positive portfolio impact, whereby the revenue from new business exceeded the loss of revenue from expiring contracts during such period, our recovery post-COVID-19 and increased volumes and pricing. Our portfolio changes over time are due to the addition of new contracts, M&A activities and the reduction in existing contracts due to expiring contracts, as well as the effects of acquisitions and disposals of parking facilities. Changes to our portfolio of facilities, including the size and mix of our facilities, impacts our financial performance. As of December 31, 2021, we had more than 3,300 parking facilities with over 649,000 parking spaces. As of March 31, 2024, we had 4,315 parking facilities, with 896,187 parking spaces. From January 1, 2021 to March 31, 2024, we signed a total of 61 asset deals for parking facilities consisting of 38 new operating contracts for parking facilities and 23 negotiated contract renewals for parking facilities, as well as seven bolt-on acquisitions of parking facilities at our legally owned properties and under long-term leases and concessions which we believe contributed an estimated aggregate amount of €40.3 million in “run-rate” EBITDA from January 1, 2021 to March 31, 2024, which represents the EBITDA generated from all new contracts signed during the relevant period, assuming that each new contract is being performed at its full maturity potential assessed by us at the time of signing of such contract on the basis that (i) all parking spaces under each contract will be made 83 ----- available during the relevant period, (ii) all revenue generating functions of our business have been realized and (iii) the customary ramp-up period has passed. When we enter into a new lease or concession agreement or acquire a parking facility, we assess the revenue potential and the optimum level of investment for that facility in order to increase its profitability and produce a suitable return on our investment or in order to generate higher Underlying EBITDA and Underlying EBITDA Margin. This will range from facilities that will benefit from extensive investment on the redesign and adding Q-Park features, which would be typical for attractive locations with expected high demand for high quality parking, to a lower level of investment and/or lease amount in facilities where cash flows are less certain and/or there is a limited opportunity to realize financial benefits from our branding and design. Our typical returns on investment are highly dependent on the type of contract and location of such parking facility. Owned assets with high upfront capital expenditure investment and infinite maturity typically have a lower return on investment, whereas concession agreements with high upfront payments but shorter duration have a higher return on investment. In contrast, lease contracts usually require relatively low upfront investments and typically have the highest return on investment. The acquisition and disposal of parking facilities under management during the period were largely driven by several strategic transactions. The integration of the Paris La Défense contract (won in 2021) into our portfolio marked one of the key highlights in terms of growth and expansion in 2022. In the second quarter of 2022, we acquired 100% of the shares in Dansk Parkerings Service A/S and ASTA ApS, a small parking operator and control fee business in the city of Randers (Denmark). Further, on August 31, 2023, we acquired Tazbell Services Group DAC, parent company of the Irish parking operator, Park Rite pursuant to the Tazbell Acquisition. We also won the public tender for the on-street management contract of Amsterdam in The Netherlands pursuant to the Amsterdam City Tender (the operations of which are reflected in our results of operations from January 1, 2024 onwards). We also acquired a parking operator and control fee business in Denmark pursuant to the Denmark Acquisition, which was completed on October 4, 2023. Most recently, we acquired Britannia Parking Group Limited, one of the leading parking operators in the United Kingdom, which was completed on June 4, 2024 and was funded using cash on balance sheet.

Subsection Title: Underlying Gross Margin[1] by Geography Underlying Gross Margin[1] by Contract Type
Subsubsection Text: An important lever to influence our revenue is the ability to change pricing. We benefit from an industry where demand is relatively inelastic to price. We believe, based on market studies, that price is not a key driver of choice for our customers, being typically outranked by factors such as location, lighting and security. Combined with our attractive and well-located portfolio of assets, this factor has enabled us to proactively implement price increases closely following the consumer price index. Over the past three years, following the high inflationary macroenvironment, we were able to increase pricing in most of our parking facilities in line with inflation. In addition to this, by virtue of the type of contracts we have entered, approximately 67% of our portfolio benefits from inflation protection either through full discretion on prices or through contractually agreed inflation-linked protection and we have partial flexibility in respect of the remaining 33% of our portfolio as of March 31, 2024. 1 Refers to facilities where we have the sole decision-making authority to change prices. 2 Refers to facilities with limited restrictions on our ability to change prices (such as mandated caps to price increases or requirements to obtain landlord or municipality consent to price increases). 3 Refers to facilities where price increases are stipulated by a specific index (usually on an annual basis). At the same time, regulation has an effect on our pricing in a number of ways. First, regulation affects the level of supply, controlling new developments and the pricing of on-street parking. Second, in some areas regulators directly regulate the price of parking. For example, in France where we operate largely under concessions, pricing is mostly based on contractual indexation, which are often linked to the consumer price index and, sometimes, combined with other indicators (e.g., labor costs and/or construction costs). Third, the amount of demand is affected by regulatory policies that discourage vehicle traffic, congestion charges and other urban planning measures, and the promotion of mass transit alternatives. 84 ----- These regulatory developments can impact pricing in different ways. For instance, we have observed a trend of municipalities increasing prices for on-street parking, as part of the regulatory shift in many municipalities away from on-street parking, which in turn drives demand for our off-street parking spaces and allows us to raise our prices. Pricing is also affected by whether the parking is used on a long-term or short-term basis by our end-customers. Long-term parking, where a user or a corporate client pays a fee to use the car park (irrespective of the usage) for a longer period, such as season tickets, generally provide more stability and transparency with respect to Underlying Parking Revenues and Underlying EBITDA, while also bolstering our working capital position to the extent payment is made up front. Short-term usage, where users park on an ad hoc basis without a prior contract, is generally charged at higher rates resulting in higher profitability per hour as compared to long-term contracts but may lead to a lower level of utilization and more volatility in results. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, 75.5% of our Underlying Parking Revenues (comprising Underlying Short-Term Parking Revenues and Underlying Long-Term Parking Revenues), was generated from short-term parking and 24.5% from long-term parking (season tickets, which include monthly, quarterly and annual season tickets), of which approximately 80.7% is generated from business-to-business contracts, the remaining 19.3% from business-to-consumer contracts. We believe that we have a sophisticated pricing model, and our ability to manage pricing is enabled by our local scale and digital leadership. Our data-driven pricing methodologies include measures such as differentiated pricing models (real-time or near-time adaptation of prices based on demand and locations, such as peak hours), flexible pricing depending on frequency and duration, entry-time and step-rate pricing, online price differentiation through online pre-bookings, location-based pricing (such as premium pricing in city centers, medium-range pricing in Park + Walk locations and budget pricing in Park + Public Transport locations) and day tariffs optimization (through parking for over six to eight hours in selected locations). In addition, we increased the volume of payments processed through PaSS (Parking as a Smart Service), a service available in all seven countries in which we operate and which we believe increases the attractiveness of the parking experience of our customers. See “Business—ICT and Operations” and “—Capital Expenditure—Capital _Expenditure for 2023” for further information._

Subsection Title: Underlying Gross Margin[1] by Geography Underlying Gross Margin[1] by Contract Type
Subsubsection Text: We launched the EV Charging Program in May 2022 to substantially increase the number of EV charging points in our parking facilities by the end of 2024. The program has made significant progress since its launch and has been boosted by our associated €30-40 million investment plan. In early 2022, we signed agreements with EV charging point operators for EV charging in our parking facilities across Europe. The partnerships are designed to ensure ownership, continuous deployment, professional day-to-day management and performance of the EV charging points. Our EV Charging Program contributes substantially to the achievement of our ESG objectives and sustainable mobility. As of December 31, 2023, we have provided more than 12,500 MWh through our EV charging points which we believe have enabled more than 63.7 million zero-emission kilometers on European roads through our EV Charging Program since its launch in May 2022. See “Business—Corporate Social _Responsibility” for further information._ We have continuously supported our EV Charging Program as electric vehicles are becoming more popular. Our strategy to gradually deploy charging points in line with EV fleet penetration curves has led to deploying almost 1,644 charging points in 2022 despite the continuing shortages of labor and equipment in the installation sector. In 2023, we expedited the roll out regarding our EV Charging Program and deployed a total of 1,352 charging points. As of December 31, 2023, our parking facilities offer 2,996 EV charging points that are owned by us. Additionally, some of our EV charging points are owned by landlords or season ticket holders and, although our customers benefit from the availability of these EV charging points, they do not generate any additional revenues for us. Including these third-party-owned charging points, there were 4,114 EV charging points available in our parking facilities as of December 31, 2023, that generated Underlying EV Charging Fees of approximately €5.7 million, representing approximately 0.7% of our Underlying Total Revenue for the year ended December 31, 2023. We aim to significantly increase the number of EV charging points in our portfolio in the coming years in preparation for the EV fleet inflection point towards 2030.

Subsection Title: Underlying Gross Margin[1] by Geography Underlying Gross Margin[1] by Contract Type
Subsubsection Text: We operate car parks in seven countries: The Netherlands, France, the United Kingdom, Germany, Belgium, Denmark and Ireland. Our subsidiaries include those that transact business and report their financial information 85 ----- in currencies other than the euro, our consolidated reporting currency. Accordingly, our results of operations are subject to currency effects, primarily currency translation exposure; transaction-related exposures at our subsidiaries are limited because revenue and costs are largely incurred in their respective operating currencies. For our subsidiaries in countries with a functional currency other than euro, presently the United Kingdom and Denmark, income and losses are translated into euro at average exchange rates, and assets and liabilities are translated into euro at closing exchange rates. Fluctuations in exchange rates against the euro will give rise to period-on-period differences in our results of operations. We implement certain measures to reduce the impact of such fluctuations in exchange rates against the euro. For example, the Danish Kroner is pegged to the euro with a maximum positive or negative margin of 2.25% from the mid-price of €1.00=DKK7.458178. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, 15.4% and 7.5% of our Underlying Total Revenue, respectively, 6.6% and 5.1% of our Underlying EBITDA, respectively and 5.9% and 9.5% of our Underlying Total Capex, respectively, was reported by subsidiaries whose functional currencies are different than the euro, which are Pound Sterling and Danish Kroner. We define Underlying Free Cash Flow as Underlying EBITDA less Underlying Existing Business Capex less Underlying ICT & Other Capex. Therefore, while some of our subsidiaries report Underlying EBITDA in functional currencies that are different than euro, the costs and expenses of such subsidiaries, including the Underlying Existing Business Capex and Underlying ICT & Other Capex are also incurred and reported in currencies different than euros and therefore, we believe that our translation risk and exposure is limited. See “—Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk—Currency Risk.” We are also subject to foreign currency effects linked to loans denominated in currencies other than the functional currency of the entity that holds the loan. For example, entities in our Group that make Pound Sterlingdenominated loans to UK entities convert these loans into euros (their functional currency), which creates unrealized foreign currency gains and/or losses depending on the fluctuation of the underlying foreign exchange rates.

Subsection Title: Underlying Gross Margin[1] by Geography Underlying Gross Margin[1] by Contract Type
Subsubsection Text: 1 Underlying Gross Margin excludes non-allocated and central operating costs. 2 Includes short-term leases, control fees and management contracts. 1 Underlying Gross Margin excludes non-allocated and central operating costs. 2 Includes short-term leases, control fees and management contracts. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our Underlying Total Revenue was €852.5 million, our Underlying Gross Margin was €287.7 million and our Underlying EBITDA was €235.5 million. Our operations in The Netherlands, France and the United Kingdom, respectively, represented 34.5%, 20.6% and 15.4% of our Underlying Total Revenue, 39.2%, 28.1% and 6.7% of our Underlying Gross Margin and 43.0%, 30.5% and 6.6% of our Underlying EBITDA for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. 121 ----- We started our operations in the European market in The Netherlands in 1998, and expanded to Belgium, Germany and the United Kingdom in the early 2000s. We have consistently secured long-term contracts and built a portfolio of prime parking locations in The Netherlands, France, the United Kingdom, Denmark, Ireland, Belgium and Germany, including multi-functional parking facilities near inner-city areas, public transport interchanges, airports and hospitals. Multi-functional parking facilities serve multiple urban needs (such as city centers, shopping centers, hospitals and railway stations). Due to a variety of physical, regulatory and other constraints such as cost and availability of space, we believe that there is limited opportunity to develop alternative parking options in many of these prime areas, allowing us to benefit from a degree of captive demand with limited competition in some areas. We generate revenues under the following main business lines: - _Parking revenues. Our off-street parking business primarily comprises parking facilities owned and operated by us or operated by us under contract (both short-term parking and long-term parking). We have a healthy mix of short- and long-term parking customers. Short-term parking includes shorter term parking customers, such as per-hour or per-day tickets. Short-term parking generated 75.5% of our Underlying Parking Revenues for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. Long-term parking includes customers holding season tickets, including monthly, quarterly and annual season tickets. Long-term parking generated 24.5% of our Underlying Parking Revenues for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. Short-term parking customers provide immediate payment in cash or by debit or credit cards at the gates and physical barriers present in our parking facilities, while long-term parking customers provide revenue stability and advance payments. Underlying Parking Revenues represented 87.5% of our Underlying Total Revenue for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. We generally retain all fees generated from operating the relevant parking facility. In respect of parking facilities owned by us, we are responsible for all expenses relating to the parking facility, including operation, maintenance and management. Under our concession and lease contracts, we are responsible for all expenses relating to operating and maintaining the parking facility during the term of the concession or the lease. - _Non-parking revenues. o _Control fees. Control fees are predominantly generated in Denmark and represent income arising from enforcement of paid parking (for example, parking fines) in parking facilities (usually above ground) owned by the Group and/or by landlords. Landlords generally contract with parking facility operators like us to eliminate or reduce the misuse of parking spaces (for example, misuse of handicap spaces, parking on rescue roads, misuse of reserved parking spaces and long-term parking in spaces intended for short-term parking). Underlying Control Fees represented 3.0% of our Underlying Total Revenue for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. o _Management fees. Our management fees business represents the fixed and variable fees we receive for operating parking facilities under contracts with third parties including public authorities as well as private landlords and other private entities. Our Underlying Management Fees represented 5.6% of our Underlying Total Revenue for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. o _Rental income. In addition to owning, operating and managing parking facilities, we lease certain of our owned parking facilities to the municipality of Amsterdam. Rental income also includes the income from the lease of parts of our facilities to third parties that use the space for parking, storage or to provide spaces used for business operations, such as refrigeration or storage facilities for restaurants. Our Underlying Rental Income represented 1.8% of our Underlying Total Revenue for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. o _EV charging fees. We launched the EV Charging Program in May 2022 to substantially increase the number of EV charging points in our owned and long-leased parking facilities by the end of 2024. We earn fees from our customers who use the EV charging points provided at our parking facilities. Our Underlying EV Charging Fees represented 0.8% of our Underlying Total Revenue for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. o _Other revenues. Other revenues include all other revenues not included in the categories above, such as subsidies, ancillary revenues, revenue from other alternative uses of our parking facilities and other services such as vending machines placed in our parking facilities. Our Underlying Other 122 ----- Revenues represented 1.3% of our Underlying Total Revenue for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024.

Subsection Title: Discussion and Analysis of Underlying Data
Subsubsection Text: As well as the financial information derived from our audited and unaudited financial statements, we produce management reports that include our key financial metrics. Due to the limitations in comparability of certain information and periods covered by our financial statements, we present and discuss certain Underlying Data. This information has not been audited, and while Underlying Data is prepared on a basis that is consistent in all material respects as the basis on which our consolidated financial information is prepared, this Underlying Data is not comparable to the audited results due to adjustments and should not be regarded as a substitute for the audited financial data of the Group or financial data prepared in accordance with Dutch GAAP.

Subsection Title: Year ended** **Three months December 31,** **ended March 31, (€ in millions, except percentages)** **2021** **2022** **2023** **2023** **2024 (unaudited)** **(unaudited)

Subsubsection Text: _Underlying Revenue Metrics_ Underlying Total Revenue represents Net revenue adjusted for the Underlying Non-Operating and Incidental Adjustments and the Underlying Constant Exchange Rate Adjustments. Underlying Parking Revenues, Underlying Short-Term Parking Revenues, Underlying Long-Term Parking Revenues, Underlying Rental Income, Underlying Management Fees and Underlying Control Fees, each represent such respective component of Net revenue, as adjusted for the same Underlying Adjustments as Underlying Total Revenue, except for Underlying Non-Operating and Incidental Adjustments, which apply to the applicable revenue stream. For a reconciliation of Net revenue to Underlying Total Revenue for the periods presented, see footnote (4) of “Summary—Summary Historical Consolidated Financial and Other Information—Underlying _Financial Data Derived from Management Accounts.” See also “Supplemental Underlying Financial Information.”_ Underlying Other Revenues represent Certain Other Revenues (i.e., our Other revenues (i) as reported in the audited consolidated annual accounts and the company annual accounts of the Parent as of and for the year ended December 31, 2021, excluding Certain EV Charging Fees and (ii) as reported in the audited consolidated annual accounts and the company annual accounts of the Parent as of and for the years ended December 31, 2022 and December 31, 2023 and the unaudited condensed consolidated interim financial statements of the Parent as of and for the three months ended March 31, 2023 and 2024), adjusted for the Underlying Non-Operating and Incidental Adjustments and the Underlying Constant Exchange Rate Adjustments. For a reconciliation of Certain Other Revenues to Underlying Other Revenues for the periods presented, see footnote (2) of “Summary—Summary _Historical Consolidated Financial and Other Information—Underlying Financial Data Derived from Management Accounts.” See also “Supplemental Underlying Financial Information.”_ Underlying EV Charging Fees represent Certain EV Charging Fees (i.e., (i) the EV charging fees presented in the audited consolidated annual accounts and the company annual accounts of the Parent as of and for the year ended December 31, 2021 as part of Other revenues and (ii) EV charging fees, as reported in the audited consolidated annual accounts and the company annual accounts of the Parent as of and for the years ended December 31, 2022 and December 31, 2023 and the unaudited condensed consolidated interim financial statements of the Parent as of and for the three months ended March 31, 2023 and 2024), adjusted for the Underlying Non-Operating and Incidental Adjustments and the Underlying Constant Exchange Rate Adjustments. For a reconciliation of Certain EV Charging Fees to Underlying EV Charging Fees for the periods presented, see footnote (3) of “Summary— _Summary Historical Consolidated Financial and Other Information—Underlying Financial Data Derived from Management Accounts.” See also “Supplemental Underlying Financial Information.” Underlying Gross Margin_ We define Underlying Gross Margin as Underlying Total Revenue less Underlying Operating Expenses less Underlying Lease Expenses. Our Underlying Operating Expenses include certain costs that are in our control, such as personnel costs, utility costs, cleaning costs, ICT costs, costs of money management, insurance costs, car and travel costs, security costs, marketing costs and advisory and consultancy fees and certain costs which are not in our control, such as property tax. Further, certain of our Underlying Lease Expenses are fixed, meaning that the rent is set at a stated amount, certain others are variable, meaning that the rent is defined as a percentage of a variable metric, such as revenues. For a reconciliation of Underlying Total Revenue to Underlying Gross Margin for the periods presented, see footnote (6) of “Summary—Summary Historical Consolidated Financial and Other _Information—Underlying Financial Data Derived from Management Accounts.”_ Underlying Operating Expenses consist of Certain Operating Expenses (i.e., expenses incurred with respect to the operation of our facilities including maintenance expenses, utilities, personnel required to operate our facilities, property taxes, money management fees such as credit card charges, ICT, parking management systems and other costs directly related to operating parking facilities, as derived from management accounts), adjusted to reflect the Underlying Non-Operating and Incidental Adjustments and Underlying Constant Exchange Rate Adjustments. For further details, see “Supplemental Underlying Financial Information.” Underlying Lease Expenses consist of Certain Lease Expenses (i.e., fixed external lease expenses, variable external lease expenses, service charges and external lease expenses related to our control fee business incurred 87 ----- with respect to operational and financial leases of relating to our parking facilities, as derived from management accounts), adjusted to reflect all of the Underlying Adjustments. _Underlying EBITDA and Underlying EBITDA Margin_ Underlying EBITDA represents Net result, adjusted for Other operating income, Taxes, Financial result, Depreciation, amortization and impairments and the Underlying Adjustments. For a reconciliation of Net result to Underlying EBITDA, see footnote (5) of “Summary—Summary Historical Consolidated Financial and Other _Information—Underlying Financial Data Derived from Management Accounts.”_ We define Underlying EBITDA Margin as Underlying EBITDA divided by Underlying Total Revenue.

_Underlying Total Revenue_ Underlying Total Revenue increased from €524.2 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 to €725.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, or by 38.4%, mainly due to an Underlying Like-for-Like Parking Revenue Growth Rate of 34.6% primarily driven by a further increase in short-term parking revenues as a result of further relaxation of COVID-19 restrictions and lockdowns, which in turn spurred the strong recovery of our results of operation and cash flow generation. Underlying Total Revenue increased from €725.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 to €828.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, or by 14.2%, mainly due to a positive portfolio impact, whereby the revenue from new business exceeded the loss of revenue from expiring contracts during such period, our recovery post-COVID-19 and increased pricing. Underlying Total Revenue increased from €192.0 million in the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €215.7 million in the three months ended March 31, 2024, or by 12.3%, mainly due to a positive portfolio impact, whereby the revenue from new business exceeded the loss of revenue from expiring contracts during such period, our recovery post-COVID-19 and increased pricing. _Underlying Total Revenue by Country_ Set forth below is a chart showing the changes in Underlying Total Revenue by country over the periods presented.

Subsection Title: Year ended** **Three months December 31,** **ended March 31, (€ in millions)** **2021** **2022** **2023** **2023** **2024 (unaudited)** **(unaudited)

Subsubsection Text: Underlying Total Revenue in The Netherlands increased from €174.6 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 to €239.7 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, or by 37.3%, driven primarily by the rebound of short-term parking revenues as a result of the lifting of COVID-19 restrictions and lockdowns, illustrated by an Underlying Like-for-Like Parking Revenue Growth Rate of 37.3%, in combination with a positive portfolio impact, whereby the revenue from new business exceeded the loss of revenue from expiring contracts during such period. Underlying Total Revenue further increased from €239.7 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 to €283.4 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, or by 18.2%, driven primarily by a positive portfolio impact, whereby the revenue from new business exceeded the loss of revenue from expiring contracts during such period, our recovery post-COVID-19 and increased volumes and pricing. Underlying Total Revenue in The Netherlands increased from €65.8 million in the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €76.9 million in the three months ended March 31, 2024, or by 14.4%, driven primarily by a positive portfolio impact, whereby the revenue from new business exceeded the loss of revenue from expiring contracts during such period, our recovery post-COVID-19 and increased volumes and pricing. Underlying Total Revenue in Germany increased from €62.2 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 to €83.3 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, or by 34.0%, mainly due to the rebound of short-term parking 88 ----- revenues, illustrated by an Underlying Like-for-Like Parking Revenue Growth Rate of 29.1% as a result of the lifting COVID-19 restrictions and lockdowns and a positive portfolio impact, whereby the revenue from new business exceeded the loss of revenue from expiring contracts during such period. Underlying Total Revenue further increased from €83.3 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 to €98.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, or by 18.6%, mainly due to a positive portfolio impact, whereby the revenue from new business exceeded the loss of revenue from expiring contracts during such period, our recovery post-COVID-19 and increased volumes and pricing. Underlying Total Revenue in Germany increased from €22.6 million in the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €24.4 million in the three months ended March 31, 2024, or by 8.0%, driven primarily by increased pricing. Underlying Total Revenue in France increased from €111.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 to €162.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, or by 45.2%, driven primarily by the rebound of short-term parking revenues as a result of the lifting of COVID-19 restrictions and lockdowns, illustrated by an Underlying Like-for-Like Parking Revenue Growth Rate of 17.3%, in combination with a positive portfolio impact, whereby the revenue from new business exceeded the loss of revenue from expiring contracts during such period. Underlying Total Revenue further increased from €162.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 to €174.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, or by 7.6%, driven primarily by a positive portfolio impact, whereby the revenue from new business exceeded the loss of revenue from expiring contracts during such period, our recovery post-COVID-19 and increased pricing. Underlying Total Revenue in France increased from €42.6 million in the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €43.6 million in the three months ended March 31, 2024, or by 2.3%, as a result of increased pricing. Underlying Total Revenue in Belgium increased from €31.7 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 to €42.1 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, or by 32.8%, primarily due to the rebound of short-term parking revenues, illustrated by an Underlying Like-for-Like Parking Revenue Growth Rate of 33.7% as a result of the lifting COVID-19 restrictions and lockdowns in combination with a positive portfolio impact, whereby the revenue from new business exceeded the loss of revenue from expiring contracts during such period. Underlying Total Revenue further increased from €42.1 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 to €48.2 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, or by 14.4%, primarily due to a positive portfolio impact, whereby the revenue from new business exceeded the loss of revenue from expiring contracts during such period, our recovery postCOVID-19 and increased volumes and pricing. Underlying Total Revenue in Belgium increased from €11.5 million in the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €12.6 million in the three months ended March 31, 2024, or by 9.7%, primarily due to increase in volumes and pricing. Underlying Total Revenue in the United Kingdom increased from €82.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 to €120.7 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, or by 45.6%, mainly as a result of the rebound of short-term parking revenues, illustrated by an Underlying Like-for-Like Parking Revenue Growth Rate of 48.3% as a result of the lifting of COVID-19 restrictions and lockdowns, supported by an increase in the Underlying Total Revenue of our airport parking facilities in the UK due to increased volumes and increased prices. Underlying Total Revenue further increased from €120.7 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 to €129.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, or by 7.6%, primarily due to a positive portfolio impact, whereby the revenue from new business exceeded the loss of revenue from expiring contracts during such period, our recovery post-COVID-19 and increased volumes and pricing. Underlying Total Revenue in the United Kingdom increased from €29.4 million in the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €31.1 million in the three months ended March 31, 2024, or by 5.8%, primarily due to a positive portfolio impact, whereby the revenue from new business exceeded the loss of revenue from expiring contracts during such period and increased pricing. Underlying Total Revenue in Ireland increased from €15.2 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 to €22.6 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, or by 48.6%, principally due to the rebound of short-term parking revenues, illustrated by an Underlying Like-for-Like Parking Revenue Growth Rate of 49.9% as a result of the lifting of COVID-19 restrictions and lockdowns. Underlying Total Revenue further increased from €22.6 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 to €31.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, or by 40.4%, principally due to a positive portfolio impact, whereby the revenue from new business exceeded the loss of revenue from expiring contracts during such period, our recovery post-COVID-19 and increased volumes and pricing. Underlying Total Revenue in Ireland increased from €5.7 million in the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €11.0 million in the three months ended March 31, 2024, or by 93.5%, driven primarily by a positive portfolio impact, whereby the revenue from new business exceeded the loss of revenue from expiring contracts during such period and increased pricing.
