Underlying Total Revenue in Denmark increased from €45.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 to €55.0 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, or by 20.0%, primarily attributable to the rebound of short 89 ----- term parking revenues, illustrated by an Underlying Like-for-Like Parking Revenue Growth Rate of 20.2% as a result of the lifting of COVID-19 restrictions and lockdowns and a further increase in Underlying Control Fees. Underlying Total Revenue further increased from €55.0 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 to €62.0 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, or by 12.7%, primarily attributable to a positive portfolio impact, whereby the revenue from new business exceeded the loss of revenue from expiring contracts during such period, our recovery post-COVID-19 and increased volumes and pricing. Underlying Total Revenue in Denmark increased from €14.5 million in the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €16.2 million in the three months ended March 31, 2024, or by 11.7%, primarily attributable to a positive portfolio impact, whereby the revenue from new business exceeded the loss of revenue from expiring contracts during such period and increased pricing. _Underlying Revenue by Revenue Stream_ Underlying Parking Revenues Underlying Parking Revenues increased from €453.7 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 to €646.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, or by 42.6%, mainly due to the rebound of short-term parking revenues, illustrated by an Underlying Like-for-Like Parking Revenue Growth Rate of 34.6% as a result of the lifting of COVID-19 restrictions and lockdowns, in combination with a positive portfolio impact, whereby the revenue from new business exceeded the loss of revenue from expiring contracts during such period. Underlying Parking Revenues further increased from €646.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 to €734.2 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, or by 13.5%, mainly due to a positive portfolio impact, whereby the revenue from new business exceeded the loss of revenue from expiring contracts during such period, our recovery postCOVID-19 and increased volumes and pricing. Underlying Parking Revenues increased from €169.9 million in the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €182.0 million in the three months ended March 31, 2024, or by 7.1%, mainly due to a positive portfolio impact, whereby the revenue from new business exceeded the loss of revenue from expiring contracts during such period and increased volumes and pricing. Underlying Short-Term Parking Revenues increased from €322.7 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 to €481.0 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, or by 49.1%, and further increase from €481.0 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 to €553.2 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, or by 15.0%. The increase in Underlying Short-Term Parking Revenues over these periods was principally driven by the growth of Underlying Short-Term Parking Revenues on an Like-for-Like basis, continued pricing efforts in reaction to inflation and a positive portfolio impact, whereby the revenue from new business exceeded the loss of revenue from expiring contracts during such period, our recovery post-COVID-19 and increased volumes and pricing. Underlying Short-Term Parking Revenues increased from €124.5 million in the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €134.9 million in the three months ended March 31, 2024, or by 8.3%, principally resulting from a positive portfolio impact, whereby the revenue from new business exceeded the loss of revenue from expiring contracts during such period and increased volumes and pricing. Underlying Long-Term Parking Revenues increased from €131.0 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 to €165.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, or by 26.6%, and further increased to €181.0 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, or by 9.1%. Underlying Long-Term Parking Revenues increased from €45.4 million in the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €47.1 million in the three months ended March 31, 2024, or by 3.7%. These increases in Underlying Long-Term Parking Revenues are attributable to a positive portfolio impact, whereby the revenue from new business exceeded the loss of revenue from expiring contracts in all periods presented, as well as a positive Underlying Like-for-Like Parking Revenue Growth Rate due to direct indexation of prices and volume recovery in short-term parking, increase in long-term parking revenues due to a positive portfolio impact, whereby the revenue from new business exceeded the loss of revenue from expiring contracts during such period mainly driven by increased pricing. Underlying Rental Income Underlying Rental Income increased from €13.2 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 to €14.3 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, or by 8.7%, mainly due to a positive growth from rental income due to the indexation of the underlying agreements combined with a positive portfolio impact, whereby the revenue from new business exceeded the loss of revenue from expiring contracts during such period, and further increased from €14.3 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 to €15.3 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, or by 6.4%, mainly due to indexation of the underlying agreements to inflation. Underlying Rental Income increased from €3.7 million in the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €4.0 million in the three months ended March 31, 2024, or by 7.5%, mainly due to indexation of the underlying agreements to inflation. 90 ----- Underlying Management Fees Underlying Management Fees increased from €25.0 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 to €30.1 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, or by 20.3%, principally due to a positive portfolio impact, whereby the revenue from new business exceeded the loss of revenue from expiring contracts during such period, and further increased from €30.1 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 to €37.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, or by 24.5%, principally due to a positive portfolio impact, whereby the revenue from new business exceeded the loss of revenue from expiring contracts during such period. Underlying Management Fees increased from €8.1 million in the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €17.9 million in the three months ended March 31, 2024 principally due to a positive portfolio impact, whereby the revenue from new business exceeded the loss of revenue from expiring contracts during such period. Underlying Control Fees Underlying Control Fees increased from €16.4 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 to €20.7 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, or by 26.2%, mainly due to increased control fees in Denmark, and further increased from €20.7 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 to €24.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, or by 20.2%, mainly due to a positive portfolio impact in Denmark, whereby the revenue from new business exceeded the loss of revenue from expiring contracts during such period. Underlying Control Fees increased from €6.0 million in the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €6.9 million in the three months ended March 31, 2024, or by 14.2%, mainly due to a positive portfolio impact in Denmark, whereby the revenue from new business exceeded the loss of revenue from expiring contracts during such period. Underlying Other Revenues Underlying Other Revenues decreased from €15.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 to €11.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, or by 24.6%, primarily because such COVID-19-related government subsidy was no longer available as a result of the lifting of COVID-19 restrictions and lockdowns, and decreased from €11.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 to €11.3 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, or by 5.2%, mainly due to lower subsidies received primarily in France. Underlying Other Revenues decreased from €3.1 million in the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €2.9 million in the three months ended March 31, 2024, or by 5.6%, mainly attributable to lower subsidies received primarily in France. Underlying EV Charging Fees We introduced EV charging points in our parking facilities across seven countries as part of our EV Charging Program launched in May 2022. Underlying EV Charging Fees increased from €1.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 to €5.7 million in the year ended December 31, 2023 mainly because we had a full year of operation in 2023 compared to 2022 and more EV charging points installed in 2023. Underlying EV Charging Fees increased from €1.1 million in the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €2.0 million in the three months ended March 31, 2024, or by 74.2%, mainly due to an increase in the number of EV charging points and higher EV volumes sold due to increased EV penetration. _Underlying Gross Margin_ Underlying Gross Margin increased from €126.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 to €241.4 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, or by 90.3%, primarily driven by the rebound of short-term parking revenues as a result of the lifting of COVID-19 restrictions and lockdowns, in combination with a positive portfolio impact, whereby the revenue from new business exceeded the loss of revenue from expiring contracts during such period. Underlying Gross Margin further increased from €241.4 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 to €281.3 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, or by 16.5%, primarily driven a positive portfolio impact, whereby the revenue from new business exceeded the loss of revenue from expiring contracts during such period, our recovery post-COVID-19 and increased volumes and pricing. Underlying Gross Margin increased from €58.9 million in the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €65.3 million in the three months ended March 31, 2024, or by 10.8%, primarily driven by a positive portfolio impact, whereby the revenue from new business exceeded the loss of revenue from expiring contracts during such period, and increased volumes and pricing. _Underlying EBITDA and Underlying EBITDA Margin_ Underlying EBITDA increased from €85.7 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 to €195.0 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, primarily driven by the rebound of short-term parking revenues as a result of the lifting of COVID-19 restrictions and lockdowns, in combination with a positive portfolio impact, whereby the 91 ----- revenue from new business exceeded the loss of revenue from expiring contracts during such period. Underlying EBITDA further increased from €195.0 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 to €231.4 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, or by 18.6%, primarily driven by a positive portfolio impact, whereby the revenue from new business exceeded the loss of revenue from expiring contracts during such period, our recovery postCOVID-19 and increased volumes and pricing. Underlying EBITDA increased from €47.0 million in the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €51.0 million in the three months ended March 31, 2024, or by 8.6%, primarily due to a positive portfolio impact, whereby the revenue from new business exceeded the loss of revenue from expiring contracts during such period, and increased volumes and pricing. Underlying EBITDA Margin increased from 16.3% in the year ended December 31, 2021 to 26.9% in the year ended December 31, 2022, primarily driven by the rebound of short-term parking revenues as a result of the lifting of COVID-19 restrictions and lockdowns in combination with continued pricing efforts in reaction to inflation, and further increased from 26.9% in the year ended December 31, 2022 to 27.9% in the year ended December 31, 2023, primarily driven by our recovery in volumes post-COVID-19 in combination with continued pricing efforts in reaction to inflation. Underlying EBITDA Margin decreased from 24.5% in the three months ended March 31, 2023 to 23.7% in the three months ended March 31, 2024, primarily driven by portfolio additions through new acquisitions with lower margins.

Subsection Title: Discussion and Analysis of Historical Data
Subsubsection Text: Below is an explanation of certain key line items that appear in our financial statements. _Net Revenue_ Net revenue represents amounts invoiced for services provided during the financial period, net of discounts and value added taxes. Net revenue recognized consists of the following: - _Parking revenues: represent revenues we receive from customers (short-stay parking and season tickets) for use of parking spaces at the parking facilities operated by us. - _Control fees: represent income arising from enforcement of paid parking (for example, parking fines) in parking facilities. - _Management fees: represent the fixed and variable allowance we receive for operating parking facilities for third parties. - _Rental income: represents the rental income from parking facilities owned by us but operated by third parties, as well as income from renting specific areas in parking facilities to third parties. - _EV charging revenues: revenue from electric vehicle charging points that are owned by us. - _Other revenues: represents all other revenues not included in the above categories (for example, subsidies, services and advertising). _Other Operating Income_ Other operating income comprises of gains realized on the disposal of assets and subsidiaries. _Lease Expenses_ Lease expenses consist of the following with respect to our facilities: fixed and variable rental fees in connection with operational leases (including leases in connection with control fee contracts and concession fees in connection with concession agreements), variable rental fees in connection with financial leases, and service charges. _Operating Expenses Parking Facilities_ Operating expenses parking facilities consist primarily of costs directly linked to operating parking facilities. The costs comprise, among others, information and communications technology (“ICT”) costs (for example, costs of 92 ----- data lines), maintenance costs, utilities (lighting and ventilation) costs, property taxes, cleaning costs, security costs, insurance costs, marketing costs, car and travel costs and costs of money management. _Wages and Salaries_ Wages and salaries consist primarily of employee wages, salaries and other expenses. _Social Security Premiums_ Social security premiums consist primarily of payments made by us in connection with social security and other welfare programs for our employees. _Pensions_ Pensions consist primarily of pension contributions and similar payments we make in respect of our employees. Within the Group, there are a variety of pension schemes in accordance with the conditions and practices prevailing in the countries in which the Group operates. The schemes qualify as defined contribution plans under which contributions are paid into pension funds or to insurance companies on a contractual basis. Premium liabilities are charged to the result at the moment the liability arises and no provisions are made for future increases of pension premiums. _Depreciation, Amortization and Impairments_ Depreciation primarily consists of depreciation of tangible fixed assets (including land and building, which also includes assets in relation to our financial leases, leasehold improvements, equipment and installations and assets under construction). Amortization primarily consists of amortization of intangible fixed assets (including goodwill and concessions). Amortization charges are recognized as part of the total depreciation and amortization expenses. Impairments are also included in this line item. The fixed component of lease expenses in relation to our financial leases are expenses reflected in Depreciation, amortization and impairments and Financial result. For further details, see “—Lease Expenses” and “—Financial _Result.” Other Operating Expenses_ Other operating expenses consist primarily of costs for central and local support and overhead functions that are not directly linked or allocated to the operations of parking facilities. These costs comprise, among others, ICT costs, office lease costs, consulting and advisory costs and car and travel costs. _Financial Result_ Financial result consists of both financial expenses as well as financial income. This line item consists primarily of interest costs on bank debt, shareholder loans, interest rate swaps, financial lease obligations, other bank costs and foreign exchange results. The other bank and interest costs primary relate to depreciation on capitalized transaction costs on bank debt. This line item also includes movements in fair value of financial instruments. Financial result with respect to financial leases comprises interest costs on our financial lease obligations. See Note 16 of the audited consolidated annual accounts of the Parent as of and for the year ended December 31, 2023. The fixed component of lease expenses in relation to our financial leases are expenses reflected in Depreciation, amortization and impairments and Financial result. For further details, see “—Lease Expenses” and “— _Depreciation, Amortization and Impairments.” Taxes_ Taxes primarily consist of taxes on result based on domestic tax rates, adjusted for actual Group companies’ rates, non-taxable goodwill depreciation, other permanent differences and other adjustments. Other permanent differences mainly relate to adjustments regarding non-deductible interest expenses and non-deductible other expenses. 93 -----

Subsection Title: Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: The tables below and the discussion that follows the tables show our historical results of operations for the years ended December 31, 2021, 2022 and 2023, as derived from the audited consolidated annual accounts and audited company annual accounts of the Parent as of and for the years ended December 31, 2021, 2022 and 2023, respectively, prepared in accordance with Dutch GAAP and the three months ended March 31, 2023 and 2024 as derived from the unaudited condensed consolidated interim financial statements of the Parent as of and for the three months ended March 31, 2023 and 2024, prepared in accordance with Dutch GAAP.

Net revenue increased by 12.8% from €191.5 million in the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €216.0 million in the three months ended March 31, 2024. The increase in Net revenue was mainly due to an increase in Underlying Like-for-Like Parking Revenue Growth Rate driven by increased short-term parking revenues in combination with new business additions, including the operation of new facilities following the Tazbell Acquisition and the Denmark Acquisition, as well as the winning of the Amsterdam City Tender that started operations as of January 1, 2024.

Lease expenses increased by 9.8% from €58.9 million in the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €64.7 million in the three months ended March 31, 2024. The increase in Lease expenses was mainly driven by new business additions, including contract additions and the operation of new facilities following the Tazbell Acquisition, as well as an increase in contractual lease payments as a result of inflation based lease indexations of our like-forlike portfolio. Furthermore, since the variable component of our lease expenses is paid as a percentage of revenue generated from the underlying contract, an increase in revenues during the three months ended March 31, 2024 also resulted in an increase in variable lease expenses.

Operating expenses parking facilities increased by 14.2% from €33.0 million in the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €37.7 million in the three months ended March 31, 2024. The increase in Operating expenses parking facilities was primarily due to the Tazbell Acquisition and the Denmark Acquisition, as well as the winning of the Amsterdam City Tender that started operations as of January 1, 2024, together with increases in ICT, security and marketing costs, which were partly offset by reduced energy and other costs.

Wages and salaries increased by 31.7% from €24.6 million in the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €32.4 million in the three months ended March 31, 2024. The increase in Wages and salaries was mainly due to significantly higher staff levels following the Tazbell Acquisition and the Denmark Acquisition in combination 94 ----- with the addition of the Amsterdam City Tender that started operations as of January 1, 2024. Furthermore, we experienced regular annual salary increases in combination with statutory increases of minimum wages.

Social security premiums increased by 18.9% from €3.7 million in the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €4.4 million in the three months ended March 31, 2024. The increase in Social security premiums was mainly due to significantly higher staff levels following the Tazbell Acquisition, the Denmark Acquisition and the Amsterdam City Tender that started operations as of January 1, 2024, as well as statutory minimum wage increases and regular annual salary increases.

Pensions increased by 40.0% from €1.0 million in the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €1.4 million in the three months ended March 31, 2024. The increase in Pensions was mainly due to increased staff levels as a result of the Tazbell Acquisition, the Denmark Acquisition and the Amsterdam City Tender that started operations as of January 1, 2024, as well as increased pro rata pensions contributions due to statutory minimum wage increases and regular annual salary increases.

Depreciation, amortization and impairments increased by 5.7% from €50.6 million in the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €53.5 million in the three months ended March 31, 2024. The increase in Depreciation, amortization and impairments was mainly due to increased depreciation on intangible fixed assets (mainly goodwill) and fixed assets following the overall business growth as a result of new business additions, the Tazbell Acquisition and the Denmark Acquisition.

Other operating expenses increased by €5.3 million in the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €6.9 million in the three months ended March 31, 2024. The increase in Other operating expenses was mainly due to increased advisory costs in relation to ongoing projects, particularly related to the sale of a minority stake, and increased general expenses (i.e. office lease, ICT, car and travel) as a result of the Tazbell Acquisition and the Amsterdam City Tender that started operations as of January 1, 2024.

Financial result remained stable at a financial expense of €23.6 million in the three months ended March 31, 2023 and 2024. The increase in interest costs as a result of the issuance of the 2029 Notes in January 2024 was offset by the gain made on the satisfaction and discharge process in connection with the tendered 1.500% Notes due 2025 in January 2024 and the interest to be received on the amounts deposited in respect of the 1.500% Notes due 2025, in combination with positive fair value movements on interest rate swaps.

Taxes increased from a tax expense of €2.4 million in the three months ended March 31, 2023 to a tax expense of €3.9 million in the three months ended March 31, 2024. The increase in Taxes was primarily due to the increased operating result in combination with the gain made on the satisfaction and discharge process in connection with the tendered 1.500% Notes due 2025 in January 2024.
As a consequence of the foregoing, Net result declined from a loss of €11.6 million in the three months ended March 31, 2023 to a loss of €12.5 million in the three months ended March 31, 2024.

Subsection Title: Year ended December 31, 2023 compared to December 31, 2022
Subsubsection Text: Net revenue increased by 14.0% from €729.1 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 to €831.1 million in the in the year ended December 31, 2023. The increase in Net revenue was driven by a combination of (i) our pricing initiatives, (ii) the further volume recovery of short-term parking revenues after the COVID-19 pandemic 95 ----- and (iii) new business, including contract additions and the operation of new facilities following the Tazbell Acquisition and the Denmark Acquisition, which expanded our portfolio to over 3,600 parking facilities (as compared to 3,500 in 2022) and 706,000 parking spaces (as compared to 678,000 in 2022), in each case, as of December 31, 2023.

Subsection Title: Year ended December 31, 2023 compared to December 31, 2022
Subsubsection Text: Lease expenses increased by 13.0% from €221.2 million in the in the year ended December 31, 2022 to €250.0 million in the year ended December 31, 2023. The increase in Lease expenses was mainly driven by new business (mainly the operation of new facilities following the Tazbell Acquisition) in combination with an increase in contractual lease payments as a result of inflation based lease indexations. Furthermore, since the variable component of our lease expenses is paid as a percentage of revenue generated from the underlying contract, an increase in revenues during the year ended December 31, 2023 also resulted in an increase in variable lease expenses.

Subsection Title: Year ended December 31, 2023 compared to December 31, 2022
Subsubsection Text: Operating expenses parking facilities increased by 17.6% from €111.5 million in the in the year ended December 31, 2022 to €131.1 million in the year ended December 31, 2023. The increase in Operating expenses parking facilities was on the one hand driven by recent acquisitions (mainly the Tazbell Acquisition) and new business additions. On the other hand, we saw increased energy costs following renewed energy contracts and the success of our EV Charging Program in combination with higher cost of security and cleaning for the upkeep of our parking facilities as well as property taxes.

Subsection Title: Year ended December 31, 2023 compared to December 31, 2022
Subsubsection Text: Wages and salaries increased by 14.5% from €90.6 million in the in the year ended December 31, 2022 to €103.7 million in the year ended December 31, 2023. The increase in Wages and salaries was mainly due to statutory increases of minimum wages of our operational staff, combined with regular annual salary increases of our support staff. Furthermore, staff levels increased as a result of the Tazbell Acquisition and the Denmark Acquisition.

Subsection Title: Year ended December 31, 2023 compared to December 31, 2022
Subsubsection Text: Social security premiums increased by 7.2% from €13.9 million in the in the year ended December 31, 2022 to €14.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2023. The increase in Social security premiums was mainly due to increased staff levels as a result of the Tazbell Acquisition and the Denmark Acquisition, as well as statutory minimum wage increases and regular annual salary increases.

Subsection Title: Year ended December 31, 2023 compared to December 31, 2022
Subsubsection Text: Pensions increased by 2.4% from €4.2 million in the in the year ended December 31, 2022 to €4.3 million in the year ended December 31, 2023. The increase in Pensions was mainly due to increased staff levels as a result of the Tazbell Acquisition and the Denmark Acquisition, as well as increased pro rata pensions contributions due to statutory minimum wage increases and regular annual salary increases.

Subsection Title: Year ended December 31, 2023 compared to December 31, 2022
Subsubsection Text: Depreciation, amortization and impairments decreased by 16.4% from €267.2 million in the in the year ended December 31, 2022 to €223.3 million in the year ended December 31, 2023. The decrease in Depreciation, amortization and impairments was mainly due to lower impairment results on fixed assets in 2023 compared to 2022, in combination with a release in the total onerous lease provisions in 2023.

Subsection Title: Year ended December 31, 2023 compared to December 31, 2022
Subsubsection Text: Other operating expenses increased by 7.2% from €22.3 million in the in the year ended December 31, 2022 to €23.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2023. The increase in Other operating expenses was mainly due to an increase in our ICT costs (data network and application support) in relation to our business growth and digital strategy in combination with cyber security measures. 96 -----

Subsection Title: Year ended December 31, 2023 compared to December 31, 2022
Subsubsection Text: Financial result increased by 34.7% from a financial expense of €75.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 to an expense of €102.1 million in the year ended December 31, 2023. The increase in Financial result was mainly due to increased interest costs as a result of higher interest rates on the variable part of our debt portfolio as well as negative fair value movements on interest rate swaps in 2023 compared to significant positive fair value movements in 2022.

Subsection Title: Year ended December 31, 2023 compared to December 31, 2022
Subsubsection Text: Taxes decreased from a tax credit of €0.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 to a tax credit of €11.6 million in the year ended December 31, 2023. The increase in current tax expense as a result of improved performance compared to 2022 was more than off-set by incidental results primarily from tax rate changes in the United Kingdom in combination with the recognition of the full amount of deferred tax losses in the United Kingdom following the strong recovery of results and anticipated further utilization of these losses in the coming years.

Subsection Title: Year ended December 31, 2023 compared to December 31, 2022
Subsubsection Text: As a consequence of the foregoing, Net result improved from a loss of €76.7 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 to a loss of €10.6 million in the year ended December 31, 2023.

Subsection Title: Year ended December 31, 2022 compared to December 31, 2021
Subsubsection Text: Net revenue increased from €526.4 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 to €729.1 million in the year ended December 31, 2022. The increase in Net revenue was primarily driven by the rebound of short-term parking revenues as a result of lifting of COVID-19 restrictions and lockdowns, which in turn spurred the strong recovery of our results of operation. Net revenue also increased as a result of new business, such as the Paris la Défense contract in France, and the operation of new facilities in 2022, such as the Dokken (Kooldok) facility in Belgium, comprising 1,100 parking spaces and 72 EV charging points, and the Odense City facility in Denmark, comprising 990 parking spaces and 10 EV charging points.

Subsection Title: Year ended December 31, 2022 compared to December 31, 2021
Subsubsection Text: Lease expenses increased from €175.4 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 to €221.2 million in the year ended December 31, 2022. The increase in Lease expenses was primarily driven by newly added contracts (mainly Paris la Défense) in combination with an increase in contractual lease payments (which are indexed to various indices, as determined under the relevant contract). Furthermore, since the variable component of our lease expenses is paid as a percentage of revenue generated from the underlying contract, an increase in revenues during the year ended December 31, 2022 also resulted in an increase in variable lease expenses.

Subsection Title: Year ended December 31, 2022 compared to December 31, 2021
Subsubsection Text: Operating expenses parking facilities increased from €90.2 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 to €111.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2022. The increase in Operating expenses parking facilities was primarily driven by the effect of increased energy prices as well as the addition of new contracts. In addition, we experienced an increase in costs for maintenance, cleaning, security and money management arising from higher mobility levels and increased revenues. Furthermore, our marketing expenses were higher in 2022 as a result of promoting our digital initiatives, including the Q-Park App.

Subsection Title: Year ended December 31, 2022 compared to December 31, 2021
Subsubsection Text: Wages and salaries increased from €73.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 to €90.6 million in year ended December 31, 2022. The increase in Wages and salaries was primarily driven by the addition of new contracts in combination with regular annual salary increases and increase in full-time equivalents (mainly due to Paris La Défense and an acquisition in Denmark) as well as more limited COVID-19 related support packages in 2022 compared to 2021. 97 -----

Subsection Title: Year ended December 31, 2022 compared to December 31, 2021
Subsubsection Text: Social security premiums increased from €12.1 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 to €13.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2022. The increase in Social security premiums was primarily driven by the addition of new contracts in combination with regular annual salary increases and increase in full-time equivalents.

Subsection Title: Year ended December 31, 2022 compared to December 31, 2021
Subsubsection Text: Pensions increased from €3.6 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 to €4.2 million in the year ended December 31, 2022. The increase in pensions was primarily driven by the addition of new contracts in combination with increased pro rata pensions contributions due to regular annual salary increases and increase in full-time equivalents.

Subsection Title: Year ended December 31, 2022 compared to December 31, 2021
Subsubsection Text: Depreciation, amortization and impairments increased from €185.7 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 to €267.2 million in the year ended December 31, 2022. The increase in Depreciation, amortization and impairments was primarily driven by impairment results on fixed assets and additions to the onerous lease provisions accounted for in 2022.

Subsection Title: Year ended December 31, 2022 compared to December 31, 2021
Subsubsection Text: Other operating expenses increased from €20.1 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 to €22.3 million in the year ended December 31, 2022. The increase in Other operating expenses was primarily driven by an increase in ICT costs and marketing expenses to promote our digital initiatives.

Subsection Title: Year ended December 31, 2022 compared to December 31, 2021
Subsubsection Text: Financial result declined from an expense of €90.0 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 to an expense of €75.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2022. The decline in Financial result was primarily driven by favorable fair value movements in the interest rate swaps in 2022 resulting from an increase in interest rates in 2022, which was partly offset by a favorable effect of foreign exchange rate differences in 2022.

Subsection Title: Year ended December 31, 2022 compared to December 31, 2021
Subsubsection Text: Taxes increased from a tax credit of €14.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 to a tax credit of €0.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2022. The increase in Taxes was primarily due to incidental results from adjustments on deferred tax positions as a consequence of true-ups on 2020 positions based on the latest available tax declarations and outcomes of tax audits pending in 2020.

Subsection Title: Year ended December 31, 2022 compared to December 31, 2021
Subsubsection Text: As a consequence of the foregoing, Net result improved from a loss of €105.7 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 to a loss of €76.7 million in the year ended December 31, 2022.

Subsection Title: Liquidity and Capital Resources
Subsubsection Text: Liquidity describes the ability of a company to generate sufficient cash flows to meet the cash requirements of its business operations, including working capital needs, debt service obligations, capital expenditures, contractual obligations and other commitments, as well as acquisitions. Our primary sources of liquidity are provided by our cash from operating activities and our financings. Our liquidity requirements arise primarily to meet our debt service obligations, to fund capital expenditures, and, to a lesser extent, to provide working capital and fund acquisitions. In addition, we have access to the Revolving Credit Facility to service our working capital and general corporate needs, including the financing of acquisitions. The availability of the Revolving Credit Facility is dependent upon conditions as further described under “Description of Other Indebtedness—Amended Revolving _Credit Facilities Agreement.”_ Our financial condition and liquidity is and will continue to be influenced by a variety of factors, including: - general macro-economic conditions, including public health outbreaks, epidemics or pandemics; 98 ----- - our ability to generate cash flows from our operations; - the level of our outstanding indebtedness and the indebtedness of our subsidiaries, and the interest we are obligated to pay on such indebtedness, which affects our finance costs; - our ability and the ability of our subsidiaries to continue to borrow funds from financial institutions; and - our external growth funding requirements, which consist primarily of acquiring or constructing new facilities. Our cash requirements consist mainly of the following: - funding working capital requirements, including payments under contracts, leases and concessions; - funding capital expenditures needs; - servicing our indebtedness and the indebtedness of our subsidiaries; - operating activities; - paying taxes; and - funding acquisitions. We expect our sources of liquidity will consist mainly of the following: - cash generated from our operating activities; - borrowings under the Revolving Credit Facility; - issuances of debt securities; and - borrowings under other loan facilities including the bilateral facilities and financial leases. Our ability to generate operating cash flows depends on our operating performance, which in turn depends to some extent on general economic, financial, industry, regulatory and other factors, many of which are beyond our control, as well as other factors discussed in “Risk Factors.” Although we believe that our expected cash flows from operations, together with available borrowings, will be adequate to meet our anticipated liquidity and debt service needs, we cannot guarantee that our business will generate sufficient cash flows from operations or that future debt and equity financing will be available to us in an amount sufficient to enable us to pay our debts when due, including the New Notes, or to fund other liquidity needs. We believe that the potential risks to our liquidity include: - a reduction in operating cash flows due to a lowering of net result, which could be due to downturns in our performance or the industry as a whole; - adverse working capital developments; - exposure to increased interest rates in relation to our borrowings which bear interest at a variable rate, including our Revolving Credit Facility; and - higher capital expenditure, such as due to higher than expected expenses incurred in connection with our organic growth or acquisition strategies. If our future cash flows from operations and other capital resources (including borrowings under the Revolving Credit Facility) are insufficient to pay our obligations as they mature or to fund our liquidity needs, we may be forced to: - reduce or delay our business activities and capital expenditure; 99 ----- - reduce or delay our planned acquisitions; - sell assets; - obtain additional debt or equity capital; or - restructure or refinance all or a portion of our debt, including the New Notes, on or before maturity. We cannot guarantee that we would be able to accomplish any of these alternatives on a timely basis or on satisfactory terms, if at all. In addition, the terms of our existing debt, including the Existing Notes, the New Notes and the Amended Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement, limit our ability to pursue any of these alternatives, as may the terms of any future debt.

Subsection Title: Liquidity and Capital Resources
Subsubsection Text: The following table shows a selected summary of our statement of cash flows for the years ended December 31, 2021, 2022 and 2023 and for the three months ended March 31, 2023 and 2024.

Our parking businesses generally operate with negative working capital, due to the immediate collection of shortterm parking tariffs from car park users by means of cash or debit or credit card payments (if they do not pay, then they cannot exit the car park), the payment by customers for season tickets in advance as well as the receipt of payments in advance when customers use the pre-booking service. Generally, our working capital is fairly stable with some effects from seasonality or the phasing or timing of large outgoing payments. For the three months ended March 31, 2024, our cash flow from operating activities consisted of a cash inflow of €58.5 million, driven primarily by operational cash generation resulting from the collection of revenues from both short-term and long-term parking and other revenue streams, which was partly offset by the payment of higher corporate income taxes during such period and a negative movement in working capital. For the three months ended March 31, 2023, our cash flow from operating activities consisted of a cash inflow of €58.1 million, driven primarily by operational cash generation resulting from the collection of revenues from both short-term and long-term parking and other revenue streams, which was partly offset by the payment of higher corporate income taxes during such period and a negative movement in working capital. 100 ----- For the year ended December 31, 2023, our cash flow from operating activities consisted of a cash inflow of €287.1 million, driven primarily by operational cash generation resulting from the collection of revenues from both short-term and long-term parking and other revenue streams, which was partly offset by the payment of corporate income taxes during such period. For the year ended December 31, 2022, our cash flow from operating activities consisted of a cash inflow of €278.0 million, driven primarily by the operational cash generation resulting from the collection of revenues from both short-term and long-term parking and other revenue streams, which was partly offset by the payment of operating costs and corporate income taxes paid during such period. In addition, there was a positive movement in working capital, primarily due to an increase in VAT and an increase in variable lease expenses (in each case, as a result of increased revenue), in combination with the addition of the Paris La Défense contract, all of which contributed to the cash flow from operating activities. For the year ended December 31, 2021, our cash flow from operating activities consisted of a cash inflow of €136.2 million, driven primarily by the operational cash generation resulting from the collection of revenues from both short-term and long-term parking and other revenue streams, which were partly offset by the payment of operating costs and corporate income taxes paid during such period.

For the three months ended March 31, 2024, our cash flow from investment activities consisted of a cash outflow of €22.5 million, primarily driven by larger refurbishment projects, our continued investments in EV charging points and timing differences in regular maintenance. New business cash outflows were primarily related to new business projects in the Netherlands, France and Ireland. For the three months ended March 31, 2023, our cash flow from investment activities consisted of a cash outflow of €18.2 million, driven primarily by major maintenance and refurbishments in combination with investments in EV charging points. New business cash outflows were primarily related to new business projects in France (mainly Brest and Paris La Défense). For the year ended December 31, 2023, our cash flow from investment activities consisted of a cash outflow of €129.3 million, driven primarily by larger refurbishment projects and timing differences in regular maintenance. New business cash outflows were mainly driven by the Tazbell Acquisition and the Denmark Acquisition, as well as development projects, primarily in France and The Netherlands. In addition, there was a positive cash flow from divestments related to a compensation payment received for the book-value of investments due to the early termination of a contract in France. For the year ended December 31, 2022, our cash flow from investment activities consisted of a cash outflow of €107.1 million, driven primarily by capital expenditures relating to existing businesses and new businesses. New business cash outflows were mainly driven by acquisitions in Denmark and development projects, primarily in France, Belgium and The Netherlands. In addition, there was a positive cash flow from divestments related to a compensation payment received for the book-value of investments due to the early termination of contracts in France. For the year ended December 31, 2021, our cash flow from investment activities consisted of a cash outflow of €84.9 million, primarily as a result of capital expenditures relating to existing businesses and new businesses. New business cash outflows were mainly driven by the acquisition of a number of facilities in The Netherlands and development projects in France, Belgium and The Netherlands.

For the three months ended March 31, 2024, our cash flow from financing activities consisted of a cash outflow of €36.8 million, primarily driven by the issuance of the 2029 Notes and the redemption in full of the 1.500% Notes due 2025 in combination with interest paid on bonds and loans and the paid interest and redemption component related to contracts that qualify as financial lease contract under Dutch GAAP principles. For the three months ended March 31, 2023, our cash flow from financing activities consisted of a cash outflow of €36.2 million, primarily driven by interest paid on bonds and loans and the paid interest and redemption component related to contracts that qualify as financial lease contract under Dutch GAAP principles. For the year ended December 31, 2023, our cash flow from financing activities consisted of a cash outflow of €183.5 million, primarily driven by the repayment of two mortgage-backed loans drawn as a liquidity buffer 101 ----- during the COVID-19 pandemic (€50.0 million) from available cash on balance sheet, increased interest rates on our variable rate loan portfolio (partly offset by interest reductions following the repayment in 2022 of the Revolving Credit Facility) and the interest and redemption component related to our financial leases. Furthermore, we also incurred transaction costs (€3.9 million) related to the refinancing of the 1.500% Notes due 2025 in January 2024, of which €2.1 million has been capitalized. For the year ended December 31, 2022, our cash flow from financing activities consisted of a cash outflow of €364.4 million, primarily driven by the full repayment of the drawn amounts under the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement (€240.0 million) from available cash on balance sheet, interest expenses on bank debt and the interest and redemption component related to our financial leases. For the year ended December 31, 2021, our cash flow from financing activities consisted of a cash inflow of €48.9 million, primarily driven by the issuance of the 2025 Notes and €80.0 million in additional loans drawn under our Bilateral Facilities in The Netherlands and Belgium to serve as a liquidity buffer during the COVID-19 pandemic, which was offset by interest expenses on bank debt and the interest and redemption component related to our financial leases.

We also discuss in this “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of _Operations” certain financial data for the years ended December 31, 2021, 2022 and 2023, and the three months_ ended March 31, 2023 and 2024, based on financial data derived from management accounts for such periods, in order to aid in the understanding of our financial information on a comparable basis. Of such financial data, Underlying Free Cash Flow, Underlying FCF Cash Conversion Ratio, Underlying Total Capex, Underlying Existing Business Capex, Underlying New Business Capex, Underlying Digital Solution Hardware Capex, Underlying LED Capex, Underlying EV Capex and Underlying ICT & Other Capex are cash flow measures. For a discussion of cash flow results on a more comparable basis based on such management account metrics, see “Summary—Summary Historical Consolidated Financial and Other Information—Underlying Financial Data _Derived from Management Accounts” and “—Capital Expenditure.”_

Subsection Title: Capital Expenditure
Subsubsection Text: We generally require capital expenditure to maintain the upkeep of our existing facilities in order to remain competitive and maintain the value of our brand. In addition, in recent years we have incurred capital expenditure in connection with new business and the introduction and implementation of technology and improvements to enhance our existing portfolios, including the introduction of EV charging points at our parking facilities. Set forth below is a table showing the changes in Underlying Total Capex over the periods presented.

Subsubsection Text: _Underlying Total Capex_ Underlying Total Capex consists of cash flow from investment activities, impact of acquisitions but adjusted for divestments, and for the year ended December 31, 2023, adjusted for €10.3 million of acquired cash on balance sheet of Tazbell Services Group DAC that we acquired and consolidated with our cash on balance sheet following the completion of the Tazbell Acquisition on August 31, 2023. _Underlying Existing Business Capex_ Underlying Existing Business Capex consists of works to maintain the upkeep of our existing facilities as well as repairs on car park facilities to ensure they remain fully operational and compliant. _Underlying New Business Capex_ Underlying New Business Capex consists of capital expenditure related to the development and construction of new or newly acquired parking facilities as derived from (1) the cash flow from investment activities as included in the audited consolidated annual accounts and the company annual accounts of the Parent as of and for the years ended December 31, 2021, 2022 and 2023, (2) the cash flow from investment activities as included the unaudited condensed consolidated 31, 2023. 102 ----- _Underlying Digital Solution Hardware Capex_ Underlying Digital Solution Hardware Capex consists of capital expenditure on hardware for PaSS and other digital solutions (such as QR readers or other hardware related to payment methods). _Underlying LED Capex_ Underlying LED Capex consists of capital expenditure in connection with our ongoing LED lighting initiative, whereby we replace traditional lighting with LED lighting in our new facilities as well as certain other facilities on an ongoing basis. _Underlying EV Capex_ Underlying EV Capex consists of capital expenditure in connection with our ongoing EV charging initiative whereby we introduce EV charging points at our parking facilities on a Group-wide basis, across seven countries, including investments in EV charging points, cabling works, signage and related safety requirements in connection with EV charging points. _Underlying ICT & Other Capex_ Underlying ICT & Other Capex consists of investment and expenditure in relation to information technology and digital and mobility solutions, including PaSS software and other digital solutions, incurred by our central and headquarter functions.

_Underlying Total Capex_ Underlying Total Capex increased from €89.7 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 to €108.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 mainly due to the new business facility in Chartres Gare, France, and the launch of our EV charging initiative in May 2022, and further increased from €108.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 to €147.2 million in the year ended December 31, 2023 mainly due to the Denmark Acquisition and the Tazbell Acquisition. Underlying Total Capex increased from €18.2 million in the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €22.5 million in the three months ended March 31, 2024 mainly due to the phasing effect of large refurbishments and an increased roll-out of EV charging points. While Underlying Existing Business Capex tends to be generally stable, variations in our Underlying Total Capex have been driven by new business acquisitions. New individual business acquisitions can have different capital expenditure requirements, depending on the type of contract. Leases generally tend to have low capital expenditure requirements, consisting of Parking Management Systems (“PMS”) relating to fitting physical barriers and implementing payment systems as well as other works, including painting and sealing floors in our facilities. Concessions generally have higher capital expenditure requirements as compared to other contract types, consisting of entrance fees, major renovation works and, in some cases, a new development of a facility. Legal ownership and ground leases also typically have higher capital expenditure requirements as compared to other contract types, consisting of the purchase price and construction costs and full maintenance responsibilities. _Underlying Existing Business Capex_ Our Underlying Existing Business Capex requirements have generally been stable, averaging 5.0% of Underlying Total Revenue over in the period January 1, 2021 to December 31, 2023. Underlying Existing Business Capex increased from €30.3 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 to €34.4 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, mainly as a result of large refurbishments to maintain the quality of our facilities and preserve the value of our assets, and further increased from €34.4 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 to €44.7 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, mainly as a result of phasing of recurring maintenance and large refurbishments in The Netherlands and investments in signs for the control fee division in Denmark. Underlying Existing Business Capex increased from €6.6 million in the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €10.0 million in the three months ended March 31, 2024, with such increase driven by the move of Paris La Défense from Underlying New Business to Underlying Existing Business as of December 31, 2023 and phasing of maintenance in The Netherlands. 103 ----- _Underlying New Business Capex_ Underlying New Business Capex increased from €44.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 to €56.6 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 and further increased to €80.0 million in the year ended December 31, 2023. In the year ended December 31, 2021, Underlying New Business Capex comprised the acquisition of a number of facilities in The Netherlands and new contracts added to the portfolios, primarily in France and Belgium. In the year ended December 31, 2022, Underlying New Business Capex comprised acquisitions in Denmark and new contracts added to the portfolios, primarily in The Netherlands, Germany, Belgium and France. In the year ended December 31, 2023, Underlying New Business Capex comprised the Tazbell Acquisition, the Denmark Acquisition, the acquisition and refurbishment of an Irish parking facility in Limerick (“Cornmarket

Subsection Title: Square”) in 2023 and ongoing investments our French concession agreements such as Paris La Défense and Brest.
Subsubsection Text: For the year ending December 31, 2024, we expect our total capital expenditure to be approximately €130-150 million, which will comprise the following principal categories of capital expenditure: (i) existing business capital expenditure of approximately €55-60 million, (ii) new business capital expenditure of approximately €50-60 million, which will vary depending on the number of actual contracts acquired and the scope of any capital expenditures required under such contracts (which we expect will off-set the EBITDA impact of expiring contracts), (iii) digital hardware solutions capital expenditure of approximately €1-1.5 million (the majority of 104 ----- which is currently expected to be completed by the end of 2024), (v) EV capital expenditure of approximately €810 million and (vi) ICT and other capital expenditure of approximately €13-15 million.

Subsection Title: Square”) in 2023 and ongoing investments our French concession agreements such as Paris La Défense and Brest.
Subsubsection Text: Underlying New Business Capex decreased from €7.4 million in the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €6.7 million in the three months ended March 31, 2024. In the three months ended March 31, 2023, Underlying New Business Capex comprised ongoing investments in French concession agreements such as Paris La Défense and Brest. In the three months ended March 31, 2024, Underlying New Business Capex mainly consisted of the ongoing construction of the top-up in the Frontenpark parking facility in The Netherlands, refurbishment of Cornmarket Square and ongoing investments in our French concession agreements. _Underlying Digital Solution Hardware Capex_ Underlying Digital Solution Hardware Capex decreased from €4.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 to €3.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 and decreased to €3.1 million in the year ended December 31, 2023. Underlying Digital Solution Hardware Capex decreased slightly from €0.4 million in the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €0.3 million in the three months ended March 31, 2024. Underlying Digital Solution Hardware comprises the roll-out of our PaSS solution and other digital solutions (such as QR readers or other hardware related to payment methods) in various parking facilities. Variances in Underlying Digital Solution Hardware Capex during the periods presented are due to the number of facilities equipped annually. _Underlying LED Capex_ We commenced our LED lighting initiative in late 2018 and the roll-out was completed in the year ended December 31, 2021. In the year ended December 31, 2021, Underlying LED Capex comprised the replacement of traditional lighting in our parking facilities mainly in France, The Netherlands and Germany. _Underlying EV Capex_ We launched our EV Charging Program in 2022. Underlying EV Capex increased from €4.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 to €8.1 million in the year ended December 31, 2023. Underlying EV Capex increased from €0.8 million in the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €1.7 million in the three months ended March 31, 2024 as a result of an increased roll-out of EV charging points, mainly in France. _Underlying ICT & Other Capex_ The increase in Underlying ICT & Other Capex from €7.6 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 to €9.6 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, was primarily attributable to increased development costs for our Q-Park App related to refining and extending of pre-booking capabilities through the Q-Park App. Underlying ICT & Other Capex increased to €11.3 million in the year ended December 31, 2023 as a result of increased development costs for our digital capabilities and enhanced cyber security. Underlying ICT & Other Capex increased from €3.0 million in the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €3.4 million in the three months ended March 31, 2024.

Subsection Title: Working Capital
Subsubsection Text: As a result of day-to-day activity at our parking locations, we collect significant amounts of cash, generally resulting in negative working capital, whereby our cash collections tend to outpace our creditor payments. We experience limited seasonality with respect to our working capital and have relatively stable working capital throughout the year. For our off-street business, we collect cash in advance with respect to monthly, quarterly and annual charges (season tickets) as well as pre-bookings, while short-term users pay either in cash or by card before exiting the parking facilities, or by other payment methods including through the Q-Park app with iDeal payments or through third party apps such as EasyPark. We use a portion of this to pay the fees to the concession owners or to pay lease fees to the landlords. For our on-street business, we generally collect cash daily at the time of service, with the cash in excess of our fees remitted to the municipalities at fixed intervals. For our off-street management business, we collect the cash from users and net it against payments owed from the facility owners and pay the remainder to the facility owners as required under the contract. Some municipalities and other clients require us to deposit the cash receipts into client accounts and the clients then reimburse us for our fees. With respect to our rental income, we invoice in advance on a quarterly basis to third parties and customers. Invoices with respect rental income are required to be paid prior to the start of the relevant quarter. From time to time, we may require liquidity in order to fund our working capital needs from cash and/or drawings under the Revolving Credit Facility. In addition, we experience significant fluctuations in our intra-month working capital due to regularly scheduled payments on certain days of each month to our trade creditors as well as our employees and landlords. Subsection Title: Off-Balance Sheet Arrangements
Subsubsection Text: We are not party to any off-balance sheet arrangements, other than operational leases, that have, or are reasonably likely to have, a current or future material effect on our financial condition, changes in financial condition, revenue or expenses, results of operations, liquidity, capital expenditure or capital resources. The Group operates parking facilities under operational lease agreements. The total nominal fixed lease obligation relating to these operational lease agreements amounts to €1,936.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2023. Our operational leases are not recorded on the balance sheet. For further information, see Note 13 of the audited consolidated annual accounts of the Parent as of and for the year ended December 31, 2023. We extend guarantees provided by banks to local authorities as well as landlords and other private parties for our performance under our long-term lease and concessions agreements. The aggregate face amount outstanding under these guarantees was €26.8 million (which includes a €13.0 million ancillary facility (designated under the Revolving Credit Facility) with ING Bank N.V.)) as of March 31, 2024 and no amounts were claimed or drawn, as applicable, under such guarantees or ancillary facility.

Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Our exposure to the risk of changes in market interest rates relates primarily to our long-term debt obligations with floating interest rates, comprising any borrowings under the Revolving Credit Facility from time to time. These borrowings have a fixed interest component and a variable interest component, where the interest from the variable interest component is hedged by means of interest rate swaps and caps. Although we currently have a hedging policy pursuant to which 70% of our interest rate exposure is either in fixed rate instruments or fully hedged, the 2020 Indenture, the Indenture and the Amended Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement do not, obligate us to hedge interest rates. For our current hedging arrangements please see “Description of Other Indebtedness—Hedging Arrangements.”

Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: We operate in various countries in Western Europe and are exposed to foreign exchange risk arising from currency exposures with respect to our activities in the United Kingdom and Denmark. Such exposure is primarily limited 106 ----- to a translation effect of the net investments in these countries as the operational activities take place locally and there are no cross-border activities in foreign currencies. Therefore, related revenue, costs and capital expenditure are all in the same currency. The exposure on the translation effect of the net investment not hedged. In addition, as of March 31, 2024, we had DKK89.4 million (€12.0 million) of outstanding indebtedness under our Danish Bilateral Facility. Foreign currency risk is the risk that the fair value of a financial commitment, recognized financial assets or financial liabilities will fluctuate due to changes in foreign currency rates.

Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: We monitor our risk to a shortage of funds using periodic liquidity planning. This planning considers the maturity of our financial investments and financial assets and projected cash flows from operations. We use our cash on hand, cash generated through operations and credit available to manage our liquidity.

Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Credit risk is the risk that a counterparty fails to meet its obligations arising from a financial instrument or contract with a client, causing financial damage. Credit risk arises from cash and cash equivalents, derivative financial instruments and deposits with banks and financial institutions, as well as credit exposures to our customers and counterparties in connection with our operating activities, including outstanding trade receivables. The concentration of credit risk relating to our trade receivables is low, as we have a diversified customer base and collect rent in advance and parking revenues at the time such facilities are used by our customers. See “—Working _Capital” for additional information._ The credit ratings of banks with which we have investments of cash, borrowings or derivative financial instruments are reviewed regularly by management.

Subsection Title: Critical Accounting Policies
Subsubsection Text: Net revenue represents amounts invoiced for services provided during the financial year, net of discounts and value added taxes. Revenue is recognized based on the service delivered to the customer until the last date of the financial year. The costs of providing these services are allocated to the same period. The revenue recognized consists of: - _Parking revenues: represent revenues we receive from customers (short-stay parking and season tickets) for use of parking spaces at the parking facilities operated by us. - _Control fees: represent income arising from enforcement of paid parking (for example, parking fines) in parking facilities. 107 ----- - _Management fees: represent the fixed and variable allowance we receive for operating parking facilities for third parties. - _Rental income: represents the rental income from parking facilities owned by us but operated by third parties, as well as income from renting specific areas in parking facilities to third parties. - _EV charging revenues: revenue from electric vehicle charging points that are owned by us. - _Other revenues: represents all other revenues not included in the above categories (for example, subsidies, services and advertising.

Subsection Title: Critical Accounting Policies
Subsubsection Text: Depreciation primarily consists of depreciation of tangible fixed assets (including land and building, leasehold improvements, equipment and installations and assets under construction). Depreciation of tangible fixed assets is based on linear depreciation over the expected period in use and taking the expected residual value into account. Depreciation commences on the date an asset comes into use. Amortization primarily consists of amortization of intangible fixed assets (including goodwill, concessions and other intangible fixed assets such as trade names and software). Amortization is charged as a fixed percentage of cost. Goodwill on acquisitions is capitalized and amortized on a straight line basis over a period between five and 20 years. This period is derived from the long-term business profile and cash flows from the underlying assets (owned and leased parking facilities). Concessions in France involving a (finite) concession for the use of the ground and facility are depreciated on a straight line basis over the duration of the underlying concession agreements with an assumed residual value of nil. The book value of the concessions includes all capital expenditure related to the underlying parking facilities. The other intangible fixed assets are amortized on a straight line basis over the expected useful economic life with an assumed residual value of nil. The expected useful life and the amortization method are reassessed at the end of each financial year. At the relevant balance sheet date, we determine whether there are any indicators present that goodwill, other intangible fixed assets and/or tangible fixed assets are impaired. If and when indicators are identified, such as a declining performance or other negative market developments, an impairment calculation is performed based on an estimation of future cash flows. If applicable, an impairment result is recognized.

Subsection Title: Critical Accounting Policies
Subsubsection Text: Corporate income tax is calculated at the applicable rate on the result for the financial year, taking into account permanent differences between profit calculated according to the financial statements and profit calculated for taxation purposes. The current tax is calculated using tax rates that have been enacted or substantively enacted by the end of the reporting period including changes regarding taxes to be paid in respect of previous years. Corporate income taxes are presented under the cash flow from operating activities. There is some uncertainty regarding the interpretation of complex tax regulations and the tax effects of the acquisition and financing structure of the Group. Considering the wide range of international business relationships and the long-running and complex nature of existing contractual agreements, differences may arise between the assumptions made and the actual results, or future changes in such assumptions may influence the actual results. Deferred tax assets related to unused tax losses are recognized insofar as it is probable that profit for tax purposes will be available to which this can be offset. To determine the value of the deferred tax assets arising from tax losses not offset, a management assessment is required regarding the probable timing and level of the future taxable profits, combined with future fiscal planning strategies. For further details, see Note 17 in the audited consolidated annual accounts and the company annual accounts of the Parent as of and for the year ended December 31, 2023 included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum.

Subsection Title: Critical Accounting Policies
Subsubsection Text: Deferred tax assets with respect to tax-deductible losses and temporary valuation differences are recognized and are valued at the tax rates expected to apply in the future years. Deferred tax assets are only recognized if and to the extent that sufficient fiscal benefit is expected as compensation or if sufficient deferred tax liabilities arising from temporary taxable differences are available. 108 ----- Deferred tax liabilities with respect to temporary differences between the tax base and commercial valuation of assets and liabilities are stated at nominal value and based on the tax rates against which these differences are expected to be settled in the future. Deferred tax assets and liabilities will be offset against each other if these fall within a tax group for corporate tax and as far as the periods in which settlement is expected coincide.

Subsection Title: Critical Accounting Policies
Subsubsection Text: A provision for onerous contracts is recognized for contracts in which the unavoidable costs of meeting the obligations under the contract exceed the economic benefits expected to be received under it. The unavoidable costs reflect the lowest net costs of exiting from the contract, which is the lower of the cost of fulfilling the contract and any compensation or penalties arising from the failure to fulfil the contract. As the time value of money is material to the provision, the amount is discounted at the market rate of high-quality corporate bonds. 109 -----

Subsection Title: Critical Accounting Policies
Subsubsection Text: This “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations” discusses our consolidated financial statements, which have been prepared in accordance with Dutch GAAP for the years ended December 31, 2021, 2022 and 2023, and the three months ended March 31, 2023 and 2024. Accounting estimates are an integral part of the preparation of the financial statements and the financial reporting process and are based upon current judgments. The preparation of financial statements in conformity with Dutch GAAP requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reported period. Certain accounting estimates are particularly sensitive because of their complexity and the possibility that future events affecting them may differ materially from our current judgments and estimates. This listing of critical accounting policies is not intended to be a comprehensive list of all our accounting policies. In many cases, the accounting treatment of a particular transaction is specifically dictated by Dutch GAAP, with no need for management’s judgment regarding accounting policy. We believe that of our significant accounting policies, the following policies may involve a higher degree of judgment and complexity. For further information, see Note 2 of the audited consolidated annual accounts of the Parent as of and for the year ended December 31, 2023.

Subsection Title: INDUSTRY Overview of the Parking Industry
Subsubsection Text: The parking sector has experienced a strong recovery since the COVID-19 pandemic in terms of both volumes and LFL revenues, demonstrating an ability to recover from industry disruption faster than other traffic exposed asset classes. Within the broader transport space, car parks are most analogous to toll roads, which have experienced the fastest pace of recovery since COVID-19. Within the parking sector, the return to pre-COVID19 volume levels and revenues indicates that large scale private parking operators (including us) have been able to successfully navigate this ultimate stress test from the pandemic. In spite of a slightly heavier exposure to COVID-19 restrictions, parking operators faced limited loss in the aftermath, indicative of a structural ability to return to pre-pandemic levels at a faster pace when compared to most traffic-exposed asset classes. For instance, our Short Term Parking (“STP”) volumes have fully recovered to pre-pandemic volume levels (based on sold hours in respect of our PMS Connected facilities), while our Long Term Parking (“LTP”) volume remained broadly stable throughout the period impacted by COVID-19 restrictions. In addition, on a revenue basis, we have improved significantly above pre-pandemic levels, with our Underlying Total Revenue for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024 26% above the year ended December 31, 2019, driven by the continued increase in volumes supported by ongoing price increases in line with inflation. Similar volume recovery across other parking operators further indicates the structural resilience of the broader parking sector. 110 -----

Subsection Title: INDUSTRY Overview of the Parking Industry
Subsubsection Text: Parking plays a central role in the overall mobility infrastructure sector, providing an essential service and forming an integral part of mobility planning. With a workforce of more than 450,000 people in the 27 EU Member States and an annual turnover in excess of €70 billion, the sector is an important economic activity. The structure of the European parking market is very fragmented, where the top three to five players have, on average, a combined market share of less than 50%. Many parking spaces are independently operated by cities, municipalities, clinics, hospitals, or private operators. In general, municipalities hold the largest market share (typically 20 to 30%), while approximately 50% of all managed parking spaces are owned by companies. The five largest private parking operators by parking spaces in Europe are Q-Park, APCOA, Indigo, Interparking and Empark. Parking operators can be segmented by offering (on-street or off-street), geographic presence, business model and contract type with the largest players typically operating across most of these dimensions. The parking sector encompasses many core infrastructure characteristics including demand stability and cashflow visibility with the combination of limited pricing regulation and price inelastic demand driving favorable pricing dynamics. The sector is impacted by various regulatory tailwinds, with municipalities increasingly adopting a paradigm shift in urban planning mainly focused on urban liveability and sustainability, which have led to a targeted decrease in on-street parking and a shift of parking supply towards off-street. The sector is also poised to benefit from structural growth drivers and macro trends including increasing car fleet levels, changing demographics, increasing urbanization, desire for cities as a leisure experience, rise of micro mobility, need for critical urban infrastructure such as last mile logistics and increasing themes around alternative uses of space. In addition, the sector is currently experiencing innovation, digitization and electrification trends that offer opportunities to impact the value chain. These dynamics are expected to benefit the larger established private parking companies by creating new sources of income and further improvements across both volumes and pricing.

Subsection Title: Volume change in comparison to the year ended December 31, 2019 for broader transport sector
Subsubsection Text: 1 Based on average publicly available traffic disclosures for key players by each mode of transport. Toll road traffic based on Abertis, Air passenger based on Fraport, AENA, AdP, AdR, TAV, Schipol. Air Cargo based on Heathrow, Fraport, AENA, Schiphol. Rail cargo based on Getlink. Global port calls based on Clarksons. 2 Based on LFL STP hours sold.

Subsection Title: Market Segmentation
Subsubsection Text: Parking spaces or facilities are generally classified by location as on-street or off-street: - Off-street: Paid or unpaid public-use parking spaces where access is generally controlled by barriers. The existence of physical barriers makes these types of facilities less personnel intensive. Off-street facility contracts are typically longer in duration (more than 15 years). Such facilities may be indoor or outdoor and are mostly located in or near event-driven locations such as city centers, stadiums, museums, hospitals, airports, train stations and other transportation intermodal hubs, hotels, and shopping malls.
