Users can rent parking spaces for the short term (on an hourly or daily basis) or long term (monthly, quarterly, half-yearly and yearly). Off-street parking also includes “Park & Ride,” which are off-street parking facilities located close to coach or rail stations or other transport interchanges. “Park & Ride” facilities aim to reduce car use and incentivize use of other transportation modes. Other parking solutions include “Park & Fly,” which provides customers the option to pre-book parking spaces at parking facilities that are located at or close to airports, and “Park & Charge,” which provides customers the option to charge their EVs using the EV charging points when parked at a facility. Off-street parking facilities are generally privately owned or owned by municipalities or public transport entities. - On-street: Paid or unpaid regulated parking spaces on the roads generally with signposting or some type of surveillance. Access to on-street parking is not controlled, and on-street parking is typically short-term in nature. Certain parking spaces may be awarded or rented to local residents exclusively. Other reserved 111 ----- spaces include handicapped, police, hotel or taxi parking spaces. On-street parking is more exposed to regulatory changes and city mobility policies. We are predominantly an off-street parking company, with off-street business accounting for 90.2% of our Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs) for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. In recent years, there has been a regulatory shift towards off-street parking. See “—Regulatory Shift Away From _On-street and Towards Off-street Parking For Cities.” This, combined with the consolidation opportunities that_ have arisen because of such shift, is beneficial to large established players, including Q-Park. Parking facilities can also be classified, by the type of destination they serve for the customer, as mono-functional and multi-functional: - Multi-functional: These facilities serve multiple functions or destinations and are typically located in city centers. Key functions around these facilities are shopping, office, leisure, residence (e.g., bars, restaurants, theatres, cinemas, events) and often other transport infrastructure (e.g., train, bus, bike). - Mono-functional: These facilities predominantly serve a single destination, for example hospitals, airport, train stations, retail malls and office buildings. Key volume drivers include railway, hospital, airport, commuting and shopping traffic. The vast majority of our facilities are multi-functional parking facilities, which represented 70% of our Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs) for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024.

Subsection Title: Business Models and Contract Types
Subsubsection Text: Parking operators utilize with a number of different business and contract models, and these vary across multiple factors such as duration, capital investment required, profitability and pricing flexibility. The most common business models in our countries of operation are legal ownership, ground leases, concessions, leases (both shortterm and long term), protected leases and management contracts. - Legal ownership: Operator fully owns the grounds and the facility. Requires substantial initial investment but offers highest business flexibility, pricing power, profitability and control. Legal ownership is available across Europe. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, legal ownership contracts represented 20.4% of our Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs). - Ground leases: Ground lease refers to a (finite or infinite) limited real right to a property, such that the property is owned, or exclusive right of use is provided in or on another person’s land. The land is leased (often from a government, public authority, or private landlord) but the operator owns the facility. Given the required initial capital investment, length of the finite ground leases are typically above 50 years, typically with high renewal rates. Compensation schemes are sometimes applicable at the end of the ground lease depending on the applicable jurisdictions and agreed terms. This business model also offers high flexibility, pricing power, profitability and control. Ground leases are available across Europe. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our ground leases represented 23.8% of our Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs) and as of March 31, 2024, have an average duration of approximately 57 years. - Concessions: Gives the operator the exclusive right to operate the car park for the concession period. Concessions are typically medium- to long-term with duration ranging from 10 to 40 years. Concessions also typically require a significant upfront capital investment. The concessionaire generally pays an upfront fixed sum and/or an annual fee (whether fixed or a percentage of revenue) to the owner of the property or land (usually a municipality). Renewal is typically via a public tender process. This business model also offers high flexibility, profitability and control. Pricing power is usually contractually agreed and linked to a certain index (e.g., CPI) with ability to increase prices subject to the time and rate boundaries outlined in the concession terms. This business model is predominantly available in France. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, concessions represented 21.8% of our Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs) and as of March 31, 2024, our concessions have an average duration of approximately 11 years. 112 ----- - Protected leases: Gives the operator the right to operate the facility with the leases extending automatically. Protected leases incorporate legal protection against termination of the lease by the owner. This business model is available in Ireland. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, protected leases represented 0.7% of our Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs). - Leases: Lease length can range from one year up to 50 or more years. Both the lessee and the lessor can have the option to extend the lease and, in some cases, the lessee has the unilateral option to extend the lease. Ownership of the property usually sits with either a municipality or a private landlord. Lease renewal is via a tender or commercial process (often also under an exclusivity arrangement). Due to the periodic lease amount, leases typically have a lower gross margin. This business model is available across Europe. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, long term leases represented 22.9% of our Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs) and as of March 31, 2024, our long-term leases have an average duration of approximately 22 years. For the same period, short term leases (together with management contracts and control fee contracts (contracts for the enforcement of paid parking in parking facilities owned by landlords)) represented 10.0% of our Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs). - Management contracts: Gives the operator the right to manage a parking facility usually for a fixed fee typically with limited revenue exposure as the underlying ownership or lease belongs to a third party. Management contracts are typically shorter than five years with no or minimal initial investment required. The operator receives payment based on time spent (usually on a cost-plus basis). The operator typically bears limited revenue or cost risks. This business model is subject to competition due to lower barriers to entry and the short-term nature of contracts. This business model has no pricing power with lower margins and levels of control than other business models. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, management contracts (and other short-term business, including short term leases and control fee contracts) represented 10.0% of our Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs). During the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, we derived approximately 89.6% of our Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs) from facilities that are owned or operated under our long-term business, of which 83% entitled to operate until at least 2033 (assuming no renewals, new business or price indexation). Long-term business includes all facilities that are legally owned or subject to a ground lease, concession or protected lease, as well as any long-term leases which have an initial duration of at least 15 years. 1 Underlying Gross Margin excludes non allocated and central operating costs. 2 Based on Underlying Gross Margin for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, excluding non-allocated and central operating costs. _Source: Company information._

Subsection Title: Structural Growth Drivers of the Parking Sector
Subsubsection Text: The car fleet in the countries where we operate is expected to grow at a steady rate of 0.5% from 2023 to 2033 according to GlobalData, driven by a growing and aging population in urban hubs. Personal cars (excluding ride hailing and taxis) also remain the most popular form of transport, accounting for 45% of trips worldwide (Source: _The Future of Mobility, McKinsey & Company Quarterly Report, April 2023), ahead of public transport, ride_ hailing and other mobility modes. Despite changing car ownership models and mobility trends, the consistent growth of the personal car fleet is an important driver of the parking industry’s turnover. 113 ----- We are geographically diversified and currently operate in The Netherlands, Belgium, France, Germany, the United Kingdom, Ireland, and Denmark. These countries, where people are accustomed to paying for parking, are stable in terms of demand and have historically experienced consistent year-on-year personal car fleet growth that is expected to continue in the future. The highest growth over the next 10 years is expected to come from Ireland, with an expected CAGR of 1.2% between 2023 and 2033.

Subsection Title: Light Vehicle Fleet in Countries in which We Operate (in millions of cars)
Subsubsection Title: Mature Market Benefitting from Favorable Pricing Dynamics
Subsubsection Text: Parking is a mature sector benefitting from structurally growing demand, high barriers to market entry (especially in off-street parking) and high supply fragmentation with the larger private parking companies best positioned for growth, consolidation, and market leadership. New supply of parking spaces is limited, especially in city centers as municipalities focus on urban liveability initiatives (Source: Local Government Association, Structural Growth _Drivers of the Parking Sector: Local and Central Government Regulations). Scarcity of locations and_ irreplaceable assets benefit large players with established positions and long-term contracts. Furthermore, operating clusters of car parks in near proximity provides substantial pricing power advantage as operational economies of scale play an important role when pricing and winning new contracts.

Subsection Title: Light Vehicle Fleet in Countries in which We Operate (in millions of cars)
Subsubsection Text: _Source: GlobalData, Global Light Vehicle Forecast – Summary Tables – September 2023._

Subsection Title: Drivers of Parking Demand Top factors for drivers when choosing a parking location in Europe
Subsubsection Text: _Source: Parkopedia, 2023 Global Driver Survey._ According to the Parkopedia 2023 Global Driver Survey, distance to destination and parking cost are considered to be the most relevant factors for customers when choosing a parking location in Europe, followed by parking availability and type of parking location. 44% of European drivers also indicated a willingness to pay a premium of up to 10% to park in their preferred locations. In general, customers’ demand for parking tends to be price inelastic, which underpins favorable pricing dynamics for large private parking companies who have presence in strategic locations and parking clusters. All countries in which we operate experienced an increase in off-street pricing in the last two years, with the majority of countries experiencing a steep price increase. The biggest increase in off-street pricing was observed in The Netherlands, where the average two-hour price for off-street parking increased by 11% since 2019. Despite these increases, off-street parking is generally still a cheaper option than on-street parking in most of the countries in which we operate. 114 -----

Subsection Title: Average two-hour price for off-street parking in countries in which we operate
Subsubsection Text: _Source: Parkopedia, 2022 Global Parking Index (figures in USD)._

Subsection Title: Pricing for on-street vs off-street parking in countries in which we operate
Subsubsection Text: The parking sector is highly fragmented, especially in the off-street market segment. Typically, municipalities operate the largest share of the off-street market, with 20-30% market share. Belgium and Ireland are somewhat below the range while Germany is substantially above the range. This dominance of municipalities is typically lower in larger cities than in smaller cities due to higher parking prices and increased visitor volumes, which create a better business case for private operators. In all countries where we operate, there is no single private parking company dominating the local market. Belgium is the most concentrated market where the top five players (including us) jointly control nearly half of the market. The other countries in which we operate are more fragmented with the top two to four players having a combined market share of approximately 10-35%. We are one of the top private parking companies based on the number of parking spaces operated in all of our markets. Further, based on a third party consultant report, we are a top three player as of December 31, 2023, based on offstreet parking revenue, in all of the countries in which we operate, and market leader in The Netherlands. As a result of this fragmentation, a significant consolidation opportunity exists, particularly for large private parking companies, whose scale and financial resources make it possible to acquire facilities and/or contracts from smaller players or to acquire some smaller companies (through bolt-on M&A). The provision of parking facilities is also becoming an increasingly privatized business model across countries as municipalities continue to outsource the operation of both on-street and off-street parking facilities to private operators. 115 ----- Furthermore, due to market fragmentation, private parking operators try to create “clusters” in strategic locations in cities to create local scale. For example, we have clusters in key cities including Amsterdam, Antwerp, Chambery, Chartres, Hasselt, Maastricht, Rotterdam, The Hague, Toulon and others. These clusters enable the larger scale players (including us) to further increase pricing power, reduce operational costs by having a single task force servicing multiple facilities and develop relationships with local governments and municipalities, providing the opportunity to participate in regulatory reviews and decisions relating to the industry.

Subsection Title: Pricing for on-street vs off-street parking in countries in which we operate
Subsubsection Title: Regulatory Shift Away from On-street and Towards Off-street Parking for Cities
Subsubsection Text: The majority of the parking spaces in the countries in which we operate are off-street parking spaces. As a result of pedestrian-focused urban planning and traffic and environmental concerns, local municipalities are increasingly dis-incentivizing car usage especially in large city centers. Local municipalities in various countries in Europe have been reducing on-street parking spaces and introducing maximum allowed parking times as well as increasing on-street parking pricing to drive parking traffic towards off-street facilities. For example, in the Amsterdam municipality, parking tariffs in the city center were increased by approximately 50% in April 2019 and have consistently been above off-street parking tariffs since then (on-street tariffs in Amsterdam were approximately 7% higher than off-street tariffs in 2022; Parkopedia, 2022 Global Parking Index). As a result of such factors, the growing parking demand is “pushed” towards off-street private parking as people look to park upon arriving in a city and then use other modes of transportation to move and commute to and within the city center (including buses, trams and other forms of public transportation). Some of the regulatory-driven initiatives being implemented by municipalities include: - Introduction of anti-pollution and other environmental policies (e.g., car fleet electrification, low emission zones) and reduction in on-street parking in low-emission zones - Designation of certain car-free roads within city centers - Transformation of certain off-street facilities into multi-modal hubs, creating an opportunity for partnerships with car-sharing operators in cities with limited on-street parking availability Examples from some European cities that introduced pedestrian-focused urban planning and anti-traffic measures include Amsterdam, Paris, and Copenhagen. - **Amsterdam: In 2019, the municipality of Amsterdam announced that it is planning a reduction of up to 11,200 on-street parking spaces by the end of 2025 with a planned reduction in parking permits of approximately 1,500 per year. The municipality of Amsterdam is also looking for possibilities to make some areas in the city center traffic-free. For example, in summer 2023, the municipality closed one of the city’s major traffic routes to cars in a six-week trial. - **Paris: In 2020, Paris announced it will remove 60,000 of its 140,000 on-street parking spaces to allow for more space for cyclists and pedestrians and allow for an “ecological transformation of the city.” This was subsequently increased to 70,000 with a target date of the end of 2025. This has been accompanied by a 50% increase in parking prices in the city center and an introduction of parking charges for nonelectric motorcycles (Parkopedia, Navigating The Ever-changing On-street Parking Landscape, 2022). - **Copenhagen: According to the Cycling Embassy of Denmark, on-street car parking spaces are being replaced by bicycle parking spaces. Additionally, a number of car parking spaces will be converted to flexible parking spaces for both bicycles and cars. The increase in bicycle parking spaces is expected to continue in the near future. In addition, the local authority introduced the “Cyclist Priority Plan for 20172025,” which seeks to see 50% of commuting journeys completed by bicycle. In January 2023, a further 600 on-street parking spots were earmarked to be removed in the Medieval City area in 2024. The municipality plans to cut one-third of current on-street parking spaces with another one-third transformed into parking for shared cars, disabled parking permits and business parking. Our position as a leading player in our key markets allows us to immediately benefit from the increased volume shift towards off-street parking as municipalities phase out on-street parking locations. For example, in Antwerp from August 2023, previous on-street parking locations in the historic city centre have been redesignated a parking zone where parking and public charging is restricted to residents with a parking permit, certain permit holders (care providers, car sharers, etc) and people with disabilities. The implication is that non-permit holders who would typically park on the street previously now have to find alternative parking solutions mostly entailing 116 ----- parking just outside the city centre where we have a large presence. We also have more than 150 parking facilities that we classify as mobility hubs and which allows us to be well positioned to take advantage of ancillary revenue opportunities (e.g., partnership with car-sharing operators, last mile delivery providers, etc.)

Subsection Title: Pricing for on-street vs off-street parking in countries in which we operate
Subsubsection Title: Long-term Potential Supported by Structural Trends
Subsubsection Text: The parking sector benefits from various structural trends, which further support the long-term potential of the industry. This includes macro and demographic factors (such as urbanization, focus on city center experiences), industry-specific innovation trends (such as increasing digitization, the development of autonomous vehicles and car sharing) as well as local government regulation.

Subsection Title: Pricing for on-street vs off-street parking in countries in which we operate
Subsubsection Text: _Source: Parkopedia, 2022 Global Parking Index (figures in USD)._

Subsection Title: Industry Trends
Subsubsection Text: The percentage of the urban population globally increased from approximately 54% in 2016 to approximately 57% in 2021 and is expected to reach approximately 68% by 2050. The expected increase in urbanization of cities will lead to a growing number of vehicles and further increases in parking demand. Increased urbanization will also require innovative and flexible solutions for more efficient urban infrastructure and development.

Subsection Title: Industry Trends
Subsubsection Text: As the demand for leisure experiences such as dining, shopping, cinemas and museums in city centers increases, city centers are becoming busier, with an increased demand for parking. According to multiple studies, an increasing proportion of consumers value experiences over buying a product and as such, are spending more on experiences (according to research by Momentum Worldwide in 2019, 76% of consumers prefer to spend on experiences rather than on material things). As a result of this, the role of city centers is therefore changing from a pure retail or shopping experience to a combined offline shopping and leisure experience. As such, parking operators with the best locations in and around city centers are well placed to capture parking demand.

Subsection Title: Industry Trends
Subsubsection Text: Recent regulatory trends around city planning, ESG and increased focus on urban liveability have led to a wave of regulatory initiatives which have an impact on the parking sector. These initiatives focus on increasing active mobility (walking and cycling) and shared mobility (car sharing, public transport) with the aim on reducing car traffic in cities and creating more space for greenery (such as trees and parks), pedestrians and cyclists to make cities more appealing to city dwellers. The initiatives also focus on achieving environmental goals (e.g., carbon neutrality). Some of the environmental initiatives include car fleet electrification, congestion charges, low emission zones, new parking policies (such as Park & Ride) and introduction of stricter speed restrictions. These trends are resulting in a decrease in on-street parking spaces and shifting demand towards off-street parking, providing significant opportunities for off-street private parking companies to capture incremental market shares in the overall parking market. Additionally, private parking companies that have good and long-standing relationships with local government authorities will be well-placed to collaborate and advise cities on smart ways to decrease traffic created from searching for parking spaces (for example, by providing dynamic parking information and encouraging drivers to pre-book their parking spaces) and then benefit from these regulatory changes driving an increase in off-street parking. Continued constructive collaboration with municipalities is key to retaining market share given the evolving regulatory landscape. Contracts with municipalities, regardless of whether for on-street or off-street parking, unlock a seat at the table for key decision-making processes and provide early insight into potential regulatory shifts.

Subsection Title: Industry Trends
Subsubsection Text: The change in consumer dynamics, the increased use of technology and ongoing energy transition are changing the mobility and parking value chain significantly. The post-pandemic era has seen an increasing shift of consumer spending from “physical goods” to “experiences.” Customers seem to value and spend more on memorable experiences like travel, events, leisure activities, restaurants and bars. Furthermore, increasing adoption of technology across all spheres of customer experiences have impacted how customers interact with parking. 117 -----

Subsection Title: How European drivers search for parking
Subsubsection Text: The European EV fleet is projected to grow from 7.8 million (2.4% of total fleet) as of 2022 to 56 million (18.0% of total fleet) as of 2030. While most of the charging demand is currently met by home charging, publicly accessible chargers are increasingly required in order to meet the charging demand of a growing EV fleet and as such, has created an increased need for charging assets linked to parking. Developing charging infrastructure will be important to meeting ever-evolving mobility demands with destination charging expected to take a significant 118 ----- share of the incremental charging demand in the near term. Parking operators are well placed to operate EV charging stations as they provide a convenient “park & charge” solution for electric vehicle drivers. According to the Parkopedia 2023 Global Driver Survey, EV drivers do not factor in parking costs as a critical factor in choice of parking locations as distance to destination, charger availability and charging costs are more important factors. Enhancing car parks with EV charging infrastructure provides an avenue for private car park operators to attract new customers and generate incremental parking volumes and revenue as well as charging revenues. The ownership model of the EV charging infrastructure also determines how much direct control a parking owner or operator has over the economics from parking. We operate a direct ownership model which gives us significant control over the investments and realizable economics from EV charging.

Subsection Title: How European drivers search for parking
Subsubsection Text: _Source: Parkopedia, 2023 Global Driver Survey._ The parking industry has adapted to these changes with increasing use of digitization and technology to improve online visibility of parking assets for customers who are planning ahead for their experience-based mobility and parking needs, with the aim of improving the overall customer experience journey. These developments have also created a need for stronger partnerships with key players in the broader mobility ecosystem. Digitization of the parking sector is expected to contribute towards a more efficient, flexible and seamless parking experience for customers as well as differentiated targeting and increased efficiency for operators. Increasing digitization has also provided scope for parking operators to expand their service offering and create ancillary revenue sources. Some of these include: - Seamless parking using number plate recognition (ANPR) or other QR-based access methods - New customer product offerings (online pre-booking and event parking for the planners, app-based parking for the regular customers) - Flexible product offerings for private, small businesses and large businesses and their employees - Cloud-based, automatic pre- or post-payment with more flexible payment options (e.g., multiple credit cards, direct debit, digital wallets, pay-as-you-go vs. bulk payments) - Electric vehicle charging stations, for private use as well as business use (e.g., vehicle fleet charging, charging for taxis, last mile delivery) - Convenient last mile mobility add-ons (e.g., bus or train to the airport, tram to the beach, travel to an offsite event location) - Reduced traffic created from searching for parking spaces by providing an alternative for on-street parking - Traffic trends, parking and charging availability (near-time or real-time updates to guide customers to the right location) - Paperless, digital invoicing services (e.g., for businesses customers) Technology is also fundamentally affecting the demand for an appropriately skilled workforce in the parking industry, where private parking companies increasingly invest in technology and new value-add services to improve customer engagement, drive efficiency and enable future growth.

Subsection Title: Factors Influencing Choice of Charging Location in Europe
Subsubsection Text: Penetration of autonomous vehicles is expected to remain insignificant for the next 15 years due to regulatory and technological limitations. Off-street car parks are still well-positioned and will have the opportunity to evolve into natural mobility hubs in the city centers where autonomous vehicles can park and charge.

Subsection Title: Factors Influencing Choice of Charging Location in Europe
Subsubsection Text: Adoption of e-commerce opportunities in the retail space has led to an increasing switch of the retail experience from in-store to online which has led to a reducing number of brick-and-mortar stores. As a result, landlords are starting to convert previously retail tenancy to non-retail creating multi-entertainment hubs. Car park operators focused on multi-functional facilities are best placed to emerge winners from this trend.

Subsection Title: Factors Influencing Choice of Charging Location in Europe
Subsubsection Text: Car sharing has continuously seen growth in recent years, especially in bigger cities where more people are passing on the costs of car ownership. Positive effects of car sharing include reduction of traffic congestion and environmental benefits. According to Statista, the European car-sharing market is projected to generate approximately $4.9 billion in revenues in 2023 and expected to grow at approximately 4%, reaching approximately $5.7 billion by 2027. Europe represents a significant portion of the global car sharing market, with 38% of the global car sharing revenue and 33% of the global car sharing users. The car sharing user base is 119 ----- expected to grow at a CAGR of approximately 4% from approximately 18 million users in 2023 to approximately 21 million users in 2027 (Statista). Although car sharing has strong positive benefits and is expected to increase vehicle utilization rates (the time cars spend on the road), most car buyers still prefer car ownership over usership. Despite changing ownership models (from individuals to mobility service providers), cars will still require parking and charging spaces.

Subsection Title: Factors Influencing Choice of Charging Location in Europe
Subsubsection Text: Focus on urban liveability by municipalities and increasing transformation of parking facilities into mobility hubs has created avenues for parking operators to create ancillary revenue opportunities from re-purposing excess car park spaces for other uses. Some of these include last mile logistics, food delivery, energy solutions (battery storage and solar panels), fleet charging and car sharing. However, most of these remain relatively limited today in their use of car park space. 120 -----

Subsection Title: Factors Influencing Choice of Charging Location in Europe
Subsubsection Text: _Source: Parkopedia, 2023 Global Driver Survey._ As of December 31, 2023 have 4,114 EV charging points, of which 2,996 are under the asset-heavy model (where we are in full control of the revenues) as of March 31, 2024. We plan to have approximately 5,500 charging points by the end of 2024. As of March 31, 2024, we have invested approximately €12.9 million in EV charging infrastructure, which delivers a “run-rate” Underlying Gross Margin of approximately €4.7 million. We define “run-rate” Underlying Gross Margin as the annualized run-rate impact of EV charging volumes for the second half of the year ended December 31, 2023 (calculated on the basis of EV charging points installed capacity as of December 31, 2023) on the Underlying Gross Margin from our EV charging business for the year ended December 31, 2023.

Subsection Title: BUSINESS Overview
Subsubsection Text: We are a leading parking infrastructure owner and operator in the Western European market, with a large and diversified portfolio of owned, leased and managed parking facilities across seven Western European countries. We mainly operate off-street parking spaces owned by us as well as parking spaces under concessions and longterm leases from public and private landlords, with a focus on off-street purpose-built parking facilities at strategic locations. We operate 4,315 parking facilities comprising 896,187 parking spaces as of March 31, 2024 in The Netherlands, France, the United Kingdom, Germany, Belgium, Denmark and Ireland. As of March 31, 2024, our long-term business portfolio included 64 legally owned facilities, 66 ground lease facilities and five protected lease facilities, 187 concession facilities and 402 long-term lease facilities, which together comprised over 320,000 parking spaces. As of March 31, 2024, our short-term business comprised 3,591 facilities and over 576,000 parking spaces. Based on a third party consultant report, we are a top three player as of December 31, 2023, based on off-street parking revenue, in all of the countries in which we operate. Below are charts showing the percentage of Underlying Gross Margin generated by country of operation and our contract mix by Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs) for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024.

Subsection Title: Strengths
Subsubsection Title: Large and Growing Market with Strong Fundamentals
Subsubsection Text: The off-street parking industry in Western Europe is highly fragmented with a limited number of large players. Accordingly, leading parking infrastructure players like us are better positioned than smaller operators to take advantage of positive industry dynamics and benefit from the resilience and maturity of the market. Our operations are supported by a growing customer base, well-established presence and favorable pricing dynamics. As an established market player, we have consistently grown our total revenue for the past 25 years (other than in 2020, when our revenues were impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic). The European countries in which we operate have also seen continued growth in light vehicle fleet which, according to GlobalData, is expected to grow at a CAGR of 0.5% over the next decade. Personal cars (excluding ride hailing and taxis) are also expected to remain the most popular form of transport, accounting for 45% of trips worldwide, ahead of public transport, ride hailing and other mobility modes, according to The Future of Mobility, McKinsey Quarterly Report, published in April 2023. In addition, we believe that upfront costs and regulatory requirements (including obtaining planning permissions to build new high density parking facilities, complying with regulatory frameworks governing parking concessions and navigating contracts with municipalities) and the economies of scale that result from operating multiple facilities across multiple geographies present significant challenges for new entrants in the car parking industry in Western Europe. In addition, our long-standing relationship with municipalities enables an ongoing dialogue with public sector players, allowing us to be a key counterpart in discussions to improve local and regional mobility solutions. This provides us with opportunities to expand our existing business with such municipalities, and we are well positioned to handle their requirements. Although our volumes (measured by sold hours in respect of our PMS Connected facilities) across the broader transport sector were negatively impacted by the mobility restrictions imposed in response to the COVID-19 pandemic between 2020 and 2022, car traffic (and closely linked to it, toll road traffic) has experienced the fastest pace of recovery among the broader transport sector. As of December 31, 2023, our LFL short term parking volumes (measured by sold hours in respect of our PMS Connected facilities) have recovered to approximately 102% of 2019 levels, while air cargo remains below 2019 levels. A similar recovery in volume has also been experienced across other parking operators in Western Europe, demonstrating the structural resilience of the broader parking sector and a proven ability to recover from industry disruption at a faster pace compared to other traffic-exposed asset classes. Further, we believe that the parking sector is expected to benefit from key trends in the industry, including, for example, (i) the regulatory shift away from on-street parking with reduced on-street parking provisions in low emission zones and/or in densely populated cities, (ii) increasing priority given to pedestrians, cyclists and various forms of shared mobility (including car sharing and public transport) as cities and municipalities increase their sustainability focus, (iii) change in consumer dynamics to focus more on experiences and (iv) carbon neutrality and “green city” goals of various jurisdictions. The increased focus on electrifying the car fleet to meet “green city” objectives is expected to drive the penetration of EVs in Europe from approximately 1% in 2020 to approximately 18% by 2030. We believe that we are well positioned to take advantage of these trends given our (i) continued focus on off-street parking, (ii) strategically located parking assets to capture continued demand, (iii) our highly developed technology platform that provides a digital parking ecosystem and seamless customer experience journey and (iv) the deployment of our EV Charging Program, which we launched in May 2022 to substantially increase the number of EV charging points (“CP”) in our owned and long-leased parking facilities to 5,500 by the end of 2024. As of December 31, 2023, our parking facilities offer 4,114 EV CPs, of which 2,996 are part of our “asset-heavy model,” whereby such EV CPs are owned by us but operated by third parties. We aim to profitably expand our EV charging business through an increasing number of EV CPs in our owned and longleased parking facilities in line with the continued increase in penetration of EVs in Europe. 123 -----

Subsection Title: Strengths
Subsubsection Title: Leading Off-Street Parking Infrastructure Owner and Operator in Western Europe with Local Scale and Diversified Portfolio of Value Creating Assets in Strategic Locations
Subsubsection Text: We are one of the leading off-street car park infrastructure owners and operators in the Western European parking market, with 4,315 parking facilities comprising 896,187 parking spaces as of March 31, 2024. Based on a third party consultant report, we have a top three market position as of December 31, 2023 in all of the Western European countries in which we operate based on off-street parking revenue. Our large footprint across our seven countries of operation allows us to build on a local scale in each of these markets. Our size and scale allows us to operate our car park portfolio efficiently, for example through sharing resources among our car parks (in particular, in clusters where we operate multiple parking facilities in close proximity), including maintenance and supervisory staff, as well as management resources in respect of accounting, marketing, human resources, insurance and tax matters. The number of our locations and the connectivity of our parking facilities through our digital capabilities and proprietary technology gives us a commercial advantage and enables us to anticipate customer needs across multiple locations. For example, our access to real-time transactional data on occupancy and availability of our parking facilities enables us to better anticipate and predict customer demand. In addition, due to our size and scale, we are better equipped to make significant investments in IT and to leverage such investments across our operations compared to smaller competitors. Between January 1, 2021 and March 31, 2024, we invested approximately €32 million in Underlying ICT & Other Capex, which includes investments in enhancements of infrastructure and cyber security. Such operational efficiencies and cost savings generated through IT initiatives and investments allow us to offer attractive terms to municipalities and landlords and operate a differentiated pricing model. Finally, the size and diversity of our portfolio means that we have significant experience with different operating models, allowing us to adapt effectively and efficiently to different contract types and regulatory structures. Our market leading positions, size and growth have allowed us to achieve significant economies of scale, and the scope of our operations and the quality of our assets have supported the quick recovery of our Underlying Total Revenue following the COVID-19 pandemic. We have been able to achieve operational efficiencies and cost savings through the implementation of a streamlined and lean management and governance structure across our operations. Our economies of scale enable us to be a consolidation platform for European parking operations and allow us to undertake and quickly integrate valuable new concessions and acquisitions of smaller players, as well as individual assets and lease contracts. In addition, through our experienced management team, and due to our long-standing reputation in the industry, we have been able to develop and maintain important relationships with various municipalities and private landlords with whom we do business, thereby reducing our dependence on any single local governmental authority or region. In the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, no single contract represented more than 3% of our total Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs) and no single city represented more than 11% of our Underlying Total Revenue or our Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs). We have strategically positioned our portfolio to focus on off-street parking in line with the regulatory shift in favor of off-street parking. Our off-street parking business and on-street parking business represented approximately 90% and 10%, respectively, of our Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs) for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. Off-street parking contracts are typically longer duration contracts (generally more than 15 years) in comparison to on-street parking contracts (generally less than five years). This generates long-term cash flows with a balanced mix of short- and long-term parking customers. Short-term parking customers provide immediate payment, while long-term parking customers provide revenue stability and advance payments. Further, off-street parking is supported by the presence of physical barriers, which limits fee evasion, facilitates prompt payment and enables revenue stability. Our business benefits from a portfolio of parking facilities and parking spaces which is highly diversified in terms of number of contracts, type of contract, number of municipality clients, number of private landlords and types of parking services we deliver. We operate across seven countries in Western Europe which have attractive and mature parking market dynamics at the inflection point for growth through digitization and electrification. As of March 31, 2024, we had a total of 380,701 parking spaces in The Netherlands, 131,957 parking spaces in France, 46,124 parking spaces in the United Kingdom, 82,672 parking spaces in Germany, 181,916 parking spaces in Denmark, 55,824 parking spaces in Belgium and 16,993 parking spaces in Ireland. Below is a chart that presents the breakdown of our Underlying Total Revenue by country for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. 124 -----

Subsection Title: Strengths
Subsubsection Text: We believe that we have several competitive advantages in the car park sector in Western Europe, including our local market leadership positions, high quality real estate portfolio, long-term cash flow visibility, resilient and diversified business profile, strong asset locations and a scalable platform with tangible growth opportunities across our core parking business, digitalization, EV charging and mobility solutions. As a result of these strengths, together with the key infrastructure features that underpin our business model and the continuing regulatory shift in favor of off-street parking, our business benefits from a high level of stable and recurring cash flows.

Subsection Title: Underlying Revenue per country
Subsubsection Title: Robust and Stable Financial Profile with Long Term Historical Track Record and Predictable Cash Flows Underpinned by Real Asset Ownership and Long-Term Contracts
Subsubsection Text: For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, 89.6% of our Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs) was generated by our long-term business. We benefit from long-term visibility of cash flows, and the correlation of parking demand to the total size of the car fleet (rather than GDP) enhances the stability of our revenues over long periods and helps ensure resilience through periods of economic downturn. We have demonstrated consistent revenue growth over the past 25 years (other than during the period impacted by COVID-19), with a strong recovery following the impact of COVID-19. Although our business was negatively impacted during 2020 and 2021 as a result of mobility restrictions put in place in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, our Underlying Total Revenue has recovered to above 2019 levels, and for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, has grown at a CAGR of 4.2% since 2017. The decrease in our Underlying Total Revenue in 2020 and marginal increase in 2021 was primarily driven by increased volatility in Underlying Short-Term Parking Revenue, which dropped immediately in response to COVID-19 restrictions, while Underlying LongTerm Parking Revenue remained relatively stable over the period. Our performance has consistently improved independent from economic cycles, with an average Underlying Likefor-Like Parking Revenue Growth Rate of 4.5% over the period from January 1, 2014 through March 31, 2024, compared to a real gross domestic product (“GDP”) average growth rate of 1.8% and consumer price index (“CPI”) annual inflation of 2.1% during the same period.

Subsection Title: Underlying Revenue per country
Subsubsection Text: Within these countries, our portfolio is spread across approximately 352 cities with no significant exposure to one city. Our top city (Amsterdam, with 31 parking facilities as of March 31, 2024) represented approximately 11% of our Underlying Total Revenue with our top 20 cities representing approximately 54% of our Underlying Total Revenue for the three months ended March 31, 2024. Across these cities, we operate a tailored approach with the type of contract tailored to the country of operations. Our business primarily comprises (i) legally owned properties, (ii) long-term leases, (iii) concessions, (iv) ground leases, (v) protected leases and (vi) short-term leases. As such, we have a portfolio consisting of both parking facilities owned and operated by us as well as those operated by us under contracts (both long-term and short-term), as well as ancillary services such as our control fee business. As of March 31, 2024, our long-term business portfolio included 64 legally owned facilities, 66 ground lease facilities and five protected lease facilities, 187 concession facilities and 402 long-term lease facilities, which together comprised over 320,000 parking spaces and accounted for approximately 89.6% of our Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs) for the three months ended March 31, 2024. As of March 31, 2024, our short-term business comprised 3,591 facilities and over 576,000 parking spaces and accounted for approximately 10.4% of our Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs) for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. Our parking business is also diversified in terms of location (inner city centers, hospitals, shopping areas and transport links). We believe our limited reliance on any single parking facility is a significant factor in diversifying our source of revenues and therefore reduces our cash flow volatility. Our parking facilities are typically not dedicated to a single institution or purpose and are mostly multi-functional, meaning they are used by drivers that may be using the car park to visit different locations, whether it is for work, shopping, cultural activities, or other purposes. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, 70% of our Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs) was generated by multi-functional facilities. We believe that we enjoy a prime position in the relevant local area with respect to a significant proportion of our parking facilities. Our prime locations, the multi-functionality of our car parks and the challenges in building new car parks help mitigate competition risk in our business. Further, our multi-functional car parking facilities also have alternative uses and can potentially be a source of ancillary revenues (for example, as storage facilities or refrigeration for restaurants, car rental, car sharing, bike parking, or as a last mile delivery hub). The remaining 30% of our Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs) for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024 was generated by mono-functional facilities, which are selected on a strategic basis with the aim of ensuring stability of demand. We generally target regional and/or national partnerships (for example, operating Park + Ride solutions for the Dutch railways (NS)) with municipalities and local authorities and/or transport hubs. Our parking business is also diversified in terms of our end users. We process over 100 million transactions annually across both short-term and long-term parking. This gives us access and exposure to and insight into the behavior of a highly diversified customer base. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our short-term parking business represented 66.1% of our Underlying Total Revenue from more than 81.5 million transactions. Our typical short-term parking customer pays for transactions on a per-hour or per-day basis and typically stays at our facilities for an average of two to four hours per transaction. These customers are largely occasion-driven with predominantly low recurrence. On the other hand, for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our long 125 ----- term parking business represented 21.4% of our Underlying Total Revenue from more than 20.5 million individual single-stay transactions. Our typical long-term parking customer pays for the transaction in advance, usually with the purchase of a monthly, quarterly, half-yearly or annual season ticket, and typically stays at our facilities for an average of eight to ten hours per transaction. These customers constitute our known loyal customer base and currently consist of more than 100,000 season ticket holders. The remaining 12.5% of our Underlying Total Revenue in the twelve months ended March 31, 2024 consists of management fees, control fees, rental income, EV charging fees and other income. We believe our diversified business portfolio differentiates us from other infrastructure companies, who typically rely on a smaller number of large contracts or concessions, or strong concentrations in a single geography, resulting in a greater concentration of risk.

Subsection Title: Underlying Like-for-Like Parking Revenue Growth Rate, compared to real GDP and CPI growth
Subsubsection Text: Note: GDP and CPI for geographies Belgium, Denmark, France, Germany, Ireland, The Netherlands and United Kingdom. 1 Based on Euromonitor data. Country metrics are weighted by share of Underlying Total Revenue for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. 2 Based on percentage change from period to period in the Underlying Parking Revenues generated from parking facilities categorized as LFL operations. We define Underyling Like-for-Like Parking Revenue Growth Rate as the as the percentage change from period to period in the Underlying Parking Revenues generated from parking facilities that we categorize as LFL operations. A parking facility is included in LFL operations: (a) until 2019, if it has an initial duration of five years or more and has operated for at least two full financial years, measured as of the beginning of the current financial year, and (ii) from and including 2020, if it has an initial duration of five years or more and has operated during the full reporting period from 2019 until the current reporting period, in each case, excluding any facilities which are due to expire in the current reporting period, facilities that are newly opened in the current reporting period and certain facilities that are not fully operational (for example, due to refurbishment). Given the foregoing, the number any identity of parking facilities making up our LFL operations up to and including the year ended December 31, 2019 is different from the number and identity of parking facilities making up our LFL operations from the year ended December 31, 2020 onward, so the periods are not fully comparable. Following COVID-19, volumes have recovered rapidly, and our total volume has been above 2019 levels since April 2023, despite price increases. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our Underlying EBITDA was approximately 8% higher than pre-COVID-19 Underlying EBITDA for the year ended December 31, 2019. The seasonality of our Underlying Total Revenue as of March 31, 2024 is also now consistent with pre-COVID-19 seasonality. See “—Parking Revenues.” 126 ----- Our cash flow generation benefits from an advantageous working capital cycle through the collection of upfront payments (through season tickets) from our long-term parking customers and revenue collection directly upon exit of the car park for our short-term parking customers. As a result of our low Underlying Existing Business Capex and Underlying ICT & Other Capex requirements, we have achieved Underlying FCF Cash Conversion Ratio of 73.7% and Underlying EBITDA Margin of 27.6% for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. We believe that our infrastructure portfolio is well invested. Our portfolio comprises a mix of legally owned assets, protected leases, ground leases, long-term leases, concessions, other short-term leases and other contracts (including management contracts, rental contracts and contracts in relation to our EV charging business). Below is a chart that presents the breakdown of our Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs) by contract type for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024.

Subsection Title: Pricing increases in line with / ahead of inflation Short-term Parking Portfolio by Pricing Dynamics (based on Underlying Gross Margin)
Subsubsection Text: 128 ----- 1 Refers to facilities where we have the sole decision-making authority to change prices. 2 Refers to facilities with limited restrictions on our ability to change prices (such as mandated caps to price increases or requirements to obtain landlord or municipality consent to price increases). 3 Refers to facilities where price increases are stipulated by a specific index (usually on an annual basis). Despite these price increases, our volumes (measured by sold hours in respect of our PMS Connected facilities) have continued to recover in 2023 and 2024 with our LFL short term parking volumes (measured by sold hours in respect of our PMS Connected facilities) surpassing pre-COVID-19 levels in the second quarter of 2023 and the positive trend continuing into the third quarter of 2023. Our season ticket volumes were fairly stable throughout the COVID-19 pandemic, with the lowest point in the period, from January 2020 to September 2022, being approximately 6% below January 2020, which was immediately prior to the impact of COVID-19. Following the easing of lockdowns, our season ticket volumes have recovered to pre-COVID-19 levels. This reflects the price inelastic nature of our volume demand, as illustrated by the charts below.

Subsection Title: Short-term Parking LfL volumes above 2019 levels since Q2 2023 Long-term Parking volumes fairly stable through COVID-19 in comparison to the year ended December 31, 2019
Subsubsection Title: Strong and Focused Management Team with Track Record of Strategy Execution and Actionable Sustainability Commitments
Subsubsection Text: Our senior management team has significant experience and understanding of the car park sector. Our senior management team has consistently outperformed budget targets and has a strong track record of strategy execution, which can also be attributed to the senior management team’s ability to anticipate and embrace new trends and technology in the car park sector. This has enabled us to be a pioneer in the deployment of efficient transformational programs, revenue management and digitalization programs, user friendly applications, such as PaSS, and sustainability initiatives, such as our EV Charging Program. Our senior management team has also shown its capability in successful portfolio management with the constant delivery of new contracts and active acquisition activity, with 68 signed deals (seven acquisitions and 61 asset deals) since 2021. In addition, our local management teams are well-connected to industry bodies and groups as well as local municipalities and maintain strong and long-standing local relationships with the relevant regulatory authorities in the jurisdictions in which we operate, and our regional management teams also have extensive sector experience. Our regional teams comprise senior people having local presence, some of whom also hold prestigious positions with local municipalities and regulatory authorities. We believe that our parking facilities are an essential part of the urban mobility infrastructure and thus part of our contribution to the transition to zero-emission mobility. We have been contributing to sustainable mobility for many years, and have been reporting annually on sustainability, based on the GRI Standards, since 2011. While our early sustainability efforts were focused on raising awareness and integrating sustainable development in our day-to-day business, since 2017 we have shifted our focus to developing and implementing shared solutions, including through identifying how we can contribute to achieving the UN Sustainable Development Goals and our role in helping society progress toward Europe’s aim to be climate neutral by 2050. Our sustainability commitments are focused on key areas that have been identified as most relevant to our stakeholders, including sustainable mobility, digitization, electrification, energy consumption and liveability. Promoting sustainable mobility is central to our efforts, and we believe that our focus on off-street parking supports this goal in a number of ways. 225 of our parking facilities were located near public transport hubs as of December 31, 2023, an increase of 2.3% since December 31, 2022, enabling our customers to take advantage of alternative lower-emission forms of transport. As of December 31, 2023, 506 of our parking facilities offered online pre-booking, which reduces the amount of traffic caused by motorists circling city streets searching for a place to park. The increase in the availability of pre-booking solutions has been driven by our focus on digitization, primarily through PaSS, which has also enabled us to process customer information more efficiently and improved our informed decision-making capabilities.. In line with the increasing penetration of EVs in Europe, we have also significantly increased the number of EV charging points in our parking facilities, from 2,114 as of December 31, 2021 to 4,114 charging points as of December 31, 2023. In addition to supporting the shift to more sustainable mobility in the communities in which we operate, we have also improved our own performance on ESG metrics, particularly with respect to energy consumption and our overall carbon footprint. As of December 31, 2023 the total energy consumed in our parking facilities has decreased by 12.7% since the year ended December 31, 2021. Our efforts to reduce our energy consumption and to source more green energy has led to a decrease in our average carbon footprint per parking space in owned and long-leased parking facilities from 179.1 kg of CO2 in the year ended December 31, 2010 to 45.4 kg of CO2 as of December 31, 2023, a decrease of 74.6%. We believe that these efforts have contributed significantly to our goal of enhancing urban liveability and helping society move toward zeroemission mobility.

Subsection Title: Short-term Parking LfL volumes above 2019 levels since Q2 2023 Long-term Parking volumes fairly stable through COVID-19 in comparison to the year ended December 31, 2019
Subsubsection Text: Our economies of scale also enable us to be a consolidation platform and we have successfully continued to expand our portfolio inorganically, including during the COVID-19 pandemic, through a prudent and returndriven decision-making process across acquisitions, contract wins and contract renewals. From January 1, 2021 129 ----- to March 31, 2024, we signed a total of 61 asset deals for parking facilities for new business including for the operation of facilities) consisting of 38 new operating contracts for parking facilities and 23 negotiated contract renewals for parking facilities, as well as seven bolt-on acquisitions of parking facilities at our legally owned properties and under long-term leases and concessions, contributing approximately €40.3 million in “run-rate” EBITDA for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, which represents the EBITDA generated from all new contracts signed during the relevant period, assuming that each new contract is being performed at its full maturity potential assessed by us at the time of signing of such contract on the basis that (i) all parking spaces under each contract will be made available during the relevant period, (ii) all revenue generating functions of our business have been realized and (iii) the customary ramp-up period has passed. The 61 new asset deals and seven bolt-on acquisitions have an average contract duration of approximately 18 years and have an average period to recover the costs from the “run-rate” EBITDA of such assets of approximately five years. Since January 1, 2023, we completed four key transactions (“Recent Transactions”): - the Britannia Acquisition, pursuant to which Q-Park UK Limited acquired 100% of the issued share capital of Britannia Parking Group Limited, a parking operator in the United Kingdom, which was completed on June 4, 2024 and was funded using cash on balance sheet; - the Amsterdam City Tender, relating to the public tender by the City of Amsterdam that was awarded to Q-Park Operations Netherlands B.V. on August 14, 2023 pursuant to which Q-Park Operations Netherlands B.V. provides on-street parking services for approximately 160,000 parking spaces and will provide on-street parking services for up to 262,000 parking spaces in Amsterdam, The Netherlands, and related services such as transactions, enforcement, permits and parking meters, for a period of eight years commencing January 1, 2024; - the Denmark Acquisition, pursuant to which Q-Park Operations Denmark A/S acquired City Parkeringsservice A/S, a Danish parking operator and control fee business in Denmark, completed on October 4, 2023; and - the Tazbell Acquisition, pursuant to which Q-Park Ireland Ltd. acquired 100% of the issued share capital of Tazbell Services Group DAC, parent company of the Irish parking operator, Park Rite, completed on August 31, 2023. We estimate that these Recent Transactions collectively would contribute approximately €10.3 million to our Pro _Forma Underlying EBITDA for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024._ Alongside our portfolio expansion, we have invested in the growth of our digital parking ecosystem, PaSS (Parking as a Smart Service), which allows us to offer increased convenience and certainty and a seamless customer experience. As of December 31, 2023, 75% of our parking facilities were PaSS-enabled (excluding management contracts and stalling garages) and 9% of LFL operations were processed through PaSS. PaSS provides us with the opportunity to differentiate online and offline parking tariffs, supporting product diversification and optimization of capacity. Across our digital platform, we focus on pre-booking revenues in event-driven areas with high and stable demand (such as airports, hotels, cruise terminals and event centers) and revenues from repeat short-term parking customers who increasingly value a seamless customer experience. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our digital revenues (calculated as revenues from (i) customers prebooking through our services as well as third party services, (ii) the Q-Park App and (iii) customers pre-booking parking at our airport facilities in the UK and Germany) were €83 million. Our digital revenues increased by 55% for the year ended December 31, 2023 compared to the year ended December 31, 2022 and by 40% for the three months ended March 31, 2024 compared to the three months ended March 31, 2023. We have also invested in expanding our business lines to take advantage of recent trends in the parking sector in order to generate incremental revenues. A key focus in this area has been the development of our EV Charging Program, which we launched in May 2022 to profitably expand our EV charging business through an increasing number of EV charging points in our owned and long-leased parking facilities in line with the growing demand for a publicly available charging infrastructure in our markets in Western Europe. As of December 31, 2023, we had 4,114 EV charging points across our parking facilities, which we estimate have enabled 63.7 million CO2free kilometers of driving for our customers since June 30, 2022. Adding EV charging points to our existing infrastructure enables us to take advantage of the continued trend toward electrification of the car fleet while requiring a low level of incremental investment and deploying capital at our own pace. As of March 31, 2024, we have invested approximately €12.9 million of capital expenditure in our EV Charging Program since 2022 and have realized a “run-rate” Underlying Gross Margin of approximately €4.7 million for the year ended December 130 ----- 31, 2023. We define “run-rate” Underlying Gross Margin as the annualized run-rate impact of EV charging volumes for the second half of the year ended December 31, 2023 (calculated on the basis of EV charging points installed capacity as of December 31, 2023) on the Underlying Gross Margin from our EV charging business for the year ended December 31, 2023.

Subsection Title: Strategy
Subsubsection Title: Maintain a Focus on our Diversified Portfolio and Profitable Assets in Strategic Locations
Subsubsection Text: We have a diversified portfolio of owned, leased and managed parking facilities, including concessions and contracts, in prime locations. Our infrastructure is well-invested, with a focus on the most attractive segments of the car parking market. We focus on smaller cities to benefit from their growth, and we will continue to seek to enhance profitability through portfolio optimization. We intend to focus our efforts on renewing our portfolio of existing contracts by maintaining our well invested assets to better manage future capital expenditure requirements and expanding our operations by capturing new opportunities that meet our stringent investment criteria. Due to our market leading position, scale and expertise, we believe that we are well positioned to continue to grow our diversified portfolio by renewing our existing contracts and capturing new contracts in value-enhancing locations from both existing customers seeking to award new contracts and from other organizations looking to outsource the operation of their parking facilities. Our selection of facility locations is driven by our long-term strategy to operate and expand in high margin cities. Our highly diversified geographical coverage spans across approximately 352 cities that have attractive market dynamics, with a strategic and tailored approach to different markets in an effort to drive higher returns. We may also acquire high-quality smaller car parks in small- and medium-sized cities to further diversify our portfolio and benefit from the potential for growth in these cities. We believe that our balanced focus on smaller cities reduces our exposure to changing urban trends and regulatory changes in larger cities. Due to our scale, long-standing industry experience and established relationships with municipalities and private landlords, we are typically able to achieve significant synergies that also allow us to offer competitive terms and win new business. We will continue to grow our parking facilities in clusters representing multiple locations in strategic cities, which enhances our pricing strategy through a more resilient local competitive dynamic, operational cost reduction given our ability to have a single task force servicing multiple locations and strong relationships with municipalities. Our ability to build and maintain relationships with municipalities makes us well positioned to negotiate and win long-term contracts and to avoid long-term regulatory risk. We have clusters in key cities including The Hague, Amsterdam, Maastricht, Rotterdam, Toulouse, Chambery, Leeds, Manchester, London, Dublin, Berlin, Dusseldorf, Antwerp, Hasselt and Brussels. In addition, we are often able to expand our locations to further facilities once we have entered a local market by virtue of our existing relationship with local authorities and the ability to benefit from synergies with existing parking facilities. We believe our position as one of the leading owners and operators of parking facilities in Western Europe, combined with our long-standing relationships with a diverse number of local authorities and favorable industry dynamics, will assist us in continuing to implement this strategy.

Subsection Title: Strategy
Subsubsection Title: Continue to Invest in a Differentiated Contract Offering with a Disciplined Investment Approach
Subsubsection Text: We believe that we are one of only a few infrastructure-based parking facilities operators in Europe that can offer the full spectrum of contracts, including ground leases, concessions, protected leases and long-term and shortterm leases. This offers us a high degree of adaptability to the most appropriate type of contract depending on the characteristics of each model and the demand in local markets. As of March 31, 2024, we had a diversified portfolio of 4,315 parking facilities in prime locations supporting stable and high demand, and 89.6% of our Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs) comprised long-term business, with the remaining 10.4% of our Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs) comprising short-term leases and other contracts and costs (including management contracts, rental contracts, contracts in relation to our EV charging business and leases with a duration of less than one year). Our other contracts typically have a fixed fee structure, which provides secured income visibility. This enables us to optimize and balance risk and return on our investment portfolio. Further, because our contract portfolio largely comprises long-term facilities (owned facilities, leased facilities (including long-term leases, ground leases and protected leases) and concessions), our Weighted Average Remaining Duration was approximately 47 years as of March 31, 2024, which provides a long-lasting cash flow profile. We also adopt a disciplined approach with respect to new investments and the expansion of our existing business. Our experienced Investment Committee (“IC”) reviews, appraises and assesses new investments. It reviews and advises on investment proposals from the country management teams with respect to potential new business (including the expansion of our existing business) and applies thorough and consistent criteria and analyses to provide a recommendation to the Executive Board to approve or reject the proposal. We will continue to take a disciplined approach to new investments, with different levels of advice, support and strategic guidance, which we believe will continue to generate robust revenues.

Subsection Title: Strategy
Subsubsection Title: Continue to Pursue Strategic Digital and Pricing Initiatives
Subsubsection Text: 132 ----- We believe we are industry frontrunners in pursuing strategic initiatives driven by digitalization trends. Key features of our technology platform include digital invoicing, Park + Events capabilities, pre-booking for city parking, on-street parking, near-time parking information, Park + Fly capabilities, equipping facilities with PaSS gateways and Park + Charge capabilities enabled by the rollout of our EV Charging Program. This is expected to serve as a basis for long-term operations standardization and digitalization. Such digital capabilities seek to increase control and ownership over data, enable the use of standard interfaces to communicate with our partners and facilitate the integration of potential acquisitions or new sites. Our digital capabilities also allow us to capture customers earlier in their journeys, by facilitating pre-booking of parking spaces via the Q-Park App, and provide opportunities for connections with third parties, such as other mobility providers and end users. Our local scale and digital leadership enable us to manage pricing. We believe that our diversified portfolio and differentiated contract offering provides price flexibility and enables us to select the contracts that best suit our investment portfolio. We are able to use such pricing flexibility as a lever to maintain stability of cash flows and sustain profitability. As demand for parking is relatively inelastic to price, we have been able to successfully pass through more than 100% of the impacts of inflation to our customers since October 2021, with no negative impacts on volume (measured by sold hours in respect of our PMS Connected facilities). Our data-driven pricing methodologies include measures such as differentiated pricing models (adaptation of prices based on demand and locations, such as peak hours, and online price differentiation with pre-booking), flexible pricing depending on frequency and duration, location-based pricing (such as premium pricing in city centers, medium-range pricing in Park + Walk locations and budget pricing in Park + Public Transport locations) and day tariffs optimization (through parking for over six or eight hours in strategic locations). Our advanced analytics leveraged through PaSS has enabled us to process customer information more efficiently and supported more informed decisionmaking, and we intend to continue to expand our analytical capabilities and increase our scale to drive digital leadership and pricing initiatives in the market.

Subsection Title: Strategy
Subsubsection Title: Enabler of Sustainable Livability through Active Participation in Mobility Solutions and Partnerships
Subsubsection Text: We aim to continue to focus on promoting sustainable livability, with a focus on customer satisfaction and convenience, by initiating partnerships across the mobility eco-system. We have introduced several mobility solutions to enhance customer experience. For example, our PaSS initiative is built around a public cloud-based technology platform that allows us to interact with and provide services to our customers and business partners virtually. Integrated payment systems such as PaSS enable us to partner with companies like EasyPark, RingGo and 4411. See “—ICT and Operations.” We work closely with local authorities including in The Netherlands (Maastricht, Rotterdam and Eindhoven) and Belgium (Antwerp) to develop facilities that enable travelers to park their cars or bicycles close to transport hubs so our facilities act as vital links in the mobility chain, connecting travelers with their final destination and acting as public transport transit points. As of December 31, 2023, we had 225 owned and long-leased parking facilities registered at or near major transport hubs, an increase of 2.3% compared to December 31, 2022. We have also introduced Park + Ride and Park + Walk facilities in The Netherlands, which are modern, integral parts of the mobility chain in many towns and cities across The Netherlands and are located in the vicinity of public transport so they are easy to access and find. Furthermore, as of December 31, 2023, we have installed 4,114 EV charging points in our parking facilities, of which 2,996 are revenue-generating. We will continue to seek and explore initiatives to enable urbanization, particularly those which we believe will give us the first mover advantage in the market and sustain our position as drivers of industry change and leadership.

Subsection Title: Strategy
Subsubsection Title: Capture Sustainable Value with Actionable ESG Commitments
Subsubsection Text: Sustainability is a key part of our strategic framework, and we believe that we are well positioned to capture value from the energy transition, particularly with respect to the evolution of the EV market. According to the IEA Global EV Data Explorer published in April 2024, the share of EVs in Europe as a proportion of the overall car fleet is expected to increase from 1.1% in 2020 to 11.1% in 2030, equivalent to approximately 61.2 million EVs. We believe that our established customer base and broad, well-invested existing infrastructure portfolio makes us well-placed to capitalize on the increasing penetration of EVs, as adding EV charging points to our existing infrastructure requires a low level of incremental investment. Approximately 85% to 90% of the EV charging market is destination charging, with a particular focus on residential, workplace and retail charging, and our existing parking facilities already cover approximately 55% to 65% of the catchment area for this destination charging, primarily through proximity to workplaces and retail locations. We have already installed 4,114 EV charging points in our parking facilities as of December 31, 2023, and we plan to have 5,500 EV charging points by the end of 2024. 133 ----- Outside of the scope of EVs, we aim to continue to focus across our business on enhancing urban liveability and connecting communities by providing sustainable mobility solutions and seamless parking services.
