Within a broader framework of key sustainability topics, we have focused on the top five material topics of liveability and the mobility transition, energy, digitization and innovation, renovation and maintenance and climate change mitigation, and we are in the process of developing specific key performance indicators (“KPIs”) and targets around these topics, informed by the EU Green Deal and EU Sustainability Reporting Standards (“ESRS”). We intend to incorporate ESRS references into our CSR report, with the goal of being fully in compliance with the EU Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (the “CSRD”) by 2025, which requires a double materiality threshold for reporting standards. Therefore, in 2023, we have conducted a double materiality analysis and analyzed both our impact on economic, environmental and social matters (i.e., impact materiality) and the financial impact of these matters on our business (i.e., financial materiality). In 2023, we have developed quantitative and realistic KPIs and targets for the top five material topics. Accordingly, the following are the targets that we aim to achieve by 2040 and are linked to our top five material topics: - achieving net zero emission through a market-based approach; - procurement of 100% renewable energy; - operating 20,000 EV charging points; - enabling two billion zero-emission kilometers through our EV Charging Program; - equipping 7.5% of our parking spaces with operated EV charging points; and - ensuring 45% of parking facilities offer alternative modes of transportation. Our aim is to complete our double materiality assessment in 2024. We will continue to leverage our sustainability efforts to date, including with respect to our EV Charging Program and reducing the carbon footprint of our parking facilities, with the goal of being the most preferred sustainable mobility hub partner by 2030.

Subsection Title: Strategy
Subsubsection Text: Our strategies focus on value creation, with the aim of enhancing urban liveability and connecting communities by providing sustainable mobility solutions and seamless parking services and a vision to become the most preferred sustainable mobility hub partner by 2030 in the countries in which we operate. We have a disciplined and conservative approach to investment. We intend to drive sustainable growth and sustained business performance through Underlying Like-for-Like Parking Revenue Growth Rate and portfolio growth, supported by value enhancement and revenue management programs, with a strong focus on sustainable development. Our strategies rely on strong processes and tools (such as data analytics, business development processes and feedback loops), our ICT and our brand. Our key strategies are the following: 131 -----

Subsection Title: Parking Revenues
Subsubsection Text: Our off-street business is our largest business line, representing 91% of our Underlying Total Revenue and 90.2% of Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs) for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. This business line primarily consists of legally owned parking facilities, protected leases, ground leases, long-term leases and concessions with municipalities, private real estate investors and other parties to operate parking facilities. As part of our long-term business, we may be required to invest in the construction of a new parking facility (a “green field” contract) or make an upfront payment for an existing parking facility (a “brown field” contract). As of March 31, 2024, our portfolio included 64 legally owned facilities under which we manage approximately 29,000 parking spaces, 66 ground lease and five protected lease facilities under which we manage approximately 36,000 parking spaces, 187 concession facilities under which we manage approximately 109,000 parking spaces and 402 long-term lease facilities under which we manage approximately 147,000 parking spaces. We have a diversified client base with our 20 largest cities (in terms of Underlying Total Revenue) representing 54% of our Underlying Total Revenue for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. As of March 31, 2024, the Weighted Average Remaining Duration of our long-term contracts was approximately 47 years. Legally owned properties and protected leases run in perpetuity, and ground leases, concessions, and long-term leases are mostly long-term. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, legally owned properties, ground leases, concessions, long-term leases and protected leases had 75.3% (contributing 20.3%), 71.5 (contributing 23.8%), 45.2% (contributing 21.7%), 16.8% (contributing 22.9%) and 25.9% (contributing 0.7%) of our Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs), respectively. During the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, we derived approximately 89.6% of our Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs) from facilities that are owned or operated under our longterm business, of which 83% are due to continue under their existing terms through 2033 (assuming no renewals, new business or price indexation). This ensures long-term visibility of cash flows. For the same period, we derived only 10.4% of our Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs) from leases with an initial tenor of less than 15 years and other contracts. This long-term cash flow profile is backed by a strong asset base offering significant downside protection. Our portfolio comprises parking infrastructure located in urban areas and other areas of high traffic density, such as inner city centers, hospitals, shopping areas and transport links. Our long-term business includes a number of 134 ----- car parks with prime locations. Many of these locations are in highly transited areas that attract a large number of visitors for a variety of purposes. These locations also usually have limited free or paid alternative parking options. Competition is generally limited in the area covering a radius of approximately 700-800 meters around the car park. Except during the COVID-19 pandemic when several lockdowns and other mobility restrictions were in place, demand for our off-street parking facilities in such areas has traditionally experienced relatively low volatility and has remained relatively stable, even during difficult economic conditions. As a result of COVID-19 and the measures taken to prevent a further spread, our business was impacted globally in 2020, 2021 and 2022 by temporary closures and other restrictions on opening hours and capacity of public establishments as a consequence of the guidelines given by the respective governments of the countries where we operate. Although our operating performance declined as a result of lockdown measures and other restrictions in response to COVID-19, we believe we have showed significant post COVID-19 recovery. Car park usage trends have been positive since 2022 as illustrated by our revenues surpassing pre-pandemic levels in December 2022, despite certain measures that have been introduced to reduce emissions in densely populated areas and the number of cars in city centres, such as in Amsterdam. After a slow start in early 2022 due to continued pandemic-related mobility restrictions, recovery in the parking business started when restrictions were lifted. The lifting of COVID19 related restrictions in the different markets in which we operate has led to a strong increase in our revenues and customers and, consequently, our revenues of operation are surpassed pre-pandemic levels. For example, our revenues for the year ended December 31, 2022 represented an increase of 38.5%, as compared to the year ended December 31, 2021. Underlying Parking Revenues saw a forceful rebound to pre-pandemic levels from April 2022 onwards and surpassing pre-pandemic levels for the first time in December 2022. The increase was primarily driven by the rebound of short-term parking revenues which in turn stimulated the strong recovery of our operating results and cash flow generation. Our business has fully recovered post-COVID-19 due to positive volume trends (driven by the lifting of COVID-19-related restrictions on the movement of people and on the opening of public establishments that were closed during the COVID-19 pandemic) and pricing trends, demonstrating the Group’s infrastructure qualities. The seasonality of our Underlying Total Revenue as of March 31, 2024 is also now consistent with pre-COVID-19 seasonality, as demonstrated in the graph below, indicating a reversion to preCOVID-19 mobility patterns. In respect of our owned properties, where we both own and operate the parking facilities, and our properties operated under long-term contracts and concessions, we may on occasion also design, build and finance construction of the facility, including underground and multi-storey parking infrastructure facilities. If we design and build the parking facility, these green field contracts generally require us to invest capital to build a facility or make an upfront payment for an existing facility in exchange for higher potential margins and long-term concession agreements. Under our brown field contracts, we pay an annual lease or concession fee to the private landlord or municipality. Further, under our long-term contracts, we may also work together with investment companies who have earmarked funds to invest in parking facilitates that are operated by us and we then agree a lease contract with such companies. Under our concessions, we charge the end-users a tariff (or fee) for the use of the facility. Further, under our concession agreements in France, we may be required to pay annual concession fees to the municipality (in addition to a one-off upfront concession fee). The fees we charge the end-user are either on a time period basis for short-stay tickets or on a weekly, monthly, seasonal or on an annual basis under a subscription arrangement. The fees paid by end-users are specified under the concession and generally automatically increase annually in 135 ----- line with inflation. We generally retain all fees generated from operating the relevant parking facility. In respect of legally owned parking facilities, we are responsible for all expenses relating to the parking facility. Our offstreet parking facilities are also subject to local taxes, for which we are responsible. We also generate a small amount of income through some basic amenities we provide to car park users within our parking facilities, such as vending machines and car washes. In general, our parking facilities are operated on a 24-hour a day/seven-day a week basis. Most of the features of the parking facilities are automated, including entry and exit controls and ticket machines. Users can obtain information about subscriptions and tariffs online, over the phone and onsite at our parking facilities. The car parks are staffed and operated by our own employees or contracted staff from external service providers. We operate a central control room (“QCR”), a centralized system to control and manage a substantial majority of our parking facilities from a remote location, which allows us to reduce personnel costs by reducing headcount while maintaining our high quality of services and customer satisfaction levels. Such efficiencies have led to significant savings in operating expenses as we reduced the number of operators per car park. In addition, such measures help reduce our reliance on external service providers by enabling us to reallocate personnel to perform certain functions previously performed by third-party service providers. The majority of our contracts are awarded as a result of a public bidding process conducted by the municipalities or private bidding conducted by private third parties. Each municipality has authority to determine the location and economic viability of car parks within its jurisdiction. Due to existing relationships with the municipality, the incumbent concession holder is often well positioned to negotiate an extension of the term of the contract (if permitted under the contract), or to obtain the renewal of the contract by using the information and experience it has developed to bid successfully in the new tender process. In addition to retaining our existing long-term contracts once their initial term has expired, we also seek to obtain new contracts and win contracts previously granted to our competitors. As discussed in “—Strengths” and in “Industry,” Europe represents a large and growing parking market with strong fundamentals, and the European parking sector is expected to grow based on structural drivers. The countries in which we operate have, in the aggregate, historically seen consistent year-on-year growth in light vehicle fleet from approximately 123 million in 2013 to approximately 136 million in 2022, and despite changes to car ownership models, the number of personal cars in the street is expected to continue to grow in the future. The parking sector is a mature market benefitting from favorable pricing dynamics, and the regulatory-driven shift away from on-street parking towards off-street parking for cities is expected to benefit our business. Furthermore, the off-street parking market is highly fragmented with a limited number of large players, with the top three to five companies in each country only accounting for 10% to 35% of the total market share in most countries. As a result, large private companies are well positioned to win contracts. We believe that the parking sector is expected to benefit from key trends in the industry, including, for example, (i) the regulatory shift away from on-street parking with reduced on-street parking provisions in low emission zones and/or in densely populated cities, (ii) increasing priority given to pedestrians, cyclists and various forms of shared mobility (including car sharing and public transport) as cities and municipalities increase their sustainability focus, (iii) change in consumer dynamics to focus more on experiences and (iv) carbon neutrality and “green city” goals of various countries. These trends may provide opportunities, whether in the nearer term or in the longer term, for leading car park companies like us. The long-term nature of contracts, the difficulty in obtaining prime locations and the presence of local monopolies, regulatory requirements, the need for scale, the commercial network and market recognition of existing participants and the technological leadership of the incumbents present significant challenges for new players to successfully break into the European car park market. In response to the key drivers in the parking sector discussed in “Industry,” we continue to grow supported by an underlying increase in the car fleet, our positioning in attractive markets and segments that allows for ongoing tariffs increase, our scale that positions us favorably to win new contracts and execute a strategy of accretive bolt-on acquisitions, our strong positioning in the off-street parking segment, our focus on multifunctional parking facilities and our overall strong position that allows us to benefit from various industry trends. Our local scale provides us with a strong position to profitably capture strategic opportunities in the market. We have a large and differentiated portfolio, giving us vast experience with any operating model and a high degree of flexibility with contract types. We enjoy a strong brand with a long-standing reputation for quality in parking. Our strong local presence gives us access to opportunities with unique local deal flow. Our focus on clustering results in pricing power, economies of scale and local government relations. Our leading position with local scale allows for significant operational benefits, with a proprietary technology platform in place (such as parking mobile applications, pre-booking and season tickets), an in-house car park design team, and a prudent and return-driven decision-making process. 136 ----- Our strong portfolio of value-creating assets in strategic locations limits demand risk. We focus on top-tier locations at European, country and city levels. At the European level, we concentrate on stable Western European countries, with geographical diversification across seven countries, and we especially focus on countries with attractive market dynamics where we can achieve leading (such as top three) positions. In total, we have a highly diversified portfolio across 352 cities in seven countries. Cities where we operate at least three parking facilities contribute approximately 87% to our Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs). At the city level, we enjoy strong local positions and market shares due to dense clusters in key areas, and we focus on multi-functional parking facilities to mitigate demand risk. Our mono-functional facilities predominantly serve a single urban purpose, for example, public transport hubs, such as rail stations and airports, as well as hospitals and other locations with stable demand. With an increasing number of electric vehicles (“EV”) charging points, we also offer our customers the opportunity to charge their electric vehicle while parked. We intend to continue investing in EV charging points to respond to the growing demand for additional inner city EV charging facilities and near public transport hubs. The chart below shows the breakdown of our investment property portfolio by country, as a percentage of the €1.8 billion valuation of the total portfolio (which includes 123 real estate properties (mostly legally owned by us, but including, in some cases, certain ground lease properties)), as of March 31, 2024. Such market value has been prepared without comprehensive due diligence or the benefit of an inspection of all of the properties. 1 Valuation data covering a portfolio of 123 owned real estate properties and ground leases. Our properties have high replacement values, with an ability to convert space for alternative usage. Real estate property space is at a premium, in particular in premium cities where we have a strong presence, so there are opportunities to implement alternative uses for parking facilities, especially for owned assets, which do not require any external approval, and long-term leases. Our ownership of assets impacts our Underlying Existing Business Capex levels, and our average Underlying Existing Business Capex over the three twelve-month periods ended March 31, 2024 has been 5.6% of our Underlying Total Revenue.

Subsection Title: Geographical Split
Subsubsection Text: Based on a third party consultant report, we are the leading parking operator in The Netherlands as of December 31, 2023 based on off-street parking revenue. As of March 31, 2024, we had 478 parking facilities and 380,701 parking spaces. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our Underlying Total Revenue in The Netherlands was €294.4 million and Underlying EBITDA was €101.1 million. Our key clusters are in Amsterdam, The Hague, Maastricht, Rotterdam and Eindhoven, which accounted for €86.5 million (29.3% of total), €35.2 million (11.9% of total), €23.2 million (7.8% of total), €25.7 million (8.7% of total) and €19.4 million (6.6% of total), respectively, 137 ----- of our Underlying Total Revenue in The Netherlands for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. Amsterdam, The Hague, Maastricht, Rotterdam and Eindhoven accounted for €32.5 million (28.8% of total), €19.9 million (17.7% of total), €15.5 million (13.7% of total), €6.5 million (5.8% of total) and €10.7 million (9.5% of total), respectively, of our Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs) in The Netherlands for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. As of March 31, 2024, we had 31, 123, 21, 16 and 8 parking facilities in Amsterdam, The Hague, Maastricht, Rotterdam and Eindhoven, respectively. As of March 31, 2024, we added approximately 160,000 additional parking spaces in Amsterdam pursuant to the Amsterdam City Tender. The value of our property in The Netherlands as of March 31, 2024 was €1,074 million. Such market value has been prepared without comprehensive due diligence or the benefit of an inspection of all of the properties. In The Netherlands, we mostly have full control and flexibility on pricing, which makes yield pricing attractive for car parks. Regulation is typically at the level of municipalities. In The Hague, Eindhoven and Maastricht, we have entered into long-term public/private partnerships, including pricing arrangements, with the municipal governments. Municipalities aim to remove resident cars from the street to make the cities more attractive, by reducing on-street parking spaces and steeply increasing on-street parking tariffs. Large clusters in The Netherlands improve operational efficiency through greater scale, but also increase pricing power. Our market leadership in certain high-value office areas ensures strong pricing power.

Subsection Title: Geographical Split
Subsubsection Text: We provide below a summary of our operations for each of the seven countries in which we operate.

Subsection Title: France
Subsubsection Text: Based on a third party consultant report, we are the second or third leading parking operator in the United Kingdom as of December 31, 2023 based on off-street parking revenue. As of March 31, 2024, we had 77 parking facilities and 46,124 parking spaces. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our Underlying Total Revenue in the United Kingdom was €131.5 million and Underlying EBITDA was €15.6 million. Our key clusters are in London, Liverpool, Crawley, Manchester and Birmingham, which accounted for €33.5 million (25.4% of total), €17.1 million (13.0% of total), €8.4 million (6.4 % of total), €10.6 million (8.1% of total), €16.7 million (12.7% of total), respectively, of our Underlying Total Revenue in the United Kingdom for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. London, Liverpool, Crawley, Manchester and Birmingham accounted for €5.0 million (26.1% of total), €0.9 million (5.0% of total), €3.5 million (18.4% of total), €3.1 million (16.6% of total), €2.8 million (14.5% of total), respectively, of our Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs) in the United Kingdom for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. As of March 31, 2024, we had 22, 6, 1,,7 and 7 parking facilities in London, Liverpool, Crawley, Manchester and Birmingham, respectively. Following the sale and leaseback of certain of our properties in the second half of 2019, we are asset light in the United Kingdom. As a result, we did not own any property in the United Kingdom as of March 31, 2024. Pursuant to the Britannia 138 ----- Acquisition completed on June 4, 2024, we acquired 629 car parks ranging from multi-storey parking facilities to conventional pay and display parking and added 62,000 parking spaces to our portfolio. In the United Kingdom, we mostly have full control and flexibility on pricing. There are typically no restrictions from municipalities as landlords, and no restrictions on tariffs at leased sites in city centers. In particular, we are able to control tariffs at the facilities we operate through long-term leases. As such, we were able to change entry time tariffs across several sites in the United Kingdom in 2019. Tariffs at hospital parking facilities generally increase annually in line with the retail price index, as contracted, while parking tariffs at Gatwick and Heathrow airports are market-driven and change dynamically throughout the day.

Subsection Title: France
Subsubsection Text: Based on a third party consultant report, we are the third leading parking operator in Germany as of December 31, 2023 based on off-street parking revenue. As of March 31, 2024, we had 124 parking facilities and 82,672 parking spaces. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our Underlying Total Revenue in Germany was €100.6 million and Underlying EBITDA was €19.1 million. Our key clusters are in Saarbrücken, Berlin, Düsseldorf, Hamburg and Leipzig, which accounted for €9.4 million (9.3% of total), €10.1 million (10.0% of total), €10.8 million (10.7% of total), €7.2 million (7.2% of total) and €8.1 million (8.1% of total), respectively, of our Underlying Total Revenue in Germany for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. Saarbrücken, Berlin, Düsseldorf, Hamburg and Leipzig accounted for €3.7 million (15.4% of total), €3.1 million (12.9% of total), €3.3 million (14.0% of total), €0.9 million (4.0% of total) and €3.2 million (13.6% of total), respectively, of our Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs) in Germany for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. As of March 31, 2024, we had 13, 9, 13, 2 and 5 parking facilities in Saarbrücken, Berlin, Düsseldorf, Hamburg and Leipzig, respectively. The value of our property in Germany as of March 31, 2024 was €149 million. Such market value has been prepared without comprehensive due diligence or the benefit of an inspection of all of the properties. In Germany, we have control and flexibility on pricing within certain conditions, and in some cases, landlord consent may be required. Regulation is typically at the level of municipalities. The occupancy rate of our parking facilities is also affected by other external factors, including urban development measures. City councils have been discussing initiatives, such as the reduction of on-street parking volume, re-allocation of driving lanes and on-street parking spaces to bicycle lanes, and additional spaces for parks or trees and leisure activities, to reduce traffic in cities. On-street parking is being reduced while new developments are built with limited parking spaces, thereby favoring off-street parking. Tariffs for on-street parking and resident passes have been or will be increased in certain municipalities (for example, tariffs in both Cologne and Frankfurt increased from €3 to €4 per hour), and other cities may follow suit in the future. Adoption of differentiated pricing models by municipalities is also expected to generate additional revenue for parking operators in the future. Moreover, high fines for violation of on-street parking restrictions, which most recently increased in Germany in November 2021 and range between €10 and €110 depending on the type and severity of the relevant violation, may also have a positive effect on the occupancy rate of our off-street parking facilities.

Subsection Title: France
Subsubsection Text: Based on a third party consultant report, we are the second or third leading parking operator in Belgium as of December 31, 2023 based on off-street parking revenue. As of March 31, 2024, we had 63 parking facilities and 55,824 parking spaces. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our Underlying Total Revenue in Belgium was €49.3 million and Underlying EBITDA was €22.7 million. Our key clusters are in Brussels, Hasselt, Antwerp, Tournai and Mechelen, which accounted for €13.0 million (26.5% of total), €7.0 million (14.1% of total), €13.1 million (26.5% of total), €2.4 million (4.8% of total) and €2.4 million (4.8% of total), respectively, of our Underlying Total Revenue in Belgium for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. Brussels, Hasselt, Antwerp, Tournai and Mechelen accounted for €7/3 million (28.8% of total), €5.3 million (20.7% of total), €7.1 million (27.8% of total), €0.3 million (1.0% of total) and €1.9 million (7.3% of total), respectively, of our Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs) in Belgium for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. As of March 31, 2024, we had 9, 4, 14, 2 and 2 parking facilities in Brussels, Hasselt, Antwerp, Tournai and Mechelen, respectively. The value of our property in Belgium as of March 31, 2024 was €249 million. Such market value has been prepared without comprehensive due diligence or the benefit of an inspection of all of the properties. In Belgium, we mostly have full control and flexibility on pricing at owned facilities. Ground lease and concession agreements generally stipulate that consent is required from the municipality with respect to pricing. For Belgium, reduction of on-street parking spaces has been a trend in certain Belgian cities. In the Brussels region, for example, 139 ----- the city government announced a targeted reduction of on-street parking spaces of 16% between 2013 and 2018. In addition, on-street tariffs were increased as of January 1, 2020 by approximately 25% in Antwerp. The installation of spaces for and other bicycle infrastructure in new and existing parking facilities represents an opportunity to generate additional revenue.

Subsection Title: France
Subsubsection Text: Based on a third party consultant report, we are the second leading parking operator in Denmark as of December 31, 2023 based on off-street parking revenue. As of March 31, 2024, we had 3,267 parking facilities and 181,916 parking spaces. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our Underlying Total Revenue in Denmark was €63.7 million and Underlying EBITDA was €11.9 million. Our key clusters are in Copenhagen, Søborg, Aalborg, Aarhus and Odense which accounted for €20.6 million (32.4% of total), €4.1 million (6.5% of total), €4.9 million (7.7% of total), €9.3 million (14.6% of total) and €6.9 million (10.8% of total), respectively, of our Underlying Total Revenue in Denmark for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. Copenhagen, Søborg, Aalborg, Aarhus and Odense accounted for €9.6 million (35.4% of total), €0.1 million (0.4% of total), €1.8 million (6.7% of total), €2.6 million (9.5% of total) and €2.2 million (8.3% of total), respectively, of our Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs) in Denmark for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. As of March 31, 2024, we had 344, 28, 214, 366 and 238 parking facilities in Copenhagen, Søborg, Aalborg, Aarhus and Odense, respectively. The value of our property in Denmark as of March 31, 2024 was €119 million. Such market value has been prepared without comprehensive due diligence or the benefit of an inspection of all of the properties. In Denmark, we have control and flexibility on pricing within certain conditions, and in some cases, landlord consent may be required. Regulation is typically at the level of municipalities. Further, in Denmark, we also issue control fees. Control fees represent income arising from enforcement of paid parking (for example, parking fines) in parking facilities owned and/or operated by us. Where we operate the facility on behalf of a third party, we agree to try to eliminate or reduce misuse of the parking facilities by putting up signs at the parking facility to guide drivers, patrolling the facility and by issuing control fees if the parking rules are violated. Our Underlying Control Fees represented 3.0% of our Underlying Total Revenue for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. Currently, there are no regulatory limits on the prices that we can charge for control fees in the private sector in Denmark. The total control fees revenues in Denmark in the twelve months ended March 31, 2024 was €21.6 million.

Subsection Title: France
Subsubsection Text: Based on a third party consultant report, we are the second or third leading parking operator in Ireland as of December 31, 2023 based on off-street parking revenue. As of March 31, 2024, we had 44 parking facilities and 16,993 parking spaces. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our Underlying Total Revenue in Ireland was €37.1 million and Underlying EBITDA was €9.1 million. Our key clusters are in Dublin, Cork, Galway, Limerick and Sligo, which accounted for €21.1 million (56.9% of total), €5.7 million (15.4% of total), €2.6 million (7.0% of total), €2.1 million (5.7% of total) and €0.0 million (0.2% of total), respectively, of our Underlying Total Revenue in Ireland for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. Dublin, Cork, Galway, Limerick and Sligo accounted for €4.7 million (39.7% of total), €2.5 million (22.3% of total), €1.8 million (16.5% of total), €1.3 million (11.5% of total) and €0.0 million (0.4% of total), respectively, of our Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs) in Ireland for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. As of March 31, 2024, we had 17, 4, 3, 2 and 1 parking facilities in Dublin, Cork, Galway, Limerick and Sligo respectively. The value of our property in Ireland as of March 31, 2024 was €78 million. Such market value has been prepared without comprehensive due diligence or the benefit of an inspection of all of the properties. In Ireland, we mostly have full control and flexibility on pricing. Regulation is typically at the level of municipalities.

Subsection Title: France
Subsubsection Text: Based on a third party consultant report, we are the third leading parking operator in France as of December 31, 2023 based on off-street parking revenue. As of March 31, 2024, we had 262 parking facilities and 131,957 parking spaces. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our Underlying Total Revenue in France was €175.8 million and Underlying EBITDA was €71.8 million. Our key clusters are in Paris La Défense, Marseille, Paris (excluding Paris La Défense), Lyon and Toulon, which accounted for €40.2 million (22.8% of total), €18.0 million (10.3% of total), €11.4 million (6.5% of total), €7.7 million (4.4% of total) and €12.1 million (6.9% of total), respectively, of our Underlying Total Revenue in France for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. Paris La Défense, Marseille, Paris (excluding Paris La Défense), Lyon and Toulon accounted for €6.5 million (7.9% of total), €7.3 million (8.8% of total), €5.7 million (6.8% of total), €5.2 million (6.2% of total) and €4.2 million (5.1% of total), respectively, of our Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs) in France for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. As of March 31, 2024, we had 11, 17, 13, 6 and 11 parking facilities in Paris La Défense, Marseille, Paris, Lyon and Toulon, respectively. As of March 31, 2024, five out of 17 parking facilities in Marseille were operated pursuant to the Marseille Concession Agreement, which was terminated on June 2, 2024 in accordance with its terms. The value of our property in France as of March 31, 2024 was €132 million. Such market value has been prepared without comprehensive due diligence or the benefit of an inspection of all of the properties. In France, pricing is mostly based on contractual indexation for concessions, and the concession agreements are protected, with renegotiation clauses in case of lower performance. In the last twelve months ended March 31, 2024, we had full freedom of tariff for 15% of our short-term parking revenues in France. The general trend in France has been to reduce the number of on-street parking spaces in medium-sized and large cities to enlarge pedestrian areas, and this favors off-street parking.

Subsection Title: Non-Parking Revenues
Subsubsection Text: Control fees represent income arising from enforcement of paid parking (for example, parking fines) in parking facilities owned and/or operated by us, as well as on behalf of third-party landlords. Our Underlying Control Fees represented 3.0% of our Underlying Total Revenue for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. This business is mainly operated in Denmark. As we control the parking area on behalf of the landlords, control fees are issued 140 ----- by us in our name and payment instructions are given to third parties for payments to be made to our bank account. If there is a revenue share arrangement, the landlord receives its share of the paid control fees on a monthly basis. If the control fee is not paid, a dunning cycle is started and eventually passed on to an external collection agency for legal action. See “—Geographical Split—Denmark.”

Subsection Title: Non-Parking Revenues
Subsubsection Text: This business line represents the fixed and variable fees we receive for operating parking facilities for third parties. Our Underlying Management Fees represented 5.6% of our Underlying Total Revenue for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. A majority of our management fees are generated in The Netherlands, France and the United Kingdom. As of March 31, 2024, we managed 558,782 parking spaces in those jurisdictions (across 478 parking facilities in The Netherlands, 262 in France and 77 in the United Kingdom). For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, Underlying Management Fees in these jurisdictions was €36.2 million, representing 47.4% of our total Underlying Management Fees. We have also acquired certain management contracts as a result of certain acquisitions in the past. Our management contracts generally range from one to five years. Our management contracts generally generate lower Underlying EBITDA Margins compared to our long-term contracts and concessions. However, these contracts require minimal investment and are subject to low demand risk. Under our management contracts, we operate parking facilities for both public and private clients in exchange for a fixed fee, which is generally inflation-indexed. In some limited cases, the contracts also include a variable incentive fee element based on the amount of revenue generated and certain other quality indicators. Thus, we are not required to make an up-front payment to manage the facilities or to make significant investments in the parking infrastructure. We typically operate the parking facility with our own employees. We also utilize the expertise and technology from our own parking operations in the management of these contracts and sometimes we also benefit from operating them in our existing city clusters where we can share personnel and have lower monitoring and running costs.

Subsection Title: Non-Parking Revenues
Subsubsection Text: In addition to owning, operating and managing parking spaces, we lease certain parking facilities owned by us to third parties. This business line also represents income from renting specific areas in parking facilities to third parties, including to third-party professional storage companies to be used as storage facilities. As of March 31, 2024, we had two rental contracts with the municipality of Amsterdam (who are the operators of these facilities) which represented approximately 43% of our Underlying Rental Income. The remainder of our Underlying Rental Income is spread across a variety of parking facilities and typically involves income from renting specific areas in a facility. Our Underlying Rental Income amounted to approximately €15.5 million, representing 1.8% of our Underlying Total Revenue for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024.

Subsection Title: Non-Parking Revenues
Subsubsection Text: With many car parks at strategic urban locations, we play a key role in facilitating EV charging for our customers. The rising penetration of EVs and plug-in hybrid electric vehicles in car fleets is increasing demand for charging infrastructures. We launched the EV Charging Program in 2022 to substantially increase the number of EV charging points in our parking facilities. Early in 2022, we signed agreements with charge point operators for EV charging in our parking facilities across Europe. The partnerships are designed to ensure ownership, continuous deployment, professional day-to-day management and performance of the EV charging points. Our asset-heavy business model (whereby we own the charging point infrastructure, set the prices and receive all revenues while the charging point operators install, operate and maintain the charging points for a fee) enables control on EV charging tariffs, through which we are able to report stable margins and continuously grow our business performance. Furthermore, our EV Charging Program contributes substantially to the achievement of our ESG objectives and sustainable mobility. As of December 31, 2023, we have provided more than 12,500 MWh through our EV charging points which we believe have enabled more than 63.7 million zero-emission kilometers on European roads through our EV Charging Program since its launch in May 2022. We have continuously supported our EV Charging Program as EVs are becoming more popular. Our strategy to gradually deploy charging points in line with EV fleet penetration curves has led to deploying almost 1,644 charging points in 2022 despite the continuing shortages of labor and equipment in the installation sector. In 2023, we have expedited the roll out regarding our EV Charging Program and deployed a total of 1,352 charging points. As of December 31, 2023, our parking facilities offer 2,996 EV charging points that are owned by us. Additionally, 141 ----- some of our EV charging points are owned by landlords or season ticket holders and, although our customers benefit from the availability of these EV charging points, they do not generate any additional revenues for us. Including these third-party-owned charging points, there were 4,114 EV charging points available in our parking facilities as of December 31, 2023. Our strategy of “Park + Charge” enables growth of both charging and parking revenues. We aim to significantly increase the number of EV charging points in our portfolio in the coming years in preparation for the EV fleet inflection point towards 2030. Our EV charging points across seven countries generated revenues amounted to approximately €6.5 million, representing approximately 0.8% of our Underlying Total Revenue for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024.

Subsection Title: Regulation
Subsubsection Text: Other than as described below, there are generally no specific regulations that apply to our operations as a car parking infrastructure owner and operator and, except with respect to certain of our contracts, our operations are not generally subject to the rules, regulations or licensing requirements that apply to contracts granted by municipalities and local government authorities. This is due to the fact that a substantial proportion of our operations and facilities relate to privately held properties that are subject to private contracts with third-party counterparts. Such contracts are not subject to the rules and regulations that tend to apply to properties owned by municipalities and other government bodies, which may be subject to public tendering processes and contract terms are based on specific regulations. Although there are no specific car park-related licenses, some local authorities require us to possess and abide by safety licenses. In The Netherlands, there are no national administrative regulations that specifically focus on the operation of parking garages. There are however general rules governing environment and safety, which could lead to a notification obligation and the obligation to comply with these general provisions when operating a parking garage. Other rules could include potential obligations with regard to EV charging points or other requirements applicable to EVs. Finally, depending on the exact location of the parking garage, specific municipality rules may also apply. In France, we predominantly operate under a concession model usually granted by public authorities following a public tender process in accordance with the French Public Procurement Code (Code de la commande publique). Concession agreements for parking facilities usually take the form of public service delegation agreements (contrats de délégation de service public) entered into with public authorities and which are governed by French administrative law. As such, in addition to the termination rights as provided under the relevant concession agreement, the contracting public authorities may be entitled to special rights to modify or terminate a concession agreement for public interest grounds (motif d’intérêt général) or for a serious contractor’s default (faute d’une _gravité suffisante), even if such rights are not provided for under the relevant concession agreement. Such_ concessions may entitle their holder to manage surrounding on-street parking as well as to collect parking fees, as set by the relevant public authority, on the latter’s behalf. Concession holders collecting parking fees, insofar as such fees are generally considered as public funds, may be considered as a de facto public accountant (comptable _de fait) in the event they carry out their activities beyond the remit of a lawful underlying title. As such, they may_ be held liable in case of default in the management of such public funds. In France, a set proportion of EV charging points for electric and hybrid vehicles must be installed whenever there are more than 10 parking spaces located in or adjoining new non-residential buildings. Further, non-residential buildings comprising a parking facility of more than 20 parking spaces must be equipped, by January 1, 2025, with at least one EV charging point, located on a parking space which size allows access for people with reduced mobility. Such EV charging point must be installed for each additional 20 parking spaces. Public authorities may grant subsidies for parking facility operator’s investments relating to EV charging points. Such subsidies may be granted within the framework of financing contracts with public authorities and may levy several obligations on the beneficiary of the subsidy, such as notification obligations in the event of a change of control. There are no specific licenses or approvals required in order to own and operate car parks in France. However, several other administrative authorisations could be required. Further, parking facilities in France may be considered as facilities open to the public (établissements recevant du public)_ and, as such, be subject to requirements regarding, among others, accessibility and fire safety, as well as periodic on-site visits by the relevant administrative authority in order to verify compliance with such requirements. Non-compliance with such requirements may result in sanctions, including site closure in the event of serious breaches. 142 ----- Setting up and operating parking facilities is usually subject to a prior town-planning approval by the relevant administrative authority. It may also be subject to prior administrative approval and/or environmental study under French environmental law depending on the facilities involved on the concerned site. In addition, Loi n° 2023_175 du 10 mars 2023 relative à l’accélération de la production d’énergies renouvelables (the “ENR Law”) requires the operator (gestionnaire) of an outdoor parking space with an area of more than 1,500 square meters to equip at least half of such area with roofing or shade structures integrating renewable energy production equipment, it being specified that certain exclusions are provided for under such law. In certain cases, this requirement may apply to certain parking facilities as early as July 1, 2026. In Germany, there are no national regulations that specifically focus on the operation of parking facilities. There are however general rules governing, for example, environment and safety, which may have to be complied with when operating a parking facility. Moreover, depending on the exact location of the parking facility, specific municipality rules may also apply. The Regulation (EU) 2023/1804 on the deployment of alternative fuels infrastructure (AFIR) entered into force on 13 April 2024. AFIR is directly applicable in the various EU countries in which we operate, without any action by national legislators. AFIR updates and replaces the current Alternative Fuels Infrastructure Directive (EU Directive 2014/94 EU). AFIR sets out, among other things, certain obligations on Recharging Point Operators (“RPOs”) for publicly accessible EV charging points installed following its application. These obligations on RPOs include: (a) facilitation of contactless card payments; (b) permitting ad hoc access to charging infrastructure for users; (c) providing clear and easily available information on the ad hoc price; and (d) ensuring that EV charging points are capable of smart charging. In addition, AFIR includes several obligations in relation to existing publicly accessible EV charging points that must be met by a specific date. These obligations include (a) ensuring that all such EV charging points must be digitally-connected EV charging points by October 14, 2024; and (b) all direct current EV charging points operated by them have a fixed recharging cable installed by April 14, 2025.

Subsection Title: Rebalancing Provisions in Off-street and On-street French Concessions
Subsubsection Text: Concession agreements may include a rebalancing clause which allows the concession holder to demand fair compensation from the public authority that granted the concession in certain circumstances where the contract renders less than the expected returns. The changes that can give rise to a claim for compensation include the adoption of administrative, regulatory or legal measures or other external events occurred to the parties that were unforeseen at the time the contract was made, which affect the long-term economic benefit of the contract in a material way to the detriment of the concession holder. The compensation granted by the public authority can include, depending on the circumstances, an extension of the concession term (subject to the maximum legal term) or an increase in the tariffs chargeable to customers or paid by the contracting authorities (for on-street concessions, when applicable). If applicable, the public authority may grant additional parking spaces under the existing concession or another change of the economic terms of the concession agreement between the municipality and us. The application of the rebalancing clause is not an automatic procedure and the compensation granted will vary on a case-by-case basis.

Subsection Title: New Business
Subsubsection Text: From January 1, 2021 to March 31, 2024, we signed a total of 61 asset deals for parking facilities consisting of 38 new operating contracts for parking facilities and 23 negotiated contract renewals for parking facilities as well as seven bolt-on acquisitions of parking facilities at our legally owned properties and under long-term leases and concessions, which are estimated to have contributed an aggregate amount of €40.3 million in “run-rate” EBITDA from January 1, 2021 to March 31, 2024, which represents the EBITDA generated from all new contracts signed during the relevant period, assuming that each new contract is being performed at its full maturity potential assessed by us at the time of signing of such contract on the basis that (i) all parking spaces under each contract will be made available during the relevant period, (ii) all revenue generating functions of our business have been realized and (iii) the customary ramp-up period has passed. The 61 new asset deals and seven bolt-on acquisitions have an average contract duration of approximately 18 years and have an average period to recover the costs from the “run-rate” EBITDA of such assets of approximately five years. Furthermore, we concluded a number of onstreet management contracts. On June 4, 2024, we acquired 100% of the issued share capital of Britannia Parking Group Limited, one of the leading parking operators in the United Kingdom. Pursuant to the Britannia Acquisition, we acquired 629 car 143 ----- parks ranging from multi-storey parking facilities to conventional pay and display parking and added 62,000 parking spaces to our portfolio. In 2023, we signed a total 18 contracts that included three bolt-on acquisitions, ten new contracts and five renewals. In addition, the integration of the Paris La Défense contract (won in 2021) into our portfolio marks one of the key highlights in our growth and expansion, where we added 15 parking facilities and more than 20,000 parking spaces under a concession agreement for eight years. The Paris La Défense contract has generated Underlying Gross Margin of €5.7 million in the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. The Underlying Total Revenue and Underlying EBITDA generated by greenfield parking facilities gradually ramp-up over the first three to four years after they become operational, and then typically remain stable with moderate increases due to inflationary adjustments and volume increases (largely reflecting increased demand due to increased traffic in cities) for the remaining term of the contract. Our new business strategy is outlined centrally following broader corporate strategy. New business opportunities are mainly sourced by local business development (“BD”) teams. Our Chief Financial Officer supervises the central business development department. The central business development team sets the direction by supporting and challenging the local business development teams in developing new business proposals. They are engaged in all strategic transactions, such as mergers, acquisitions and divestments. We have a well-established and disciplined process for evaluating new business opportunities. Centrally, we maintain a multi-disciplinary Investment Committee (“IC”) comprising members of our senior management team in Business Development, Real Estate and Finance that reviews and evaluates new business opportunities. New business proposals with an annual lease commitment or accumulated investment of greater than €0.1 million require Executive Board (“EB”) approval, and are submitted to the IC by our local BD teams. Proposals and financial models submitted as part of this process must follow standard rules and formats, and all project proposals must include key assumptions, security margins, sensitivity analyses, benchmarking and an analysis of expected competition. The IC may ask for clarifications on the proposal or advises on changes to a proposal submitted by local BD teams. The proposal is reviewed by our IC which provides a recommendation to the EB to reject the proposal, approve the proposal or to approve the proposal under certain conditions. When evaluating an opportunity, the IC considers targeted returns, the proposed contract terms, expected consumer demand for the parking facility, potential risks and possible economies of scale with the existing business. Contracts are only signed after formal approval of the EB. We believe that this dedicated approach allows us to properly evaluate and respond in a timely and efficient manner to potential business opportunities. Projects with an annual lease commitment of greater than €10 million or initial investments greater than €10 million must also be approved by our shareholders. Approved projects that are won and become operational are subject to a subsequent monitoring follow-up plan that can last over five years.

Subsection Title: ICT and Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our ICT strategy is focused on improving our data infrastructure and analytical capabilities to enable an increasingly advanced pricing strategy. Our revenue is driven by volumes and pricing, with volume being driven by the location of the parking facility and targeted sales initiatives and price being actively used to increase revenue as demand is relatively inelastic. Data analytics are key to enable more advanced pricing management. Day-to-day pricing management is crucial given low marginal costs. Pricing in the parking market is moving from pay-by-the-hour to pay-by-the-minute, and from periodic price adjustments to continuous optimization in our high-traffic, busier facilities, where differentiated pricing models produce higher revenues. Our pricing strategy is to focus on setting the right price at any time in any facility. This includes customizing pricing plans for individual car parks to maximize revenue based on central sharing of best practices, applying tariffs that suit the location, the services offered in the surroundings of the facility (for facilities serving casinos, restaurants, offices and shopping centers) and the customer, creating big data analytics to analyze and react to customer behavior, and optimizing a mix of short-term and long-term rates to leverage both peak-hour short-term rates as well as downtime long-term utilization. Our pricing management is based on careful analysis and monitoring, with analysis performed at a parking facility level. The availability of data analytics support pricing segmentation and the rounding of parking tariffs, among other innovations. Our resulting pricing improvement initiatives include differentiated pricing models during events and based on specific needs (such as lunch time specials), flexible pricing based on frequency and/or duration, and optimization of day tariffs in facilities where a significant number of customers park for more than six or eight hours. 144 ----- Another example of our investment in ICT is PaSS (Parking as a Smart Service). The core engine of PaSS is a cloud-based technology platform that allows us to interact and provide services virtually to our customers and business partners via a “plug-and-play” approach. We use automatic number plate recognition (ANPR) to identify customers at our car parks (at entry and exit), charge them via a central cloud-based billing engine and allow them to pay automatically via a chosen electronic payment method. The benefits of this digital transformation include: - For our customers: o Seamless, no-touch parking experience in and out of our car parks, requiring no ticket, no physical payment card or cash, and no queuing; o Automatic payment via a method chosen by the customer and linked to their profile, with multiple number plates per user allowed; o Flexibility to use any automatic, virtual payment method linked on profile, such as personal debit or credit cards, digital wallets, direct debit or third-party mobile applications (e.g., EasyPark, KBC banking mobile application, or mobile payment methods like 4411 in Belgium); o Ability to digitally buy longer-term subscriptions, to pre-book a parking space or to “payas-you-go” with a post-payment electronic invoice, which can be provided after every transaction or in bulk; and o Increased choice for parking as well as charging (in addition to the limited, on-street options in cities). - For our business partners, such as landlords, municipalities or commercial third parties like EasyPark or Ticketmaster: o Easy on-boarding onto our digital platform, which is completed as a “plug-and-play” mechanism via application programming interfaces (“APIs”) for third parties; o Ability to offer a differentiated, higher level of satisfaction and convenience to customers, as customers would no longer need to use paper tickets or validation machines and can make bookings online easily; and o Flexibility for landlords and municipalities to accelerate the journey towards “smart parking” within “smart cities” through seamless integration via our digital platform into the wider “smart city” ecosystems. - For us: o More engaged and loyal customer base and stronger collaboration with third-party business partners, which leads to increased parking transaction volumes and revenue across sales channels; o Ability to centrally harness transactional data, which allows us to customize our offering and pricing to individual customers based on their preferences and parking behavior; and o A standardized digital platform that eliminates the complexity of operating non-standardized facilities with varied local characteristics and on-site technology, which results in reduced operating expenditure and capital expenditure costs. We have experienced positive results from continued investments in digitization (via PaSS) and have begun to experience the benefits of the commercial insights it delivers. PaSS is now available in all of the seven countries in which we operate, in 459 parking facilities. It is anticipated that PaSS will drive further mobility through both our own online sales channels, our Q-Park App and third-party partnerships, including with 4411, easypark, easytrip, KBC and RingGo. Through our third-party partnerships, we have a direct connection for on-demand, pay-as-you-go short-term parking via our partners’ apps. Other partnerships include collaborations with purpose partners and providers of public transportation. This also allows us to offer tailored customer propositions and differentiated pricing. Through our ecosystem partnerships, we also have the ability to react more proactively to 145 ----- innovations like “smart city” concepts and “mobility as a service” (“MaaS”). As of and for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our: - total digital revenues were approximately €83 million, with an increase of approximately 8% in our total digital revenues compared to the year ended December 31, 2023; and - digitization efforts have resulted in approximately 9% of all parking transactions being processed via PaSS (paperless and seamless). A key pillar in our operating model is the Q-Park Control Room (“QCR”), which we believe is a differentiating factor compared to our competitors. The QCR is an international help desk, available 24/7, and its employees have direct access to on-site employees, service technicians and the customer service department. The QCR gives customers instant access to multi-lingual employees who can provide help and support with queries relating to the payment system or relating to accessing or exiting the parking facility. The QCR improves quality, customer satisfaction and by remote operations delivering efficiency, by decreasing working hours and the number of complaints and lowering parking management costs. We believe that automation and advances in technology can enhance customer experience, lower labor costs, improve cash management and increase overall profitability. We have introduced a number of automation and technology based services in recent years, including a large scale LED program, parking guidance and access systems and cashless payment solutions.

Subsection Title: Property
Subsubsection Text: As of March 31, 2024, the market value of our properties, predominantly located in large and attractive cities, was €1.8 billion. The portfolio comprises 123 properties consisting of legally owned and ground leases. Such market value has been prepared without comprehensive due diligence or the benefit of an inspection of all of the properties. We lease our main corporate offices in Maastricht in The Netherlands. We also lease regional offices in Rotterdam and The Hague in The Netherlands and we also lease regional offices in the countries in which we operate.

Subsection Title: Suppliers
Subsubsection Text: Historically, our primary suppliers have been construction companies and contractors who build our parking facilities. These complement our in-house design team, thereby alleviating the dependence on external suppliers. We also rely on suppliers of parking management systems and information technology. For parking management systems, we fulfil our requirements from a limited number of international suppliers. We purchase our information technology requirements from a variety of suppliers, our main suppliers being Cegeka (ICT development and certain operations) and Expereo (MPLS data lines). Although the infrastructure in some cases is owned by us, the EV charging points in our facilities are operated by third-party service providers. As of March 31, 2024, we partnered with a total of five EV charging point operators.

Subsection Title: Contract Counterparties
Subsubsection Text: Our contractual counterparties, with whom we enter into lease agreements, concessions or contract management agreements, include municipalities, semi-public entities and private companies. As of March 31, 2024, we had 187 parking facilities in concessions within 47 cities, 446 leased parking facilities (majority of them being with private landlords). We manage our relationships with these counterparties on a centralized, regional and local basis. In general, the same personnel that manage our contracts on an ongoing basis are responsible for maintaining relationships with our clients. A number of our concessions are managed by personnel who have developed longstanding relationships with the municipalities and private entities with whom we enter into concession management agreements. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our top 20 contracts by Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs) represented 21% of our Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs).

Subsection Title: Corporate Social Responsibility
Subsubsection Text: Environmental, social and governance (“ESG”) considerations are important to us, our stakeholders and market participants. We have been integrating sustainability principles in our business since 2010. In addition to our compliance with relevant laws and regulations in relation to ESG and sustainability, including our preparations to 146 ----- ensure we comply with Directive (EU) 2022/2464 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 14 December 2022 amending Regulation (EU) No 537/2014, Directive 2004/109/EC, Directive 2006/43/EC and Directive 2013/34/EU, as regards corporate sustainability reporting (the “EU Corporate Sustainability Reporting

Subsection Title: Directive” or the “CSRD”) and Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2023/2772 of July 31, 2023
Subsubsection Text: supplementing Directive 2013/34/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council as regards sustainability reporting standards, and as well as with the EU Corporate Sustainability Due Diligence Directive (“CSDDD”) (which was approved by the Council of the European Union on May 24, 2024 (thereby completing the adoption process)), we are developing a corporate social responsibility (“CSR”) strategic framework in line with CSRD requirements. Following the entry of CSRD into force in the EU on January 5, 2023 and our obligation to start reporting in 2026 for the year ended December 31, 2025, we intend to use the European Sustainability Reporting Standards (the “ESRS”) where applicable and relevant, as per the Commission Delegated Regulation 2023/2772 of July 31, 2023 supplementing Directive 2013/34/EU as regards sustainability reporting standards. As part of our ESG considerations, we set targets for at least the top five key themes we have identified and align these themes with our key programs such as (i) the energy program, which includes EV charging points, renewable energy generation, sourcing and energy storage, (ii) the sustainable mobility partnership program which includes mobility hubs and mobility partnerships, (iii) the digital program, which encourages sustainable mobility innovation and seamless parking services and (iv) the CSR program, which includes our CSR strategic framework, emission-free and liveable cities, embedding ESG and sustainability principles into our Group’s processes, services and products. Our guiding principles include: (i) meeting the needs of today without limiting the needs of future generations, (ii) aligning with our purpose, vision, ambitions and activities, (iii) iterating and evolving over time to get closer to desired results, (iv) engaging stakeholders to share goals and clarify efforts and (v) prioritizing the most significant impacts on the environment and society. Sustainable development is an important aspect of our values and strategy. We are committed to the furtherance and achievement of the United Nations’ 17 Sustainable Development Goals, particularly those pertaining to affordable and clean energy, industry, innovation and infrastructure and sustainable cities and communities. Our sustainable development activities and contributions include the following: - increase substantially the share of renewable energy in energy consumption. Equipping selected and above ground parking facilities with solar panels, wind turbines and other means of generating renewable energy and focus on energy efficiency of equipment, installing LED lighting and sensors, and other operational measures; - develop high-quality, reliable, sustainable and resilient infrastructure by offering (i) attractive offstreet parking facilities, which make urban amenities and essential amenities such as hospitals, airports, universities and city centers, more accessible and (ii) mobility hubs to enable customers to easily change to public transport, bicycle or other modes of transportation; - upgrade infrastructure and retrofit industries by investing in LED lighting to reduce energy consumption, installing EV charging points to support electrification of the urban fleet, renovating, repurposing and upgrading existing parking structures, working with environmentally-friendly and circular building materials and methods; - enhance inclusive and sustainable urbanization by working closely with local authorities to analyze changing mobility patterns and devise innovative responses, such as implementing smart parking tariffs and increasing the number of parking permits for residents and pre-booking options; - reduce adverse environmental impact of cities and provide access to secure parking spaces. We aim to reduce car traffic created from searching for parking spaces by providing dynamic parking information and encouraging customers to pre-book their parking space. We also aim to provide off-street parking to help create car-free zones and public spaces which can be transformed into urban parks and town squares; - provide universal access to safe, inclusive and accessible green and public spaces by offering offstreet parking to create car-free zones and public spaces that can be transformed into public venues; - support links between urban, peri-urban and rural areas by strengthening national and regional development planning by providing “Park + Ride” solutions and being part of mobility hubs, which contribute to connecting rural and urban areas and reducing car traffic in city centers; 147 ----- - share knowledge and cooperate with third parties by encouraging students to conduct research into urban mobility and parking issues through our Student Award scheme in partnership with Erasmus University Rotterdam, holding annual educational events on parking and mobility; and participating in industry-wide events and opening our database for academic research; - enhance policy coherence for sustainable development by developing and adapting sustainability policies according to our stakeholders’ needs; - enhance local, national and international partnerships with public and private organizations to implement sustainable technologies for EV charging, sustainable power generation and urban mobility; and - encourage effective partnerships through our sustainable mobility partner program. Tangible ways in which we have carried out actions to meet our sustainability goals include our focus on offstreet business, which contributes 90% of our Underlying Gross Margin (excluding non-allocated and central operating costs); our reduction by more than 50% of market-based average carbon dioxide emissions per parking space between 2021 (93.3 kilograms) and 2023 (45.4 kilograms); our reduction by 12.7% of energy consumption (only parking facilities; excluding GWh consumed by EV charging points) between December 31, 2021 and December 31, 2023; our LED lighting initiative across our parking facilities, which further contributed to the reduction of energy consumption and cost; our focus on bicycle parking solutions, which experienced a growth of 47.2% between 2021 (55 parking facilities with designated bicycle parking) and 2023 (81 parking facilities with designated bicycle parking) and the installation of EV charging points, which also experienced a growth of 94.6% between 2021 (2,114 charging points) and 2023 (4,114 charging points) and which are now available in approximately 283 facilities across all the seven countries in which we operate (as of December 31, 2023) with plans for further roll-outs.

Subsection Title: Employees
Subsubsection Text: As of March 31, 2024, we employed 2,207 full-time equivalents. We believe that our relations with employees are satisfactory. We have not experienced any strikes or work stoppages that have had a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations.

Subsection Title: Competition
Subsubsection Text: The off-street car parking industry in Europe is highly fragmented with a limited number of large players. We believe that most countries in Europe have between three and five large private companies in the car parking market, accounting for between 10% and 30% of the total market share in such countries. Accordingly, market dynamics make it possible for large private players to acquire small competitors at discounted multiples, thereby driving market consolidation and scale. Due to our scale, long-standing industry experience and established relationships with municipalities and private landlords, we are typically able to achieve significant synergies that also allow us to offer competitive terms and win new business. However, we face competition from other parking operators in the bidding process for contracts and concessions. We also face this competition when our concessions and contracts come up for renewal and when we bid on concessions of others which are coming up for renewal. Due to our highly diversified business mix and long-standing relationships with a diverse number of local authorities, we believe that we are well positioned compared to our competitors. Since the Weighted Average Remaining Duration of our long-term contracts was approximately 47 years as of March 31, 2024, we face limited competition in the near future to maintain our portfolio. Additionally, there are several barriers to entry to obtain new contracts and concessions. These barriers to entry include having the relevant experience, technology and being familiar with the relevant administrative tender processes. Our parking facilities face competition for end-users with nearby parking options. In general, we believe endusers are not willing to park more than a short walk from their intended destination, so competition is generally based on location and proximity to a customer’s intended location (covering a radius of approximately 700-800 meters around the car park). Therefore, we may face competition from parking structures built nearby. We believe this competition is normally limited since many of our parking facilities have limited direct competition within easy walking distance and the risk of new structures being built is mitigated by the cost and difficulty of developing new parking facilities in city centers due to the high density and planning regulations. Despite a limited number of private facilities surrounding our concessions, the terms of the concessions provide us with some exclusivity within the areas covered by the relevant concession. We benefit from broad country diversification, 148 ----- scale and focus on a strong asset base or infrastructure-driven contract mix. Furthermore, we believe that in comparison to our leading competitors, many of whom act as only concession holder or operators, our highly diversified business mix, which is focused on ownership and long-term contracts, our limited reliance on municipalities, which gives us flexibility on capital expenditure, our presence in attractive and high-growth countries and cities, and our strong local positions and market shares with a focus on multi-functional parking facilities place us in a strong competitive position.

Subsection Title: Legal Proceedings
Subsubsection Text: We are party to various legal proceedings involving routine claims that are incidental to our business. See “Risk Factors—Risks relating to our Business and Industry—Adverse litigation judgments or settlements _resulting from legal proceedings in which we may be involved in the normal course of our business could materially adversely affect our business, results of operations or financial condition,” “Risk Factors—Risks relating to our Business and Industry—We may face complaints or litigation from season ticket holders with respect to our long-term parking facilities,” “Risk Factors—Risks relating to our Business and Industry— Instances of fraud, bribery, corruption and ethics, integrity and privacy breaches involving our management, employees, business partners or agents could expose us to penalties and reputational damage and could hinder our ability to acquire or renew contracts or even continue our operating activities” and “Risk Factors—Risks relating to our Business and Industry—We conduct business in multiple jurisdictions and are exposed to changes in tax laws, tax rates and their application and interpretation in the markets in which we operate, and we have been (and may continue to be) subject to significant claims related to tax disputes and audits.” Although our legal_ and financial liability with respect to such proceedings cannot be estimated with certainty, we do not believe that the outcome of these legal proceedings, individually or in the aggregate, will have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations. 149 -----

Subsection Title: MANAGEMENT Supervisory Board and Executive Board of Q Park B.V.
Subsubsection Text: The Issuer, a direct subsidiary of the Parent, directly owns Q Park B.V., but as Q Park B.V. falls under the Dutch mitigated large company regime, the operations of Q Park B.V. and its subsidiaries will effectively be controlled by the executive board of Q Park B.V. (the “Executive Board”) and supervised by the supervisory board of Q Park B.V. (the “Supervisory Board”). We are governed by a two-tiered board structure comprising a Supervisory Board and an Executive Board. The Supervisory Board is responsible for supervising the policies and management of the Executive Board and the general affairs of the Group, including the interactions with our shareholders. The Supervisory Board also advises the Executive Board and certain resolutions of the Executive Board are subject to approval by the Supervisory Board. The general meeting of shareholders appoints the members of the Executive Board and determines the remuneration and other conditions of employment of the members of the Executive Board. The Executive Board conducts our business in accordance with the applicable laws and regulations, the guidelines and policies established by the Dutch Civil Code, Q Park B.V.’s articles of association, the Executive Board regulations and the Supervisory Board regulations. The Dutch mitigated large company regime applies to Q Park B.V.. The general meeting of shareholders has the power to appoint, suspend and dismiss the members of the Executive Board and the Supervisory Board has the power to suspend members of the Executive Board. Under the mitigated large company regime as applied by Q Park B.V., the general meeting appoints the members of the Supervisory Board pursuant to a binding nomination by the Supervisory Board, taking into account any recommendation rights of the general meeting. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the Supervisory Board consists of seven members, all of whom are nominees of our shareholders. The Supervisory Board consists of board members A and board members B. The Supervisory Board has the power to review key strategic decisions of Q Park B.V.’s management.
